I was a seasoned Command & Conquer veteran before I tried this and let me tell you, this gave me whiplash. Going from controlling no more than a dozen units at a time to 100s was quite an adjustment. When I adjusted though, I realized that this is one of the best RTS games I have ever played. This game completely takes the macro of an RTS to its logical extreme and executes it beautifully. This is a gem of a game not only because its good; but also because its unique. Unfortunately there aren't any other games out there really quite like this one.

With all the crap RTS's that have come down the pipeline in the recent years, I almost always end up coming back to this game. Don't let the hours on recorded fool you, I've play well over 1000 hours off steam. This game is everything that an RTS needs. It's got distinct factions, is well balanced, plenty of units, the feel of real progression, viable units at all tiers of tech, and there is plenty of lore behind it. Do yourself a favor and if you are thinking about buying this game, just do it. You won't regret it. Fair warning though  there is a bit of a steep learning curve. Just youtube a couple of matches and you'll get the jist. I love this game, and until Chris Taylor tops this, I'll be playing for years to come. (Also, if you want multiplayer, get Forged Alliance Forever)

LAN multiplayer works, by the way, so this might be good for a LAN party (if people still do those).


Edit: Forged Alliance Forever is an extensive, community-developed "mod" which updates graphics and adds a LOT of maps, and a few other things. Unfortunately, that does not seem to support LAN multiplayer. If you like this base game, you may want to check that out as well.

This game is the epitome of Macroscale RTS games. Since its release, there has been none other like this and there may never be another one. The game just oozes class and passion of the developers, clearly evident in  the units and their designs. To me, this is the ultimate macro strategy game. The map sizes are huge, by huge I mean 81 KM x 81 KM in size. The sheer scale of the battles, the stratas being used, with recon fighters up top, followed by air superiority fighters, bombers, torpedo bombers, land and naval units, submerged units to giant mechs walking the ocean floor, it truly is an amazing sigh to see it all unfold. I also love how intelligence is vital, using radars, sonar and omni and then using counter intelligence to hide your units, truly insane. I can't recommend this game enough. One more thing, get the following mods:
1.) FAF: For multiplayer matches and general QOL improvements. A really good MOD which allows PVP as well as really good QOL improvements.
2.) LOUD project: My personal favourite as the entire core files of the game have been reworked, vastly improving the AI and allowing the game to finally run in excess of 40,000 units at once without any late game slowdown, enabling large scale epic warfare in the largest maps. The AI uses tactics well and changes them according to the situation. It turns each battle into a large strategic war where using integrated warfare tactics become essential. 

As an RTS fan, this game is the best in the macro scale. Nothing else even comes close. 10/10.
It still crashes too frequently, but this has been my favorite RTS game since it was released.

[h1]You're All Mad[/h1]
Came looking for a good RTS fix. Tried the original and found it incredibly rough. Then, saw many people suggesting giving it a skip and coming straight to this one, supposedly the 'best in the series.'

Begs the question: did I just skip an entire game's-worth of difficulty curve or are Supreme Commander fans just sadists? 

Well, given the absurdity of the very first level, I'm betting more on masochists.

Regardless, improved though this may be, my problems with the first still remain:

[list]
  [*]Glacial game speed.
  [*]Units are slow to respond to commands
  [*]"Commands" sometimes seem more like "suggestions." 
  [*]Units behave in some truly baffling, braindead ways. (Path-finding is all over the place, and I would regularly find my aerial units wandering off for impromptu 1-vs-20 dogfights, far away from any of my air defenses.)
  [*]I probably am doing any number of things wrong, but neither this nor the original concerned themselves much with explaining anything. This one offered an insultingly simplistic tutorial, and then there are the forums and Youtube to see how it's actually supposed to be played. 
[/list]

This is a ambivalent recommend. I have played it a lot, but now I am going to park it.
For me the first RTS was Dune II. Then the original C&C, AOE2, warcraft 2, starcraft, Dark reign 2, Empire earth, C&C generals, ... I have seen many along the way.

The game is very old and the company behind it is no more. You should get this old title for historical insight in the genre and to broaden your RTS perspective, not for (the lack of) technical merits, but despite them to get a different angle on things.

As tech has advanced since then, the game has aged badly in comparison. This should be taken both figuratively and literally - it was targeted to run on XP. That is 2 versions of windows before windows 7, for you youngsters out there.
As such it is lacking a lot of modern features both technically behind the scenes and UI/controls.

This game is great. But the learning curve for multiplayer is ridiculous. I definitely missed the window to play the multiplayer by 10 years. At this point everyone who does play knows exactly what they're doing. If you're not willing to dedicate dozens of hours to practice, you're not getting past the bar of entry. I know there's plenty of tutorials online that teach you "how to play" - but it feels practically impossible to play this game in a casual sense. If you're into competitive RTS you'll probably love this, but it's not for me. I've given it plenty of time and chances to convince me otherwise but so far nothing has clicked. Props to the FAF community for their dedication... but this is about as niche as it gets

No other RTS game in the past 14 years can match this game's complexity and diverse play options. Its an open sandbox for trying different strategies. You can mess with settings and map sizes to get large battles spamming thousands of units or small skirmishes where knowing the individual traits of each type of unit will matter. Other RTS games tend to be smaller in scope and have simple economy mechanics. It's replay-ability is very high. Add on the modding community and FAF (look that up later) and you will find that this old game still has legs.

Despite being a huge fan of RTS genre i can't reccomend this game

The game looks like all possible bad ideas in one product

1. You need 3 different types of workers to build 3 different lvls of buildings. In all other games it's just one type worker units with multitasking, here, to build a specific structure, you should first produce a specific type of workers. 

2. Usually, you unlock new units by building some structure or doing the research. Not in this game. Instead, if you have 3 factories and you need siege tanks, you need to upgrade manually EVERY SINGLE factory to lvl 2, and than do it again to lvl 3 in each building.

3. You can (and must) upgrade your reactors, but, unlike every other RTS, here extractors STOP MINING for all long upgrade period. So you can't just upgrade all of them at one time - you will lost all income until upgrade is finished.

4. In other RTS games if you have overflow on some resource, it continue to rise to be spent later, when you notice.
Here there is a limit and it as very low, and when you reach it in a couple of seconds, you blocked, you just losing energy or mass. Only solution is to build storages for mass and energy. A lot of them.

5. Should i mention that instead of building generators to produse energy, this game has 3 different lvls of generators, and every type of cource, should be built only by specific engineer? 

Eco in this game purposely made so hard and frustrating, i can't understand how anyone can have fun struggling with it.
I really glad they fixed all this problems in Supreme Commander 2 and i really recomend you to play that game instead of this one.
Download Forged Alliance Forever :)

SC:FA is probably my favourite all time RTS. 
I played the original SC more, and picked it up on Steam later to play it again. 

With the gold edition, you get both for a great price, and it's worth playing the original for the campaign, but after that it's FA ftw. It got a major overhaul to many aspects of the gameplay, and adds another faction, so it's overall a much better game.

The control system and Sorian AI are good enough that skirmishes are still fun years later.
I still regularly play the campaign with each faction too, from time to time.

It's definitely not perfect, the story is absolute cringe and the NPC chatter is grating af, but the huge maps, control system and AI opponents, is where it's at. Turn down the voice-over to a level where it can be comfortably ignored, and it's a great game I still play to this day.

If you don't like the idea of battles that take 1-2hours, it might not be your cup of tea as there is a bit of commitment in that regard. Although you can of course save, and load later.

The quintessential Supreme Commander experience. The Campaign throws you into the deep end because it expects you to have played the base game campaigns but the massive UI and control improvements are well worth it.

It also makes a heap of balance changes and quality of life improvements (tier 3 mobile SAM ground units and a "factory HQ" system that means you only need to fully upgrade 1 factory and can immediately build factories at tier 2 & 3 as long as your HQ building is alive for example)
Still THE best (and my favorite) game of all time!

The short answer: SCFA is a game with a ridiculously high skill ceiling, allowing for a LOT of upward growth and progression, but it can also be played about as casually as you want. Either way, the game is an amazing take on the RTS genre, with one of the biggest senses of scale on the market.

The long story: the original SC was really, REALLY rough around the edges. Units had some pretty dumb pathfinding, certain weapons / units were a little broken (in both OP and just plain broken terms) and could overall use polish... but it set a fine enough story to be progressed here. In this expansion, you get an entirely new story, a few new units, a new faction, and many of the broken factors are fixed; pathfinding is still a disgusting issue, but that's just because this is a pretty old game. If you want to play online, easily mod, or just enjoy a bit of a better experience, remember to get Forged Alliance Forever, a free community-made client to this game.

Land, air, navy, buildings, artillery, nukes, you name it, everything is available in this game. Want to steamroll opponents with a neverending horde of tanks and mechs? Go for it. Want to airstrike them into oblivion with bombers, own the skies with fighters, and pummel them with a stream of gunships? You got it. Want to dominate the water and blast your opponent off their barren rock from afar? Navy is your approach. You can even do all of them at once to be the unpredictable menace you know you can be. Improve your economy to fuel your hungering war machine with higher-tier mass extractors and power generators, make shields and turrets for your factories, or build massive artillery installations whose range can span half an entire map, annihilating everything in the blast zone. Or unleash your faction's nuclear arsenal with strategic missile launchers, the choice is all yours. Do them all at once to be the real supreme commander.

And it would be a crime not to mention the experimental units the game offers. Massive mobile factories with battleship-grade weapons? Sign me up. Multi-legged spiderbots with microwave lasers mounted on their heads? Sure thing! Flying saucers with death beams on the bottom? Gargantuan bombers that can annihilate entire armies in one bomb? Experimental artillery classified as game-ending? This game has something for everyone, and a lot of times, you don't need much strategy. Choose the faction that most suits you, because they all were meticulously designed not to overwhelm the others; they all have their strengths and weaknesses, but none of them inherently beat the others by themselves. Cover your weaknesses, bolster your strengths, and choose your tactics appropriately. Dive in and become the supreme commander.
Excellent successor to Total Annihilation.

Man oh man do I love this game. [strike]Although it appears I don't have much time on this game (I had to leave it open for five minutes so that I could make this review[/strike], I have been using the client "Forged Alliance Forever," a fan-made client for Forged Alliance multiplayer, that I highly suggest you download and play through in case you want to enjoy this game to the fullest. [strike]Unfortunately, FAF doesn't display on Steam when you've launched the program.[/strike] (It does now!!) This client comes with balance patches made lovingly by fans of the game for fans of the game, continuing even after the difficult death of Gas Powered Games, which resulted in the multiplayer dying, which is where FAF picks up. (The Steam version and FAF are different games entirely, allowing you to play either one. FAF just legally requires you to own a copy of the game so that you may play FAF.) Although I might be a newcomer to this game (around 30-50 hours), I can assure my love for this game is genuine and with good reason.

This game is incredibly difficult for newcomers, with a large skill floor and an even higher skill ceiling, which Supreme Commander 2 decided to fix by lowering the skill ceiling entirely, removing much of the complexity of the game; not to mention the fact that the game itself was made with consoles in mind, which was a result of a port to the Xbox melting the machine from the performance. So what makes it difficult?

People who know how to play this game will dumpster you. Completely and absolutely, no matter how good your talent for RTS is. You will learn from your mistakes, and have to tutor yourself in order to get better at the game. The variety of strategy and maps absolutely astounds me for a game that is one and a half decades old. You are your own greatest enemy when you are a newcomer. If you mess up your economy early, more proficient players will easily take advantage of the time and resources you have wasted to mount an attack and absolutely massacre you. Economy is no laughing matter, and very heavily punishing if not managed correctly. Stalling should be avoided in almost all cases, because the build times grow exponentially larger as you have less and less resources to put into build orders, which leads to a cascade effect on your economy; you lose time, which means you lose resources, losing you your ability to expand your economy, losing resources which you could've gained if you hadn't stalled, and the cycle repeats itself. I cannot stress enough how important your start is in this game.

In addition to economy being very difficult to manage for newcomers in this game, strategy is also key and difficult to learn. Of course, there are many rush and heavy offensive strategies, but how about defense? As a newcomer, the most likely tactic to pick would be to hunker down and turtle, using strong point-defense, anti-air, and shields to stop enemy fire. If this strategy, the so-called "You-Shall-Not-Pass" defense is employed, I can 100% guarantee that you will lose, spectacularly. Not only are your protections stagnant and not moving, allowing for an easy target, but point defenses and anti-air can be easily countered through ranged artillery, high health units, and/or experimentals. They do not move, and are sitting ducks for any kind of counterplay. Your utmost priority when it comes to defense is simply to create better units. This game is a shining example of "Offense is the best defense." How is a newcomer supposed to know that one of the main strategies for one faction is to do nothing but bolster resource generation so that they may rush a T3 Assault Bot? Just like any other game, you don't learn strategies by just intuition, you have to learn the meta of the game so that you know what to do and what your opponent is going to do.

So now that you've read through why this game is so difficult for newcomers, you might be asking, "Okay, so why do you like this game so much?" For starters, this game is so difficult for newcomers because it is there are so many options and strategies. The game is so open-ended that it makes it compelling to learn. It tells you, "So you think you're hot stuff huh? Alright, let me just drop a textbook on you about the strategy in this game, so daunting that it might turn you away." That might sound pretty awful, but learning is part of the fun when it comes to Forged Alliance. When you do well in this game, you feel like an absolute genius. When you do good in this game, you know that it wasn't luck (mostly), but pure skill on your end, you are absolutely sure that you did something right. When you can counter the opponent and end their ACU, the death nuke is just so absolutely satisfying. This game isn't for everybody, just like RTS isn't for everybody.

My two gripes with this game is the learning curve and the other being my own fear that there will never be another RTS that will ever top this. Those in itself isn't so bad, though. I enjoy the fact that I actually have to learn about the game in a deeper sense to understand how to win. Oh, and also, on a smaller note, the AI isn't very good. The best way to practice is against other players, which might seem daunting, given that I just told you that older players will steamroll you, but there are many helpful, active players in the community, and also videos and guides to help you along the way. 

Good luck, Commander, and don't power stall.

A lot of the issues I had with Supreme Commander are resolved in Forged Alliance but not all.
The campaign is mostly difficult for the first 10-20min and then it is mostly easy. And, since missions last for over an hour with the map expanding after each objective being met, it is a slog fest when you get the hang of it (especially after the initial defence and base setup).

The story is not much better than in the first game. The new faction is quite powerful as it has all the ups of other factions - kind of like a jack of all trades. But that doesn't matter when you build up on units and swarm the enemy with all you've got.

The game sure is better than the first but still not much to talk about when playing it without any mods or just playing campaign.

Where the game really shines is with the modding community. Now THAT is the reason you get this game. "Forged Alliance Forever" is a must honestly. Custom missions, coop missions, new units, maps and more. Give that one a go and it just might turn a boring game into an awesome one.

Supreme Commander is an excellent RTS that still stands with the best of them even 10 years later.

The good:
- 4 factions which are well balanced
- Massive scale makes it good for macro players, but micro players can zoom right down and control individual units
- Unique resource scheme means that controlling your build is more crucial than ever.  Just two resources are available but the capability to over-subscribe and go into negatives makes it surprisingly nuanced.
- This isn't just a rush-fest.  Turtling is just as viable in this game.  A large variety of playstyles can be used each with their strengths and weaknesses.  Nothing quite beats the thrill of completing that massive artillery piece after 1.5 hours of real-time building it, then subsequently crushing your opponent from across the map.

The bad:
- Weak AI means that you have to use cheating AI, which is just unfair.  The Sorian AI helps but doesn't conpletely correct this.
- Online lobbies are a bit weak.  Thankfully Forged Alliance Forever largely fixes this: https://www.faforever.com/

The ugly:
- The un-modded AI tries to control dead units, which means that the game will slow down over time.  To make things worse, the original game hails from 2006 when multi-core CPUs were in their infancy.  As such it is single-threaded and your fancy 8-core CPU won't help.  All this means that the game will slow to a crawl during long player vs. AI games.  You really need the Sorian AI mod to fix this.  It is built into FaF: https://www.faforever.com/
Still one of the best RTS games out there with active community and support from Forged Alliance Forever

The stand-alone expansion following the events of Supreme Commander. I gave a review on the original game that covers a lot more detail about the game. This review will mostly focus on the changes that came with this isntallation.

[b]New Players[/b]:
Supreme Commander: Forged Alliance is an RTS game that is set far in the future, where the events of the first game continues. You can play one of four factions that consist of the UEF, Cybran, Aeon and the new faction known as the Seraphim. Each has their own unique aesthetics with different units that gets used to overwhelm the enemy commander.


[b]Review[/b]:
Off the bat, this is a greatly improved version of the game. It's still Supreme Commander, but plenty of quality of life changes got made that give the player a much better experience when playing.

[b]Game play[/b]:
The game has introduced a lot more units and structures with one of the better ones being engineer stations. Usually, you would create engineers to help assist with building and speeding unit production, but the station now automatically does it for you which saves a lot time, but also gives you some unit cap back.

The interface has also been changed and I found it much easier to find things than before. There's still the issue of icons being small with higher resolutions, but the setup is neater and much better organized.

The majority of everything else is the same. Get your economy running, build defenses, fuel an army and kill off the enemy commander. 

[b]Graphics[/b]:
I didn't notice too much of an upgrade. The Seraphim of course look pretty cool, but the main difference I noticed was the upgrade of portraits. Dostya, Rhiza, Burke and all the others are greatly enhanced which looks damn cool. I still opted to put most of my settings on low, because things can get distracting when playing such an RTS, and I prefer seeing information to detailed graphics.

[b]Story[/b]:
Events continue after one of the factions ([i]by the looks of it the Aeon[/i]), fired Black Sun. What unexpectedly followed was the a gate opening for the Seraphim who were waiting for an opportunity to strike. They took everyone by surprise and nearly annihilated the factions. Some of the Aeon broke off and create the Order to side with the Seraphim.

This forced the human factions to create an alliance to fight off the invaders. Once again, the player is given the option to choose which faction to represent, but this time, the entire campaign is the same for all three factions, with the difference being side-quests and which commander portraits display during the campaign.

I did not attempt to complete the campaign with all three factions. As much as I love this game, completing levels are time consuming and having to re-complete levels with the only change really being playing a different faction is not that appealing for me, but I'll come back to play this again at a later stage.

[b]Conclusion[/b]:
If you loved the original, you'll most probably love this one even more. By the time I completed the first one, I thought I was over it, but then starting off this one just got me back into it, especially with all of the upgrades and changes, not to mention, the story is also pretty good.

This is an RTS and it continues the story of    'Supreme Commander'.  Some characters will be there again. But the story is by far less clever. It has less twists and less surprises. 
 
The game has a good and slow starting tutorial about a few missions. You don't need it to understand the game if you have played   'Supreme commander'   or other RTS with base building. The fractions have different buildings. For the most of them, just the look is different. If you have played the first game this experience is a small adavantage. Of course every fraction has to produce energy and win material of the ground. But some fighting capabilities are really different. This is true for your fighting vehicles (air, water, ground) as well. The Mega-Fighting Vehicles can be described as  MECHs (like in Mech Warrior). And the ground units look like this. The grafics were modern when the game was new but they are still pretty today.
Since energy and material are short and special buildings to overcome the shortage are very expensive, it is important on what you spend your ressources. Different strategies can lead to victory - and I did not make the experience you can see in some videos on youtube: the nukes (nuclear missiles) do not always end the game - not at all. 
I like the gameplay of Supreme Commander - Forged Alliance a bit more than the gameplay of   'Supreme Commander'  -  its precessor. This counts for the campaign as well as for the free game maps. There could be more of them but after all these years I still have fun with them and the fight on a large map can last for hours. Some maps I play against several AI opponents and the alliances of fractions are totally free to your disposal. And the best is: you play the new (4th) alien fraction as well. This is great fun.

One last word: don't buy Supreme Commander 2 after you've played these two games mentioned here. You won't like it anymore even this is not a bad game.

The best large scale RTS i have ever played.  Even 16 years after it's release it still stands tall and has an active player base.  The community has taken over updating the game and providing matchmaking services after the official ones were discontinued.  (look for the "Forged Alliance Forever" launcher online.  They even made a patch so it runs on Linux.)

The game focuses more on macro strategy instead of micro so can appeal to those lower APM players like myself.  It has 4 factions with each roughly similar units, but each faction has notable aspects and shortcomings unique to their faction.  Despite the differences there is not a clear power imbalance between the 4 factions as long as they are played to their respective play styles.

One other notable thing that shines about this game to me is it's second monitor support and the ability to zoom out to the entire map.  This game does not have a mini map, but rather has no limit to how far out you can zoom the camera.  The second monitor acts like a completely seperate view and both can be zoomed in or out individually.  This means the second monitor can be a full screen "mini" map, or you can be watching two seperate sections of the battlefield and giving orders to both at the same time.  I have yet to see another game come close to the depth, polish, and uncommon features this game has.

So glad I picked this game up during my high school years and on Steam, one RTS game that I keep coming back to, even with today's modern titles.

The [u]Gameplay[/u] is unique from the other titles I've played, such as [b]StarCraft[/b] 1 & 2, [b]Command & Conquer[/b], [b]Company of Heroes[/b] 1 & 2, [b]Rise of Nations[/b], etc. You start with an empty map (depending on the settings) and spawn in with that sick shock wave that will burn the nearby trees, and soon after, the match begins as structures are erected at the crater. There are tiers in Supreme Commander, which makes this title stand out! Units are small at first but get deadlier as you upgrade the levels. If tier 3 units are not good enough, build an experimental unit.

The main [u]Story[/u]: Sadly, I never play it, even today... Mostly play Skirmish/Comp-Stomp (I wonder if that exists nowadays) with family and friends.

Have we got a noise complaint? No problem, show them this game, and once they blow up a commander, they will look at you and nod slowly. (Put it on easy otherwise, it's an eviction...)

A classic recommendation!

Coming from Starcraft 1 and 2, this is not the RTS for me, at all.

There are technical issues with no borderless fullscreen, no UI scaling, and a crap tutorial that crashes at the end. The UI itself is very hard to read.

The campaign maps are enourmous, and units are tiny, impossible to make out what you're looking at, constantly zooming in and out.

Units and structures take forever to build, descriptions are vague and upgrades are not very visible, and take even longer

The 'campaign' starts you with every unit on a huge map with an overwhelming enemy that destroys most units built until upgraded. The story is all boring exposition, no explanation other than kill the enemy.

Your own Air units will randomly wander around the map no matter what commands you give, getting destroyed immediately most of the time and wandering into anti-air range. There is no control of unit formations whatsoever.

I'm glad I only paid a couple dollars for this, waste of two hours.

This game, and its predecessor, Total Annihilation, were amazing RTSes at release that I still play today. Really a great game and you'd be hard pressed to find even a recent RTS release supplanting Supreme Commander. Even the computers of today can slow down from an epic Supreme Commander battle. I've had many years of enjoyment of both singleplayer and with friends out of this title.  Pathfinding, especially with the AI, can have issues, and the Soren AI is needed for a challenge.  This did get a spiritual sequel in the Kickstarted Planetary Annihilation, but I was not a fan even though I was a backer.  That game has AI that was trained with machine learning to be a better "smarter" player and a significantly different art style.

*Do NOT get Supreme Commander 2 as the franchise was purchased by Sega and significantly dumbed down.

Best. Strategy. Ever. Period. I grew up playing starcraft 1. Later I played starcraft 2. But this game? This is it, there is no reason to search for any other strategy. There are few things that makes that game so good. 1. Races are both similar and completely different. What does it even mean? Generally most races have the same setup of units, scouts, light mechs, tanks, medium tanks, light artillery, the list go on. Its not like one has zergling and other marines, which are completely different things. But. Units themselves differ, a lot. And skilled commander will abuse those differences. Maybe one unit has better rotating turret, better tracking, maybe its slightly faster. For a beginner its barely a difference, in reality its a line between op and useless.2. Resource system is pretty unique (I think Total Annihilation, which I believe is a spiritual parent of this game used it too). You both balance your income/spending and use your stock. Want to keep building army non stop? Sure, balance income and keep producing stuff indefinitely. Need to ramp up production because of strategic reasons? Sure, use your stockpile to produce more than your income allows. 3. Reclaiming. Technically its also about resources but it has deeper nuance to it. Throwin units at the enemy sounds fun and cool, but you gotta remember, that enemy can and will reclaim what he/she kills so by attacking without plan you basically give your enemy free stuff. On the other hand, well planned strike will earn you resources your enemy used.4. Maps have tons of different sized, which allows diversity in gameplay.5. Less logical BS. You wont see marine killing battlecruiser. 6. Combining air, ground and naval units is crucial. You might want invest more in one, but there will be no success if you just spam 1 or 2 units over and over again, and you better not give your enemy full air superiority.7. Game requires both micro and macro management from the player, skilled player will really shine.8. Now for surprise. The game is actually still developed, though by fans. Forged Alliance Forever keeps it alive, has client for easier matchmaking, downloading maps and so on. They rebalance the game, improve it, and even works on 5th race! (Which is I believe in beta right now).9. Graphics are old. But not "bad" old. The game is surprisingly pretty.10. Music is really catchy, 8/8 from me. 11. It is hella cheap, like seriously.See you on FAF!

I got into this series because in 2016 Supreme Commander 2 was free with Xbox Live gold, this with Halo Wars made me fall in love with RTS games in general. Recently I finally got a PC even though its a dell with a 12 dollar graphics card that I bought off of amazon but I'm able to try some games that I always wanted to play but couldn't because they were only on PC. Forged Alliance was one of these games and I absolutely enjoy it even though the game's age is rivaling mine to some extent. This game seems to be at the peak of it's genre while the whole RTS scene was pushed into obscurity by the huge rise of gamers and wide appealing games took over the market. The series tried to change with the time by making Supreme Commander 2 more simple to appeal to a larger audience but ended with destroying what it was known for by the fans of the series. This game is a relic in all senses and being kept alive by the small and dedicate community that have a huge amount of content they have made to keep it alive. The people behind FAF (Forged Alliance Forever) managed to bring the last of the community together and even made the story missions be able to play in CO-OP which I find insane.
I do highly recommend the game if you like strategy games and want something with a pretty large scale and depth to it because there ain't much like it right now.

Don't get me wrong, it's a good game but... one thing irks me... one common sin... 
This game creates the common sin of any RTS... 
...Unit caps... 
If Command & Conquer: Red Alert can diversify units without needing a unit cap and still have strategy? I'd expect the same from your game. Both in their prime were AAA titles... You know what also ruined evil genius 2 for a lot of people? Unit caps; capped at an abyismally small 300; the problem with that was you're conducting global operations and only had so many staff that when you maxed out you could get overwhelmed. Unit caps are the bane of actual strategic thinking. The only game I say did it right was Valkyira Chronicles 1 through 4, and that's because you can actually think of where to position everyone and get ready for the fight in advance, and the unit cap made sense because you were commanding a militia. 
 
So why do I take issue here with the unit cap? You're supposed to be leading an entire army, air force, and naval force. And you usually need so many energy, mass and storage facilities that those take up more of your unit cap than anything else, and upgrades dwindle this set of resources like nothing else burning through it in narely 10 seconds. The unit cap to me is a sign of cowardice and incompitence. For as cool as the game is with the extra one faction? 
The unit cap is the ice breaker... sorry.

The strategic scale of the game is simply unmatched, and the intel systems adds another layer of tactical depth. I cannot praise this game enough, truly one of the best RTS games of all time.

Great strategy game, a classic really, with an excellent campaign mode between this and the base game. It was innovative for its time and has a large scale which still is largely unmatched in RTS titles. It is kept alive by the Forged Alliance Forever launcher for multiplayer, and even has some mods which can add quite a bit (such as the Nomads faction which works quite well in multiplayer). I recommend it to anyone who loves RTS games and wants to experience a good classic, yet one that doesn't feel so dated as older classics.

(Don't mind my low hour count, that's going to change soon. Most of my SC knowledge is imported from SC 2 from 360, so I understand what I'm saying)
I first played the SC series in SC 2 on the 360. I got it free with gold and it was the shit! It was so much fun, and a fantastic RTS! And the thing that makes SC so special to me is that you're not limited to specific building plots. 

You want to build a factory over there? Be my guest! 

Want to colonize that island with mass? Go wild! 

Want to erect a series a walls with turrets and shields and couple artillery lines to keep the filthy seraphim from immigrating to your side of the map? Please do that actually, they are a menace and they keep bombing my factories so that I can't pay my under-aged "employees" to build my precious assault bots.

My point is that in terms of RTS games, in my opinion, SC stands above them with an iron fist! I've played plenty of them: Stellaris, Halo wars 1 and 2, Empire at War, Homeworld, Supreme Commander 2, Air Mech Arena (Yeah I know, that one is a bit odd), and Heroes and Castles 1 and 2 (Those 2 are RTS games YOU WILL NOT CHANGE MY MIND!!!), and the Supreme Commander games just stick with me the best. 

Last point. 
Supreme Commander Forged Alliance is every Supreme Commander 2 is, but dialed up to 13. 
-More units! 
-More structures!-4 factions! 
-More players per match! 
-Higher caps!
-THE ABILITY TO BE MODDED!
Words cannot describe my vast love for this game!

I used to play the first Supreme Commander as a kid. Growing up, it eventually became outdated. I never got to play online or anything, but years later here I am enjoying it once again. Forged Alliance brought back a lot of nostalgia for me, and only for around $2.00 since it was on a special sale! The maps are large and each game can take up to an hour or more to complete, depending on your set game mode. A buddy of mine and myself love battling against AI or each other, though it can be a little difficult with the matchmaking- you can still somewhat commonly come across multiplayer games. The mod support is also really cool and allows you to add more exciting aspects to the game if you want. If you're into real time strategy with minimal economy, multiple map size choices (some of them being absolutely massive), different factions for different play styles, and out just outright action packed fun- this is probably a game for you.

The game is incredibly unrestricted in terms of playstyles and there are lots of different ways to complete your objectives. The learning process can be tricky without external guides and tutorials. 
The main campaign is decent with a plenty of twist and surprises. Opponent AI is also decent enough, and with certain mods, it becomes much more adaptive and unpredictable. 

Personally, I would choose this over any other (similar) RTS including AoE 
or RoN. A remaster would be OP.

First, a disclaimer: I generally play only solo; the following review does not reflect multiplayer.

Much like the classic original Total Annihilation, The Supreme Commander series is a solid RTS that delivers pretty much constant action. I have found the Forged Alliance title to be the most replayable of the lot, mostly because of the differing faction unit options with their varying strengths and weaknesses within the same missions (Cybran is easiest and Aeon hardest). The downside is that there are only 7 missions, but even that is mitigated by them being multi-leveled, taking solid gameplay to work through (especially in hard mode). I had this before it came to steam, so I have played it through a lot more times than the 161 hours implies, and (unlike the aforementioned Total Annihilation) it plays equally well in the steam environment as it did off the disks back when.

SupCom is the most engaging, complex, and original game of its kind, only matched hopefully by its spiritual successor soon to come, Sanctuary: Shattered Sun. Since its release, players have logged thousands upon thousands of hours, not just playing but modding and improving the game. While the campaign as a story left much to be desired, its Skirmish mode and Multiplayer provide endless hours of combat, large-scale warfare, and delicious carnage. It pushed the boundaries of Real-Time Strategy and opened the doors to new gaming possibilities that none of its competitors have since attempted to explore.
Hop in and crush everything in your path.

Overall:
Supreme Commander: Forged Alliance is a fantastic real-time strategy game involving a unique selection of units for every faction, which invites players to experiment with different playstyles and strategies. 

One noteworthy element is the game's community, which is still ongoing despite being a game made in 2011. Please go to https://www.faforever.com/ to check out their client, connect with other players, play an updated/improved game version, and get access to various mods. 

Pros:
+Large variety of units within each faction, each having its strengths, weaknesses, and aesthetics
+Good single-player campaign
+Excellent economy/resource system that affects early game strategies and playstyles
+Graphics are still somewhat tolerable for a 2011 game
+Strong multiplayer community in Forged Alliance Forever, with access to competitions, ranking systems, mods, and more.

Neutral:
*Base game does not reveal certain strategic elements that are pretty important, especially in early game strategies (for example, adjacency bonus resource production)

Cons:
-The game slows down drastically in the base game when playing with friends (highly suggested to play multiplayer using FAF client instead if base game)

Supreme Commander: Forged Alliance is a cult classic at this point and to some considered the best RTS ever made. It features 4 unique factions, awesome experimental units which tower over normal ones, and an insanely high skill ceiling due to the potential micromanaging you can accomplish. (Though personally I'm pretty laid back.)

[b]However, if you're going to get into this game, I strongly recommend checking out FAF or the LOUD project.[/b]
FAF, Forged Alliance Forever, is a PvP focused continuation of the game with a dedicated playerbase, balancing, some fancy mods including a 5th faction, and tournaments.

If you're more interested in the PvE side of Forged Alliance, browse the internet instead for the LOUD project mod. This mod tunes up the AI to be a lot smarter and optimizes the game for larger scale battles. Very fun! And comes with its own built-in mods! (Optional, of course.)

This game is great by yourself or with other people, and despite how old it is, manages to still have a solid player count.

It's been a decade since my original review, and this is still the greatest strategy game ever made.

This is the greatest strategy game I've ever played.

If you like micro management, macro management, and armies of robots, you will sink 100's of hours into this masterpiece. Features four different yet balanced playable factions, multitudes of strategic options at your disposal, epic soundtrack, varied game modes, THOUSANDS of maps, full mod support - this game literally has it all.

Bombard your enemy with massive artillery from across the map? Sure.
Death from above with swarms of jet fighters? Allll day.
Nuke your enemy into oblivion with warheads? Go for it.
Break down their front door with hordes of robotic soldier drones? Heck yes.
Or maybe spend the entire game building one catastrophic engine of doom and fly over them with the flying saucer from hell, spewing lasers and bombs in every direction? Hey, why not.

All of these options and several more are in there, and each tactic can be countered by a different one. Your mind is the limit.

This is the greatest RTS of all time. If you download the LOUD AI mod to make the AI truly cunning, the game becomes even greater. 
Why is Supreme Commander: Forged Alliance the best RTS there is?
-The game is pure, undiluted RTS. No branching tech trees, no "doctrines" that lock you out of other playstyles, no "you can only build this unit once", no "you must capture this zone to score points", no bullsh*t. Each battle begins with just your Commander unit, and you can immediately start constructing all buildings and units from Tier 1. To access the next tech level, you just "buy" a simple Tier 2 upgrade, same for factories. This game is just you, the map, the AI, and all the units you can build. Pure, total war.
-This game may offer the largest battles of any RTS, with options for unit caps going up to 1000+. They don't HAVE to be large, but if "big boom-boom" is what you want, this is the game for you.
-Every unit is effective, there are no "useless" units.
-Every unit is balanced, there are no "OP instant win" units.
-The first player to the max tech level doesn't instantly guarantee victory, you can still have a meaningful chance at survival and victory even when your opponent outclasses you.
-The resource income & management is balanced without ever limiting what kinds of strategies you can play with.
-You can zoom all the way in...and all the way out. As in, close enough in that you can see the scratches on the paint, and far enough out that you can see *literally* the entire battlefield.
-You are given lots of options for customizing battles. Change the unit cap for all teams or only one team, restrict certain units, add civilian bases, add a "no starting rush" timer, various victory conditions, etc.
-Some of the best maps in any RTS (Seton's Clutch will always be my favorite)
-Still has an active multiplayer base
-Comes with a handful of optional mods you can activate if you want, to make the game easier, harder, or just different
-Very nice graphics, even by today's standards.
-Extremely intuitive UI and controls; SupCom is arguably the game that set the standard for UI's and control layouts for all RTS games to come
-Very effective system of alerts and sound cues. Never too frequent, never jarring, and each one is distinct.
-Each faction has a distinct artstyle, and each unit looks cool yet practical.
-The game even has a very nice OST, complete with contextual music tracks.

My original review received critical feedback, so here is attempt #2:

Since Sup Com: FA released in 2007, it has established itself as a big name in the RTS genre. I know some people love this game, and I'm not going to change their mind. On the other hand, my experience has been frustrating. In this review I try and articulate where I think this frustration is coming from.

Performance: 2/5
back in 2007 when this game released there always came a point where the game would turn into a laggy mess, and its still true in 2022. The 1000 unit cap in the game is a stupid made up number.  If you are playing a short small scale map then performance is manageable, otherwise performance decay will creep up until the game is unplayable. 

Single player experience: 1/5
Playing campaign mode felt like I was being kept in the dark. I would make incremental progress, and then suddenly a timer/other condition would trigger revealing a whole new section of the map and I would have to race towards a new objective. It felt poorly executed & more mentally exhausting than rewarding.

Resource management: 1.5/5
Resource management starts off being relatively straight forward, but as your economy scales, resource management tends to be more complex. Weird things start to happen, such as the resource bar oscillating between being full & empty. If/when you do get resource capped, it can last for forever. 

Pathing: 1.5/5
I frequently have to give units multiple commands to move from A to B. Sometimes its because the AI doesn't handle formations of multiple units. Sometimes units will go from A to a point that is sort of close to B (but not really). 

Bots: 2/5
Bots frequently do weird suicidal guerilla rush tactics with the commander unit. Bots are good at challenging players who like to fight off getting rushed (I don't), but tend to stagnate beyond a certain point. It feels like in long games the bots just breaks.

UX (user experience): I hate this game.
As far as I can tell, the thing that Sup Com: FA does differently to other games is scale. At a small scale, this game plays reasonably. On the other hand, I didn't get this game for micro scale RTS fun. I would argue that in 2022 there are much better games for that. In theory this game should make for some pretty epic battles, but it never really seems to go that way. It just feels abrupt and janky. Some things that have soured my experience:
* Getting 1 shot by a nuke because of a mistake made 20 minutes earlier (I.e anti nuke defence has an unfavourable lead time to get up and running).
* End game naval units are painfully slow. In big games, the games always seem to finish before ships ever arrive at their destination.
* Tech scaling: Many of my games have ended because an experimental tier unit will emerge out of the fog of war, and by the time I see it I can't  counter it with anything. It just makes everything feel pointless/redundant. 

Summary: 
Each individual feature/criteria of the game feels like it was either inadequate out of the box or has now been superseded by a newer game. The enormous scale of this game seems to be its primary selling point, but the poor execution of this is what makes the game so frustrating to play. After years of getting frustrated, I sincerely hate this game.

One of the greatest RTS games of all time, And trust me I've played alot.  This is a true gem of the past.  Its age also hits that real great gaming sweet spot for the Evolution of Rts Games.  After Starcraft 1, but right before starcraft 2 I believe. Meaning, unit pathing is alot better than the old school, you can create unit groups, select all hot keys ect.... All the QOL that didn't come around until later.  

Last Pro and Con are the same, This is one of the highest Ranked RTS games, not many even less good RTS games, that actually are RTS games being made anymore.  If you enjoy these style of games the replayablity will give you around 20 exstra hours. Just from needing to beat the map with each race. to unlock the last race.

Warfare on a scale that no game today can replicate.  Actual physics are the foundation of the game.  Planes bank, mechs move faster over broken terrain.  And the scale, did I mention that? you can have a couple hundred planes vying for air superiority while your ground army of 300 escorting a mammoth experimental robot attacks a base. 

And my hours are slightly incorrect.  I have been playing this game since 2007.

I would skip this one unless you're a HUGE SC fan. Newcomers to the series should look to SC or SC2 for a better entry point. 

The story is almost non-sensical. The pacing of the game wayy slower than previous entries. Its made intentionally slow. The game removes the research trees that increased the replayability of the game and changed how units behave. Now each building must be teched up individually or build with a teched up engineer, expending mass and energy resources instead of research points, a standalone resource. 

The resource system is changed to be more complicated. You now have resource storage and it fills up or expends based on income modifiers. This means you can stall your economy way easier than past SC titles if you go negative on an income. The game also does a bad job of really showing you in detail your resource expenditures, and its hard to understand why your economy is suddenly tanking. 

The pace of the campaign is so slow. instead of a multitude of quick and fun missions like in SC2, there's like 6 missions that take place on massive maps in phases. It takes a ton of trial and error, because you don't know what the next "phase" will bring. You have no intel or heads up about what the end game of a mission will be like, making it hard to create a strong production and economy without making risky decisions. Also there are no faction specific campaigns, you just get to play the 6 missions as each faction.  

Also, as a personal gripe, they removed the Cybran's "adapter" unit, one of my favorite units of all time!

After playing hundreds of games, after playing for hundreds of hours, I shamelessly admit that this is one of my favorite RTS games of all time.

(+) Macro over micro - Having a big economy and a bigger army is more important than micromanaging your units, etc. Personally, I'm better at rolling in cash and using that cash to make a big base and a bigger army than I am at trying to micro my units.

(+) Very dedicated community - The "Forged Alliance Forever" community has been keeping this game alive LONG after its official servers were shut down. Some people have even taken their free time to make additional content for the FAF community to enjoy - including mods, new maps, etc.

(-) "Noobs" are pretty picky with their maps, from what I see - Although this isn't a deal-breaking issue, most of the more casual or inexperienced players of the FAF community tend to play DualGap (a map I unironically enjoy) or Astro Crater (a map I do not enjoy at all). Fortunately, if you don't like that, you can host your own games and pick whatever map you want! :D

Took me a while to get into this game. It's complex and very different to most other RTS games. But it's been a blast to play casually with a couple of friends against the AI. I treat it more as a sandbox to play around with different units and strategies than a game to win - there are just sooo many possible strats!

The good:
- beautiful aesthetic/visuals that still hold up pretty well in 2022
- you can scroll all the way out and manage the game from space
- plenty of variety in units and strategies to keep you busy for a long time
- very satisfying to kill an enemy commander or drop a nuke on their base
- there's a free community tool called Forged Alliance Forever that provides unit balancing, more maps and easier multiplayer

The bad:
- games can be quite long and slow as it takes a while to build up your economy
- so much to do means you can feel overwhelmed a lot, especially when learning it
- if you miss one area, such as building air defence over your base, you can lose from one big air attack from an enemy
- tools are a bit lacking to streamline building, balance your economy or tech properly (eg if you run out of mass there's no way to get a breakdown of which units/buildings are consuming the most mass)

The ugly:
- unit stats are not available from the GUI, so it's guesswork as to which unit you should build sometimes
- UI can be a bit buggy, such as when queuing up multiple upgrades on a factory
- pathing can be really bad at times
- Forged Alliance Forever doesn't work for me, perhaps due to a router issue? luckily steam multiplayer still works fine

Do you like RTS games? Then you'll like this one.
There's only 2 resources: Mass and Energy, but that doesn't stop the game from from making you really have to think about your economy. 
Am I producing enough resources to upgrade my extractors? When can I upgrade to tier 2 units? What are the best ways to expand?
Once you have the economy set up, the combat begins and there is plenty. Every RTS game I've played, I've never really needed more than 100 units, with Supreme Commander, 100 is the bare minimum for an assault.
OF course if you're like me and don't always enjoy the basic back and forth of assaulting bases, you can simply turtle up with nuke defense silos and artillery.
The number one thing I have to say I love about the game is the size of the maps. Largest is 81 square kilometres, smallest is 5 square kilometres and even the small ones still feel pretty big. You have enough room to really build up and either swarm or turtle up.
Long story short, coming from a C&C fan, if you want a little variety when it comes to strategies and units, this is the game for you.

This is an old school classic RTS game with some really neat and interesting stuff in it that isn't in other games of the same genre.  Also, the experimental units and the artillery in this game are more customizable to your base.  In many ways the game is better than supreme commander 2 even if you include the SC2 DLC/experimental units.

Essentially, for point defense there are just more options available - making things more interesting. Plus, I really love the commander battle strat that was more viable back in the old days when you could launch a tactical nuke from your commander's shoulder, have multi-layer sheilding, etc..  So there's alot to enjoy with this game and the skirmish mode can be pretty dang challenging too.

IMO, the campaign was better than supreme commander 2 as well.
I sometimes go back to do the campaign just to play certain maps that I liked.
The resource system does takes a couple games to get a grasp on how it works.

But the game is a classic fav of mine that I keep installed for rainy days.
Just don't know anyone else that plays it.

BEST RTS EVER

Does this game deserve your money? I mean, for this price, for sure yes. After all these years, it still has an active community and Square Enix seem to have been wise enough to either foster it or at least let it be.
Does this game deserve your time? I also think yes, but that requires a more elaborate review.

Clearly a very ambitious game, the scale of the battles is monstruous in terms of how many units there can be. Maps in this game can be gigantic, with as high as 12 players on the same match. This means one can have a 6vs6 in this game, and with mods it is possible to have up to 16 players.
In this game, the map IS the territory. The developers make sure to show that to you from the beginning of any game, by demonstrating a zoom-in to an pretty level of detail, from a zoom-out that can go pretty much as far as one wants.

The game's community is still quite active and the interested player may want to have a walk around Forged Alliance Forever (FAF) website.

In summary: this is one of the best videogames of all time. At least try it out, if you have a chance.

That is not all. At the time of writing this review, I had already invested a generous amount of play time in Planetary Annihilation(2015), and Ashes of the Singularity(2016). I have also tried out Beyond All Reason(still in development).
OK, so Supreme Commander is showing its age. But again, there are things that have been done here, that don't seem likely to happen ever again: The support for multi-monitor, the impossible scale of battles, beyond what we've seen in a Total War game, the attention to detail, the factions... this is on another level. This is not something that an indie dev team can tackle. You would need for RTS to become the fashion again, and to allow a team with a crazy project like this to go on for years and years, before we see something that compares. Again, I have tried some of the newer alternatives, and I don't think we will. I'd hope to be wrong, though.

I've been playing this game on and off since I was a kid, first on the xbox (FA isn't on the xbox, just the original SupCom and SupCom 2) then when I got a computer I immediately bought it along with the other two and played all three of them for countless hours, Sadly some hours are lost from either being offline or from an account I had lost a long time ago (and on FAF which doesn't count your hours).

IMO the game is absolutely amazing, If you like RTS's at all it's definitely worth trying, Truthfully its still one of the only good RTS's even after being 15 years old, It's a game I come back to every now and then, I'm still waiting for a successor for this game, A game called "Sanctuary" is in development that is supposedly supposed to be the spiritual successor to this game, Truthfully I'm very excited to see its development, They have 3 factions like in the original SupCom, Each of the three remind me of one of the factions in SupCom, EDA for example reminds of of the UEF, the Chosen remind me of the Aeon/Illuminate, and the Guard remind me of the Cybran, I very much recommend checking them out, From what I've seen and heard about the game it will hopefully shape up into something amazing.

Also, If you want a more updated experience of SupCom FA I recommend looking into FAF (Forged Alliance Forever) they have done an amazing job at keeping the game up to date and adding things that improve the quality along with having easy and accessible ways for installing maps or mods not to mentions adding optimizations to help improve late game performance, 10/10 experience for SupCom Fa and FAF.

[h1] A Landmark of the RTS Genre and a Must Play [/h1]

Very fun! The gameplay is intuitive and satisfying, simulated ballistic projectiles results in some entertaining mishaps or wins. The AI is very challenging especially early on, requiring you to learn new strategies on the fly to keep up, in both the singleplayer and skirmish modes. On that note the singleplayer is actually very fun and its surprising how much voicework and lore there is in a game that maybe didn't require it, but surely benefits from it. I haven't played many of these games so the whole concept of an economy on the battlefield was a surprisingly welcome addition, and bought in a whole bunch of tactical mechanics you don't really see in other games. 

There are an absolute ton of unique units spread out over the four factions, each with their own specific purpose (so not 20 tanks that all basically do the same thing for the sake of variety), and each faction has their own strengths and weaknesses you can take advantage of. The models, despite the low texture res, are very detailed and look fantastic when you've made your own army and megabase. There's a lot of maps for the multiplayer/skirmish modes and they get crazy big, I think the map size indicator is a little misleading since most of the units in the game are gigantic compared to your regular person, when you see a map that says 80km x 80km it feels closer to maybe 20km in reality, but thats still massive. I didn't touch FAF solely because I didn't want to get stomped by someone much better than me, but I hear its a very pleasant and active community. 

TL:DR 9/10. In Summary this a fantastic strategy, RTS that is a required play for those who enjoy the genre. Whether its $15 or $3.50 like I bought it, PICK IT UP ASAP
This classic RTS will never let me down!  I love it.  Being on Steam really easy to setup a private or public game.
great game

Don't be fooled by my short playtime, as i play on FAF (Forged Alliance Forever) which is a multiplayer client mantained by fans, keeping the game supported with constant updates and balance patches, and even outright new content for this amazing game. The game itself holds up extremely well to the point that it's the only non-officially supported RTS game of its era to be actually growing in player numbers. So if you read this, come join us over at FAF! 

On to the game itself. Only real blemish is that as others have said it really only uses a single thread which means that huge battles can start to stutter a bit. The major point in the game's favor, besides its sheer scale, is the economic system. An RTS in which it's more satisfying to balance your economy outright doesn't exist, as you don't even have to wait to have all the resources to start building anything, it'll just build according to the resources you're generating per tick. When it comes to the scale there's also absolutely no equal: thousands of units on screen, huge robots and experimental tanks, planes and carriers, nukes, insane 500 meter tall artillery guns, there's no end to the CRAZY machinery and ammunition you can throw at one another, all manageable from the single unit, up close, to a view that goes up in space and lets you see the entire battlefield according to your intel.

The learning curve is steep, but instead of being frustrating it mostly means you get more hours out of it, as the more you play the more strategies and tactics you discover. 4 very unique factions add to the variety, with one more, well-balanced major mod faction that seems to be about to be made official. There's also ranked seasons and co-op campaigns. In short, it's more than 10 years old but considering the genre has basically done nothing but regress, it still represents the absolute highest peak rts has ever reached. Yes that includes AOEII.

[h1]Hands down one of the best if not the best RTS game of all time.[/h1]

[b]Here are some reasons why:[/b]

[list]
[*] [b]Massive and expansive battlefield:[/b] Maps can be as big as 81km is size with 8-12 people with both air, land, sea and even some space elements. 
[*] [b]Hard to master and play:[/b] For new people, there is a learning curve to say the least, but its really fun when you get the basics. But how I would describe this is the game is like a really advance version of chess. There are moves you are always having to make to lead to a decisive victory. That being, involving certain building of units with certain tier levels, economy balancing, recon, etc. Even after many PVP and PVE games, and the completion of the campaign, I am still learning how to play this game well. It takes a lot of strategy, tactics and concentration to play this game well. At least in PVP. 
[*] [b]Continued love almost 10 years later:[/b] The Forged Alliance Forever (FAF) mod lobby is a community of Supreme Commander fans that play together in PVP, PVE and Co-op Campaign to enjoy this game even after all this time. They have not only patched and improve the game in performance and balancing, but they have also added a mod and map vault, lobbies players can host and join with ease, co-op campaign, and more. Incredibly fun and is way better than using the Steam severs to play. Also, its free! I also recommend the LOUD Project Mod for this game. It improves the AI, balancing and game performance drastically - while adding mods & maps that are compatible with the overall mod. I use LOUD now exclusively when playing the game. 
[*] [b]Pretty good graphics & music for its time:[/b] The game has pretty good graphics in my opinion for its time. Its unique art-style outweighs any other RTS I can think of. It isn't cartoony as its more futuristic. It also has great particle effects, explosions, and overall a sense of scale with the units that come with the graphical detail for each one. The sound track for both this game and the first one are amazing. Some really original, adrenaline-inducing songs that can really get you going in the intensity of the battle. Also has some nice casual songs that build up a nice but relaxing atmosphere as you start the game and start building your base. It also seems like its dynamic as battles start happening, so in my opinion, the music isn't worth turning off unless you like to have absolute focus or you are wanting to talk to people over VOIP. Even then I recommend you just simply turn down its volume. 
[*] [b]It still holds up today:[/b] All the reasons I said before, combine into this reason on why this game is one of the best RTS games of all time. If not the best. It still has the longevity that Command and Conquer would dream of or other similar RTS games. It just continues to be awesome. 
[/list]

Overall, I am have glad to update this review to provide some more insight into this game, its a great RTS game for anyone to get into, though its hard to master if you are in any sense a hardcore RTS gamer. If you are casual, prepared to be punished by challenging gameplay, at least in PVP. Even then if you don't know a proper build-order, then the AI might kick your butt. Do buy this game and get the FAF lobby client. You don't want to miss-out on one of the most unique games of the last two decades.

I'm updating my review to something (hopefully) a little more helpful. 

I enjoy this game a lot. RTS games have been my favourite since I first started playing video games. There are many elements that make an RTS game excellent, this catches most, but not all of them. There are some problems which I'll address. 

Cool factor, there are very few RTS games which grip cool factor by the balls like this one does. The mixture of scale, sound design and unit behaviour gives this game a massive and epic feel. An interesting approach to tech sees you starting with small, swarm-like robots which progress into larger machines up until the truly massive, game ending 'experimentals', or tech 4 units. 

Base building, an important component to RTS games that has been tragically reduced as developers sought to capitalise on the success of MOBAs. This game does it very well. Like with units, your buildings progress through 3 tech levels, up until the fourth where you have specialised, faction specific super structures. Bases in this game get big and you're encouraged to spread it throughout the map to secure strategic regions and resources to tech up and increase production. 

Asymmetry/variety is a valid expectation and it can be found here. There are 4 factions and each have their strengths and weaknesses as well as specialised units. The variance is closer to something like Command and Conquer rather than Starcraft. There are staple units across the factions which, whilst different in stats, perform the same role, as well as some unique units which do not have equivalents. It's not ground breaking but it's still good. 

Whilst the strategic elements to the game are excellent, where it falls shorts is in the tactics. Due to the sluggish responsiveness of units and the lag which is common in multiplayer, fine micro is more difficult than it should be. Units often bump into one another, are slow to carry out orders and are generally clumsy. Were this game on a smaller scale, this would be a truly game breaking problem. But, given the large scale and focus on macro, rather than micro, it isn't too great an issue. 

Difficulty wise, this game has a comfortable difficulty curve and a good distribution of players across the skill levels. Its mechanics are intuitive but complex enough to allow for plenty of room for improvement. 

Thanks to the efforts of modders who put together the third party client 'Forged Alliance: Forever', the game lives on in a state far superior and better balanced than it ever was on release. An active MP community exists, coop campaign was added and many quality of life and stability improvements have been added over the years. 

If you like RTS games and are willing to install and make an account for Forged Alliance Forever, I absolutely recommend this game.

[h1]READ THIS BEFORE YOU BUY[/h1]
If you played Total Annihilation, this spiritual successor will sate your craving for an intense strategy game. The in-game multiplayer is its only downfall, as the servers and systems are too outdated to support steams current invite system. If you are going to play the game at all, please use the Downlord Forged Alliance Forever (FAF) Client, found online.


[h1]GAMEPLAY[/h1]
The game revolves around your two main resources Mass and Power, you must keep a balance and upgrade your mass extractors when appropriate. Supplying power to your factories and workforce will allow you to continue expanding and producing at a competitive rate. From perfecting your build order; to the mix of units you employ, the defence and attack strategy you decide upon shapes the game on a map by map basis. Each match is utterly unique with fighting armies over tonnes of community made maps (or even a map generator found on Downlords Client). Do you fight with numbers, or technological strength? These are choices that this game will cause you to choose.

[h1]GRAPHICS[/h1]
The game suffers from age, but at max settings, it is still beautiful enough to observe your forces cause carnage and explosive conflict. The bloom setting is a personal preference, but it causes some graphics like Shields and Outlines to be unnecessarily bright. Overall the graphics are capable but not world shattering. The explosion effects from your Units being destroyed or destroying other units are quite satisfying, and the blackened burned wreckage left behind in their wake are appropriately illustrated.

[h1]SOUND[/h1]
Jeremy Soule masterfully portrays his score in this title, as he did in the previous game, Total Annihilation. If you were like me, and came from Total Annihilation; knowing what Jeremy was capable of, you are not disappointed when you load in for the first time. I have never been sick of the music playing along against each strategic thought.
The Unit sounds are unique, and generally acceptable to identify what unit you have selected, the sound design is very good with unit to unit combat; firing sounds, explosions etc being a spectacle to behold. Nukes, Artillery shells and Commander explosions are satisfying and the visual effect in combination of a roar of explosive power, you're left in awe of the blackened landscape from the aftermath.

[h1]DIFFICULTY[/h1]
Assuming you're using the Downlord Client to play, the AI are many, and if you so choose, very difficult. you will be tested and shaped into a better player, the harder the AI you play against. There is a bit of a learning curve, but once you master the basics like your initial build, expansion and become familiar with the units of each race; you'll become more adept as you continue.

[h1]TL:DR[/h1]
A reasonably good looking, well paced RTS, with an extensive unit roster means hours of enjoyment. immersive audio and music, will make it very easy to sink alot of hours into this game.

If you would rather see a number to judge your purchase, il rate it as such:

9/10.

This game is fantastic.

The economy in this game is one of the best in the genre, one which SupCom2 fails to uphold. The continuous economy system is great in practice and intelligent in design. Instead of a staggered income like in Starcraft where your resources are tied to workers physically traveling back and forth with an infinite storage, you have resources being aquired per game tick and finte storage. This facilitates building as much as possible when possible.

What is especially unique about SupCom1 is that when spending resources (mass and energy, the only two resources other than time) you don't pay the entire cost the moment you click build. Like the income, your spending is also on a per tick system. This is not only intuitive, it bypasses a lot of the tedium of macroing in other rts games. Instead of being charged upfront for queing 10 units, paying the entire cost of each unit before a single unit rolls out, you que units as you please and get charged the build cost per tick (something like every 1 or 2 seconds, i dunno).

You may think this is inconsequential, but when combined with spare resources in storage, you can build expensive structures or units extremely quickly for as long as you have the resources for it. In that same thought, if you have insufficent storage, you can use your engineers (all purpose builders, repairers, recyclers) to reclaim mass from destroyed friendly and enemy units. After a large battle near your base, it's entirely possible to greatly increase your production per tick if you have engineers get the mass, allowing you to build some costly things for a short time.

The scale for this game is amazing. Unlike in other games where the camera is only ever at a fixed distance, requiring you to pan, click on the minimap, and use hotkeys to snap to places constantly, you can simply zoom out to see the entire map in SupCom. This gives you a better picture of your own army and buildings. Depending on your units' line of sight and sensors or dedicated radar/sonar structures, it's possible to locate every enemy unit and building on the map (barring some gameplay features).

There are several core ideas to fight the enemy SC in the game. All of which involve building a main army, probably consisting of many tier 1 units and a smattering of Tier 2 and Tier 3 units when possible. T1 units are the most cost-effective, after all.

One way to fight the enemy SC is to deny their mass income by destroying Mass Extractors as often as possible. Build a few units and send them out to deny as much mass as possible. This should slow down their production and development slightly. Of course, if they are also destorying your MEs as well, it gets more complicated.

Another idea is to use air transport units to attack structures that are important to the enemy. If your scouts see an undefended Shield Generator, for example, it might be worth dropping some T1 units into it to both deny the enemy SC protection and waste their resources and time by forcing them to rebuild it. It may also be a good idea to prevent large strategic buildings and Experimental units from being completed in the first place. No one wants a constant rain of artillery in their base or a giant death robot massacring their army.

The concepts in this game are inspiring and the execution of it is just so fun. It's clever and avoids some pitfalls or annoyances of other games of a similar genre. I suggest you at least try SC:FA.

Despite all of the balance issues this game has, namely, Aeon being a bit overpowered as well as Seraphim just slightly less overpowered than Aeon (the devs when this game was being supported constantly needed to keep nerfing Aeon units), this is arguably one of the best RTS games I have ever played, and I have been playing this game since it first came out over 10 years ago; I used to play it competitively reaching the top 500 at one point in both the original supreme commander and then again in the expansion forged alliance.  

What makes this RTS game different from the starcrafts and red alerts is the sheer size and scale of the battles and armys/navys/airforces you build.  This game is less of a rock/paper/scissors game of what units beat what as in starcraft and warcraft and more of a game about controlling territory.  The rock paper scissors element is still there as in a bomber will take out a tank, but you will also have anti-air, and your own airforce if you know what you are doing and properly balance out your units.  

If you play this game against friends you will have a blast and if you play competitively it ends up being a real time strategy game of chess where you are trying to kill the enemy commander, the first one to lose their commander loses the game, and since your commander is your most powerful unit in the early game, you will find yourself putting him on the front line constantly playing this balance between expansion and not over-extending as to lose your commander.  As you slowly tech up to more powerful units, your commander becomes less and less of front line unit and becomes more of a unit you need to protect.  In the end game, you have nukes, and experimental units which will end the game very quickly if your commander finds himself face to face with one.  

The concept of the game is simple, control the mass nodes, build mass extractors on them as well as build energy producing buildings, balance out your mass and energy to build units (air,land,sea).  Tech up to get more energy, and more mass, tech up your factories to produce more powerful weapons rinse and repeat until you are in the end game building monkey lords and nukes or until someones commander dies.  

For the price this game costs, I would recommend picking it up, at the very least you will have a lot of fun just playing the computer learning the game.
