Linus Tech tips  said this was his favorite game and I just got steam (usually play Division1&2). so I added this, wow its like playing an indie game that skipped all the steps. I expected improvements not an unfinished game. Its like the coders never played DUNE 2000 of CNC. NOTHING LIKE COMMAND AND CONQUER generals. I expected different but not unplayable different. 

The zoom in and out is the worst. using the arrow keys throws you all the way across the map. IN CNC you can just click to go where you want.  the first game set on normal took 5 hrs 20 minutes. takes forever to build units. All the while you get pumelled by air from the opposing side. That is at least 10x what you are. no clear upgrade path for tech, it just does it for no reason. I still won but only because the game gives you an unbeatable super cannon near the end and there is a waterway between your base and the bad guys. And the shield generators helped a lot too.

after winning the first round they give you a base to rescue. But you cant build on the other base, or use any of the buildings. So I put some level 3 builders onto light transports and sent about 15 of them to the new encampment and made my own camp.

So i build 20 tanks and 20 mobile artillery and they get taken out by 5 airplanes. Insanely rediculous. It was drudgery waiting for the long build times. Your boats get hit by 3 shots and they sink. But you have to hit their 10 times and they are still firing.  Super unbalanced.

then after saving one base another pops up and a ready made army comes with it. and super alien robots on top of that.

Again i beat it but the interface makes it overly burdensome to play the game and get around on the gameboard. AND this from someone who has played CNC for 12 hours straight with no stress. dont know what I paid for Supreme Conmmander but it was a loss.

And all that was the first game on normal. Couldn't I get one base to start with instead of one and 2 more that dont work. Maybe i missed some settings. 

and then the worst thing games do when you win, there were hundreds of straglers wandering around on the board. and the game session just ends. I hated that the worst. 

Cant i get some relax time building units and hunting down all the straglers? That would have been nice. A gentle game of golf at the end of saving your base. But no. You completed all but one secondary accomplishment (8 out of 9?) and THE END: Session over.

On CNC I play 7 other bases at one time, so its not like I appreciate a challenge. But come on, you have to be able to move around the map and be able to upgrade at least half as fast as your AI.

They did do one thing pretty cool I had not seen. You could click and drag, a missile tower across the map, and it would build as many as it took, to make them like a wall. That is something CNC did not have.

I just switched to a new gaming laptop, I need to find my NO CD upgrade of CNC generals. Of course I own it I own all my games. Only evil people steal. But DRM is stealing my clock speed. Thats a real crime. DRM is the best way to get me to say no to a game (if I can avoid it). My computer My SSD/hard drive. Dont rape my drive.

I can't imagine any timeline where I do not recommend this game to anyone looking to play a new RTS game. Forged Alliance is a standalone expansion to the first game which adds a new campaign, new maps in multiplayer mode, new units for the existing factions as well as a completely brand new 4th faction named the Seraphim. 

I cannot say much regarding the lore and campaign of the game as it seems relatively generic and bare. It seems like more of an extended tutorial in order to get used to the mechanics and gameplay to be able to start Multiplayer. 

The variety of units between the 4 different factions makes each match feel relatively fresh as each faction may have different strengths and weaknesses, meaning no faction is objectively overpowered versus the others. I personally enjoy the Cybran faction due to their high damage and cheap experimental units, which are end game units capable of ending games or turning the tide of a game. 

I highly suggest that you download the Forged Alliance Forever client as that is where the majority of the community resides. It's an active match browser and mod installer which allows you to make your own maps as well as download existing ones and play ranked games online. You can also download mods to mess around with such as ones that add entirely new units, new factions or new building types for example. It also contains single player and co-op missions that can be completed as something to do outside of online matchmaking.

I recommended this back when I had it on retail disc, and I still recommend it now.  A decade later and still stands as one of the best RTS games available; gameplay wise it has aged like a fine wine.

+Large scale real time strategy that you‚Äôll find it hard to get anywhere else
+Visually and audibly ‚Äúepic‚Äù, incredibly satisfying just to watch stuff go boom.
+One of the better RTS campaign‚Äôs I have played through(-awful voice acting, and isn‚Äôt played for laughs like C&C is)
+The Forged Alliance Forever(FAF) community client has picked up on development, making quite a few positive balance/meta changes.  The base game is fine too!
+Both the base game and FAF community have a ‚Äúlarge enough‚Äù player base to get matches going during active hours.  Better get used to losing though.
+[i]It cheap[/i], goes on sale for under $4 sometimes!

-Whewlad, the toxicity online... I think RTS games are just cursed to be some of the most salty communities, with how in team games, one lower skilled player can ruin the game for everyone else‚Ä¶
-This came out back in the Windows Vista era, and its poor performance shows.  Expect slow downs during large air battles, or even 2v2+ team games.
-Supcom also tried to expand on its roots from TA, which it did!  But there are newer titles that do an even greater job expanding the UI.  Micro management in particular feels clunky compared to newer titles, such as Planetary Annihlation and games built on the Spring Engine.
-The FAF rebalance doesn‚Äôt do a very good job of explaining to vets what it changed generally.  Can be quite a whiplash in certain scenarios for returning players, unless you read [i]all the change notes[/i].

The absolute best RTS ever created. It has almost everything you could want/need from an RTS

-Large/small scale battles
-Land, air, sea
-A complex and deep resource/economy system
-Build templates
-Great mod support with tons of unit, mission, UI, and rehaul mods to play around with
-Support for well over 10 player matches
-Active competitive and casual multiplayer scene
-A great campaign with an awesome soundtrack
-4 different factions and a variety of units
-Nukes
-Actual projectile physics (Bullets aren't just homing projectiles)
-Loads of great maps
-A camera system to die for
-Hard to learn, near impossible to master
-Lots of viable strategies
-Probably a lot of stuff I am missing here

Overall, no other RTS even comes close to this game IMO. That includes TA. Warcraft, AOE, C&C. and many others. With that being said there are a few negatives which should be addressed

-Desync issues in MP
-Can be laggy
-Quite a few crashes and issues with tabbing out
-All of the active players are on a mod-loader (FAF which is a must for MP)
-Can be hard to get into if you are new to strategy games
-Pathfinding is a little off

This game is severely underrated for how good it is, the graphics might be a bit dated compared to today's newer stuff but rest assured this game is super fun. So many people already explain why this 2007 game is still today in 2021 completely awesome and unmatched by the likes of other RTS.  I think some of that has to do with when I first played the game in 2007-2009 --> my PC at the time could barely run it.  Somewhat due to GPU but mostly due to CPU (dual core, not quad & lower IPC).  I mean barely because matches get up to 500 units / team of 8 = 4,000 -- it was the first RTS with real formations, complex patrol routes & battle landscape strategy, yet not completely high level like Total War series.  

This game made Starcraft 2 look like a tinker toy, and yet is only now getting resurgent adoption because hardware is finally able to handle everything (my fav fact: 1-core CPU is dedicated to projectiles -- every bullet / blast is an independent object that can be intercepted / dodged).  I am excited to keep playing today and have an eye on Sanctuary --> which is looking like a legit successor from an Indie dev (Square/Enix bought GPG in 2008, made SC2 in 2010 -- now defunct and has no plans to make another one)

Play this one on Steam or Forged Alliance Forever (FAF) until Sanctuary is out (2022 Q1?).  It is completely worth the money.

I've spent more money on a cup of Starbucks (overpriced and horrible coffee) than the current price of this game (1,99‚Ç¨ for the DLC and 2.99‚Ç¨ for the game + DLC). This is one of the last, great RTS games to be released in terms of scope, complexity and tactical flexibility. 

You have everything from small, chaff robots that you can churn out in a few seconds to gigantic, skyscraper sized monstrosities that lay waste to everything before them. You have a wide array of defensive structures from basic defence turrets to artillery structures that can literally reach across the map and flatten enemy structures and units. 

Everything is simulated from your unit's movements to the projectiles they fire. One of my favourite moments from this game was watching a T3 artillery structure munition striking a Cza and it's structure falling onto down onto an enemy T3 power generator and crippling the player's resource pool. Absolutely fantastic!

Supreme Commander Forged Alliance is the only expansion of the series. And unlike other companies deliverance, this is the only DLC that is needed. 

 Despite being a standalone expansion (if you care not for the continued story) it arguably represents the pinnacle of the entire series. Building on the many positive similarities with vanilla SupCom which made it so memorable in its debut. Like its predecessor it aptly continues to justify "Supremacy","Command" and "Epic Proportions". Funnily enough much from my vanilla thoughts can be applied to FA and so there isn't too much to say if you enjoyed the game play of the former, FA is bound to be a favourite. It pretty much runs on the same basis, with a more refined approach to its the already fan loved formula. The game sets in the same universe after events of vanilla. 

Fa continuous the series goal at redefining the genre of "real time strategy". Having the capabilities of generating large scale battles across complex maps. To the simple yet fluid battles that take into account minuscule details from the players input. The ever changing  game state between early-mid-late game transitions; Never is there an idle and if so expect the worst. From the dreaded nuclear launch, the new surprise T4 experimentals, innovative strategies or just a total economic stall. All of it returns.

Iconic features found in SupCom return like the strategic zoom. In addition to many other QoL mechanics. Streamlining of the GUI is a welcomed change as well as the other optimisation tweaks. The expansion does justice to what DLCs fail to do nowadays. Adding non-compulsory lengthy content to an already complete game. A new faction (Seraphim) joins the 3 old ones. Again each with their unique play styles. Familiar units return bundled with more interesting and diverse role units. Larger pool of experimental that are more devastating and worthy as game-ender status. Giving players extra units and structures that add more complexity. Moreover an entire campaign to follow-up the teased ending of SupCom's narrative. Noting many favourite characters return.  

SupCom FA is effectively a polished version of SupCom. Retaining the authentic epic scale and weight of proportions of battling forces. But just more of it. If you loved SupCom, without a doubt, SupCom FA is a natural progression and there just isn't much more to say than that. A critically praised and well received RTS like its predecessor and should not disappoint hardcore fans of the franchise or even genre itself.  In its entirety it chases the same goal of supremacy.

Heading into the series later years most people nowadays play on the Forged Alliance forever client (requires copy of game). A cosy community keeping this ancient treasure alive and updated. A testimony to how tenacious SupCom fans are adorning a RTS franchise that gave more than a retail product price. A true recommendation for fans of the RTS genre. Be wary of the somewhat steep learning curve and required dedicated time needed to play and maybe having to learn. But a worthy price to pay for what great potential can be mined from the series.

Has got to be one of the best RTS games out there. Its super realistic graphics make it incredible game play. I wont go in to much detail about the game but its basically a continuation from the first Supreme Commander and this version introduces a whole new alien race faction known as the Seraphim. 

If you don't own the original Supreme Commander I recommend getting that too. Both games are by the same creators/developers of Total Annihilation from 1997. That too is a really fun game as well. After CaveDog entertainment dissolved, the devs created Supreme Commander & made a new company known as Gas Powered Games putting the previous head developer and owner Chris Taylor as CEO . In fact Supreme Commander has been announced as Total Annihilation's "Spiritual Successor."

2021 Review

What is and has been the best large scale RTS ever is still just as playable in 2021, even multiplayer matchmaking. And that is thanks to its fans. The beautiful people that recognize the brilliance of this game and show it the love it deserves. Notably, the folks over at Forged Alliance Forever. But also the people behind the LOUD Project and a bunch of others.

The Pros:
    
    - Huge maps giving you the ability to try out tactics and strategies on a large scale
    - Nice Cinematics and Story
    - Tutorial
    - Decent Single Player Campaign (Co-Op w/ FFA)
    - Decent Voice Acting
    - Four Different Factions with Unique, Well Balanced Units
    - F****ING EXPERIMENTALS (A butt ton of fun)
    - Land, Air, and Sea Combat on a huge scale
    - Robot corpses all over the battlefield


TheCons:
    
    - Graphics are a bit dated.
    - May never get a true sequel (SC2 was simplified for some reason)

Seriously, this game is a classic and FFA, the LOUD project, and others are proof of that. Do yourself a favor and give it a try. I suggest start with the campaign, then make some custom matches against the AI. When you want more of a challenge, go with FFA and play against more advanced AIs or try matchmaking. FFA is where the competitive scene is for this game and it is still active.

Just like I have done for the original Supreme Commander, this one is also one I got as a sale and something I have not played for a while. Spoiler alert if you have not played the first one, otherwise continue on.

The game and its difficulty is MUCH easier than the game before. You will have help from someone for each mission, with only 1 of them being left on your own for majority of the mission (this might be the only really challenging one). There is no separate story for each faction but instead the same missions with different dialogue and upgrades, depending on your choice of UEF, Cybran, or Aeon. 

Much of the logistics remains the same, with major differences of gunship AA nerfed to the ground (you will no longer be able to shoot down other air units including Experimentals or other gunships with ease like with the UEF T3 Heavy Gunship "Broadsword", and nuclear missile launchers and defenses no longer build quickly in the construction phase and also missile building phase. It takes FOREVER... Luckily, heavy artillery installations and Experimental building is a lot easier and quicker to do. Air staging facilities will function automatically (when you set most air units to patrol your base, upon depleting all gas they will automatically refuel and take off if there is an air staging facility nearby, also the more the merrier). Certain units get a look change, some major and some minor. There is more, but those are the one's that have been most helpful. 

More units have been added to the game and they add a substantial change in game-play. Beware of a new faction emerging?! (It is hinted in the name and cover art, "Forged Alliance") You cannot play as this new faction during missions by default; however, you can capture enemy engineers as you possibly can and build up an army that way. Fight fire with fire. The Seraphims are a stronger Aeon with many similarities to other factions as well as having their own strong suits. For example, they receive a T3 Heavy Tank that is very strong against other land forces in large groups and are capable of firing torpedoes when submerged and are the ONLY faction to feature a T3 Submarine Hunter and T3 Battleship that can launch nukes. Give it a go to capturing them and unleashing their own toys against them. 

This is the "last" installment by THQ for Supreme Commander. Supreme Commander 2 is the last and final game, though it is not made by the same creators and has a different layout. Getting it is your entire choice. It does continue off and supposedly brings the fight to a final end, where Aeon, Cybran, and UEF finally coexist in (mostly) peace.

I watched a cast online about a year ago then watched a couple dozen more from June -> December 2020. I first dipped my toes in around December after much anxiety, and now, 4 months on, I'm still a complete noob. It's rewardingly difficult. The pathfinding can be a bit irritating, it's difficult to balance games and you're going to be destroyed in your first 100 games. Despite these drawbacks + a few more, it is quite simply the greatest strategy game ever, in the same way Brant Bjork is the coolest musician to have ever lived or like that amazing food at that small restaurant, hidden away that the locals know about, yet the mainstream never speaks about. It's your big brother's favourite game.

+ Grown up community.

+ Unit variety. 
+ Assassination mode on acid.
+ Nukes/experimental T4 units and artillery.
+ The soundtrack. 

- Good CPU required.
- Pathfinding.
- Difficult to balance in your first 100-200 games.

Arguably the finest RTS of all time. Despite this game hailing from the heady by gone days of 2007 when the genre was still thriving, it still remains exceptionally playable. Having outlived not only the genres hay day but also Gas Powered Games and THQ, its one of the very few real long standing RTS success stories. In order to get the most out of it you need to play on the community driven client "Forged Alliance Forever"; Download available at:  https://www.faforever.com/

What makes this game so great? Well many things really but if you had to summarize, one word, scale. Everything from the numbers of units and their utilisation and weaponry to the maps themselves. Virtually all RTS confine you to a bordered combat areas but the maps themselves feel large in Supcom. Even its occasionally awkward pathfinding mechanics add to the sense of scale in this game. 

The economy follows on in the same vain as Chris Taylors earlier RTS title, Total Annihilation, where by players mine mass from specific areas of the map and generate energy from power generators that they build.  On the face f it, it doesn't sound that unique but the economy balancing is a very different mechanism to those employed in other titles and adds an extra depth of play in an area that other games have historically overlooked. 

Let me be clear, the game has a steep learning curve and there are some technical issues (such as the lack of multithread utilisation) that you would expect to find in an older game. But there is no question in my mind that only really special games to play and even watch, manage to amass such a loyal following that still pulls in thousands of players to this day.

Behold the greatest RTS of all time, the best thinking man's game I've EVER played. SC Forged Alliance is just such an intricate game, each faction is so different and genuine, it's hard to hate such a well thought out masterpiece. After almost 14 years now of this game being released it STILL looks great for an RTS game and it STILL has a living and thriving community filled with all sorts of skill levels! I'm so happy I've been able to finally play online in this game and compete with people from all over!! Expect 30+ mins matches at times due to how long and ridiculously huge some armies are going to get, lot's of different strategies to implore in this sleeper! If you're looking for an all out futuristic war simulator then look no further. 

All in all, if you're into RTS and you like GRAND SCALE BATTLES then SC Forged Alliance, raging at your screen because your units wont move after you issue an order or the shitty path-finding for any and all units in this game forces you to lose then is the game for you. 10/10 EASILY!!!

This game is as criminally underrated as it is legendary. It's one of the few that actually live up to the "strategy" part of "real-time strategy", with potentially thousands of units moving simultaneously on maps dozens of square kilometers large. Nothing before or after has ever reached epicness on this scale, and even today, over a decade after its release, it's still holding its head high as one of the last true oldschool RTS games made before the genre unfortunately faded into obscurity. 

No micro-intensive unit abilities like in [i]Starcraft II[/i] or [i]Warcraft III[/i], no stupid unblockable abilities like in [i]C&C Red Alert III[/i] - nothing but spectacular clashes between gigantic armies, gigantic superweapons, and gigantic awesomeness all around. If you're sick of your "armies" barely amounting to 30-something units before the arbitrary unit limit cockblocks you, this is the game for you (SupCom: FA also has a unit limit, but it usually sits at 1000-2000 units, all with the same weight of 1, so you can go really nuts before you even notice it exists). Choose your faction, assemble your armies from a diverse variety of units, conquer the land, the skies and the seas, and bury all who oppose you under an unending avalanche of steel!

I bought this game 2016 in a sale because I remembered the times probably around 2010 when I played it at my dads pc. A couple months later a friend told me there is a mod called FAF that keeps the multiplayer alive. Downloaded the faf client and slowly started playing some games. It was nice but I wasn't really hooked. In Summer 2019 I joined a small clan and started playing a bit more competitively. Thats when the proper fun started. Now after over one year and probably 2000 games the game starts to make sense to me. I am able to recognize good gameplay and see beauty in it. Kind of similar like a mathematician sees beauty in a proof. 
Getting to the point where you feel like you are in control of the game (not the oponent) takes a lot of training. I don't feel like I am there yet. Maybe noone is there yet. But that is in my opinion where the game shines. The skill ceiling is incredibly high not because of a lot of mini tasks you have to perform but because the game is so complex and most maps are so large/ complex. 
The good news for begginers is that it is already great fun to play non competitively. The graphics have aged incredibly well and everything feels very well refined. All the guns have the right amount of weight to them. You can easily see that it was a true AAA RTS game when it was developed. And now finally the cpus have caught up to the incredibly high demand of the simthread hammering one core. You should definetly have a cpu that is post Haswell (intel 4th gen). 

But a review of this game isn't complete without talking about the reason it is still played: Forged Alliance Forever. It took over the multiplayer after GPGs own multiplayer service shut down and now continues to shape the game with balance updates, minor graphical improvement and recently a reworked net code that improved the multiplayer experience a lot.
The community is mostly friendly. Ofc there are some black sheep everywhere. For a beginner I would recommend to play the campaign missions first. It is decent and after that you should know most units. Diving into multiplayer can be a bit rough. You might get kicked from lobbies because of you little games, aka having a rating that shows gray. And unfortunately most of the toxic player are in the low rated Astrocraters and Dualgap maps, which are basically the only maps hosted by lower rated people. Don't worry it isn't even close to 2013 LOL levels of toxicity. Just not actively welcoming. I suggest to start hosting your own lobbies as soon as possible.
If you need technical help or tips to improve your gameplay you can ask in the FAF forum and on the FAF discord server. The techsupport usually is very good because it is top level tech support. Gameplay tips wise it can be kind of a mixed bag. There is a chance your question will start a heated discussion amoung the veterans who will argue about nuances and not really answer your question. But if you are determined to get better you usually will find someone who will train you personally. 

The active faf community is small enough that you will recognize most players in your lobby after a while. So to me it starts to feel more and more like a small village.
Fantastic game, all time favourite. If you buy it, you need to join the FAF community.

The game allows for a massive number of units to be out on the battlefield acting in realtime, with seemingly no limit to the stockpile of resources one can acquire.  Things that require mass to be built will consume mass when being built, and things that use energy to build or operate will expend energy in turn.

Upsides, loads of units and variety to fighting with multiple factions, adding on a fourth with this game being a pseudo sequel to the base game.  Everything pretty much runs well at all times, even with the ability to manipulate the game speed to 10x the normal, and vice versa.

On the downside, it doesn't have the highest quality in graphics, it takes a long time to build anything without speeding the ingame speed function, and it feels as though there's a slight tilt when it comes to requiring you to turtle as a guaranteed method for surviving matches.

In my humble opinion, the most epic & demanding real-time strategy game of all time. The 'real' community (with a few hundreds of players) have build their own online-gaming platform, called 'Forged Alliance Forever', in short 'FAF'. Although almost 13 years old, this RTS classic includes Single-player and multiplayer modes. The single player campaign consists of eighteen mission (6 for each faction), where each mission could last for hours.
it's fun

Supreme Commander Forged Alliance brings with it a wealth of greatly appreciated improvements across the board, including a reduced, cleaner UI, making it easier for players to actually see both the map and their in-game menus. New units added to the three previous factions that enhance their tool set, but perhaps the most significant addition to the game in terms of units is the additional 4th faction, the Seraphim. 

In the previous game, you could play as one of three human factions, the Cybran Nation, the Aeon Illuminate and the United Earth Federation (UEF for short). Here, you can now play as the Seraphim, a truly alien faction in every sense of the word. However, they are only playable in multiplayer and skirmish modes. They take up the main antagonist role of the campaign, with a number of other characters from each of the three human factions serving as lesser antagonists. Honestly though, the story isn't really worth getting into because it doesn't have much impact despite the heightened stakes compared to the first game. Supreme Commander as a franchise has never been particularly impressive from a story-telling perspective, but the missions are fine enough to help you get adjusted to the new UI improvements, as well as the new units. 

A word of advice to anyone interested in buying this game; get both of them, the first game and this one. I say this because, while Forged Alliance is considered a stand-alone game in it's own right, it's still an expansion to the first game. If you're interested in the story (like myself admittedly), then definitely get the first game. More importantly, the first game has a good tutorial that teaches you the basics of the control scheme, something shared between both games. Not to mention, the campaigns in the first game does a slow-burn kind of pacing, where you unlock new units as the campaigns progress. 

Forged Alliance unfortunately drops you right into the action with access to mostly everything at once, and the only new units to unlock are the ones added in this game. It's not a bad thing, but it can be jarring considering the fact that the mission maps in the Forged Alliance campaign become enormous as the match drags on. You'll generally start out in a small area where you'll have to build up a base, destroy the first batch of enemies nearby and have a functioning economy to support yourself before continuing onward. You can complete your objectives as quickly or as slowly as you want, the game doesn't penalize you for time elapsed aside from reminding every so often of your current objective. There are timed objectives yes, but mercifully not many of them. The real problem is just trying to get your armies across the battlefield quickly due to how huge the maps become. 

Another thing, if you noticed how I said the first game has more campaigns, then that's true. Each campaign focuses on a different faction, with you (the player) fighting in the closing days of the galaxy spanning war consuming all three groups. The three campaigns are distinct from one another, but there is some overlap here and there. In Forged Alliance, it's one campaign, but you can choose to play as one of the three human factions in each one, basically replaying each mission with a different set of tools at your disposal. 

Moving on from the campaign, the game play is solid and rather intricate once you've had time to adjust to it. I won't cover everything here, otherwise I would've made a guide rather than a review, but here's the gist of it: In most matches (barring some campaign missions), you start with nothing as you're teleported to the battlefield in your all-purpose Armored Command Unit (ACU). The ACU is the lifeblood of your army and arguably the most important weapon in your arsenal, able to build bases and engage enemy armies. The ACU is strong on its own, but as the game drags on, more advanced forces are fielded and it becomes increasingly dangerous for the ACU to fight enemy forces. You can upgrade the ACU to make it more effective in battle or more effective at building bases and supporting your economy. Eventually however, you can build expendable sub-commanders who are somewhat more effective in combat than an un-upgraded ACU, but a better alternative all-around for a front line general if there's no other option. 

When building bases, you have to keep note of several major factors: factories, production and defense. Nearly all buildings come in three tech levels and all buildings can be built by your ACU, your sub-commanders, but more commonly by your engineers. Each engineer and every unit is split between these three tech levels and only engineers of a specific tech level can build something from that level. Higher tech engineers can build lower tech stuff as well. 

Most maps in the game let you build all three types of units, but not all of them have water (or in some cases, not enough water), so you'll have to make due where you can. On all maps however, you'll have to scramble to acquire mass nodes, because without mass, you won't be able to build anything efficiently. You can build energy production facilities anywhere on the map and without energy, you won't be able to power defensive structures like shields, radar and stealth generators, or produce bases as efficiently. 

Unlike other RTS games out there, you don't send out builders or dedicated collector units to obtain funds to purchase things with. Instead, you work toward building enough economy structures so that your mass and energy output isn't exceeded by your spending. You can build anything, but you're managing your build speed instead of your battlefield finances. In other words, as long as the bars at the top right of your screen are full, or at least, not empty, then you're good to go with construction.

Lastly, you have to bear defense in mind. It's entirely possible to never have to build defensive structure throughout the course of a game, but this usually isn't a good idea from my experience and from seeing other people try this. None of your defenses, barring shields and the like, use energy, so you can build as many as you need. But bear something else in mind; the placement of your defenses is as important as the kind of defenses you build. This game has some really awesome physics and projectile tracking, which leads to a lot of fun to be had. None of the weapons in the game are hit scan, so units fighting one another won't instantly hit when they fire their weapons at each other. If a hill is in the way, then unless the unit in question can fire over it, those shots will be wasted. Missiles also work this way and I've seen quite a number of what would have been sure-fire hits fail because they hit the very tip of a mountain or exploded prematurely against the upraised terrain. 

Speaking of AI, the worst thing that could be said about it is path-finding. Good lord, the path-finding in both games is horrendous, especially when you want your army to move around a corner. Many can say they hate Supreme Commander 2 all they want, but if you ever try to deny the fact that game fixed the path-finding issues a thousand fold, then I literally don't know what to say about you. Right, this is supposed to be a positive review. 

Ultimately, this is a game about grand scale strategy, managing a truly unique battlefield economic system, all while building up armies of robots, tanks, air planes and battleships to destroy your enemies with. Buy this game because it's a solid experience on its own, then download the Forged Alliance Forever third party client to do online play and get access to a great selection of mods. Buy the previous game to get a complete experience and consider buying the sequel because it does have some merits that outweigh its problems. 

Thank you and have a pleasant day.

Supreme Commander stands alone as the definitive RTS experience. Start with just one unit able to build basic things and tech up to massive armies. Choose where to focus your resources to overcome the enemy in classic rock-paper-scissor balance. Have your tactical and strategic planning be rewarded as the enemy is annihilated while you barely take a scratch. Or despair as a strategic misstep leaves your units vulnerable and they are slaughtered wholesale. I have only played campaign so far, but I have only good things to say about it. And there is a multiplayer community still alive and well, testament to the longevity and sheer quality of the aptly named Supreme Commander game.

Do you like RTS games? Congratulations! You found the best one ever made! Every aspect of Supreme Commander is scalable: the map size, the AI difficulty, the length of missions, etc. The campaign is also one of a kind in that the map expands and objectives change during gameplay so that you get to work with an existing base for multiple phases of a mission. 11/10, 1,000,000,000/10, and so on.
https://youtu.be/1G8uYRZQT5Y

I always get caught up in the resource management of the game because it is so well done and expansive... and there are only two resources! The combat includes ground, air, and naval units along with experimental units. Most of the mundane aspects of epic RTS games can be automated by setting infinite production loops of whatever units you want, by setting patrol waypoints, or by constructing energy shield or engineering stations. 

This is the best RTS ever made and you should give it a shot.

This is my all time favorite game. theres a lot to say

Units
Loads of different units. All of them are awesome, cool, fun to use and look awesome. There's always an abundance of choices and plenty of different way to play. Even naval combat is fun. taking battleships and blowing up naval bases (and even parts of the enemies land) is always fun. 

Variety
Plenty of it. This game has everything from the first Supreme Commander game and added more to it. Incluiding a new faction. Each one may have similarities but theres a lot of different distinctions. The Aeon for example has slow firing units, but they have the most range and they deal heavy damage. Cybran has much faster, lazer shooting enemies and uses stealth units to execute surprise attacks. UEF has explosives and machine gun combos. Seraphim has a combination of all of those (sorta). BTW the new units added are very good and do make game changes.

New Players
If you played the 1st Supreme Commander game, you can go into this pretty easily, but for new players? not so much. Not only does this games story continue on from the 1st game, but when you start, you have all the units from the first game and new units for each level. Theres a tutorial, but it only covers UEF and the very basics. Though, it did improve a lot in unit descrptions so at least new players know what it does.

UI
Very clean easy to understand. Unit capabilities are defined well, each option for the units is easy to use and understand (unless your completely new), each attacking unit now has a defined attack range instead activating all at once or none at all, theres not an overabundance options but there is plenty to use. Its well made.

Addiction
This is one of those games where you can lose track of time because of how immersive it is. I can spend hours in one play session because seeing the progression, the firepower, the scale of it all, is breathtaking. I always want to keep playing because i am doing so much and watching so many things that it holds my attention.

Grind
There really isnt any grinding unless you count resource management. Each factory, builder is restricted by their tier so you only have to upgrade factories to get higher tiers. The factory will also decrease time for lower tiers after an upgrade. You cant stack engineers on factories for even faster unit production, and you can stack engineers when building as well to create buildings faster. Of course, if you cant manage the resources either it will slow to a crawl or just take the same amount of time as a regular build (thats if you stop stacking and your resources arent still being drained)

Multiplayer
This game's mulrtiplayer is no longer existant since GPGnet is dead, BUT there is a mod called Forged Alliance Forever which has brought back the multiplayer and it is very much alive.

Campaign
It is fun to play (the story isnt engaging, but the gameplay is), depending on which faction you paly, you can obtain different side missions, some dont make any real changes, others can give you an advantage in battle. The friendly ai is very weak and barely helpful. When you first start out, they are ok but later on, they dont make any real changes. Thankfully there is a mod that increased unit cap, makes friendly ai way more useful and adds new friendly ai that doesnt exist in the base game. here's a link if youre interested: https://www.moddb.com/mods/forged-alliance-enhanced-campaign-ai

Supreme Commander Forged Alliance has got to be my favorite RTS game of all time. I grew up playing and loving classic RTS games, my favorite of which was always Total Annihilation. I remember fiddling with the Spring Engine back when that was a thing, a community project that was largely used to create an open-source true 3D successor to the original Total Annihilation. Then, I discovered a new RTS game that was on the horizon, called Supreme Commander. The familiar layout of starting out with a lone commander unit, now called the ACU looked uncannily familiar and immediately rekindled my nostalgia for TA. I later found out that it was made by the same creator, and that it was truly the spiritual successor & evolution of my beloved childhood favorite. It featured the same core game mechanics of a lone, powerful start unit whose survival is key to your yours as the player, but was built up to an absolutely massive scale and mechanically fine tuned & polished.

Then, when I thought it couldn't get any better, the stand alone DLC Forged Alliance released. I truly love the era of standalone RTS DLCs that take one of your favorite games and make it even better, adding new content and polishing the existing game. This is one of the finest examples of such releases, as Forged alliance added a fourth faction to the game with its own complete list of units while also expanding existing faction unit rosters, and also added new maps. In addition to this, it also introduced balancing measures that made match-ups between units more sensible, and made progression through the tech tree in the game more smooth and fluid. And to polish all of that off, the in-game UI was revamped and slimmed down.

The interface in this game is still what I consider par for any base building & battle RTS, and is still at the top of my list in terms of controls & interface, balance between micro and macro focused strategic gameplay, and time and size scale. The way units behave in game (especially how they move and shoot at the same time, yes I'm looking at you StarCraft), and the way this game forces players to focus on effective macromanagement & strategy while giving them a buttery smooth and intuitive control interface that takes a lot of the pain out of micromanagement to do so is, in my opinion, simply unmatched by any other RTS game. 

The game is just a boat-ton of fun with friends in multiplayer, or alone in skirmish against AI, the options for which feature a healthy variety of difficulty levels and play styles. The map variety offers fast-paced, in your face brawling action or massive scale multi-hour slugging matches with other players or AI, which coupled with adjustable game speed offers any speed or time frame of gameplay desired. It also features a decent single player campaign that is a great way to learn the game mechanics & controls as well as a bit of strategy. 100% recommend, worth picking up at full price, ABSOLUTELY worth picking up when on sale.

I would rank Supreme Commander: Forged Alliance as one of the all-time best Real Time Strategy ( RTS ) games i have ever played, it truly does stand up to Age of Empires and Starcraft in terms of the classic and enjoyable aspects of the game. Not only does this game feature a real time aspect, but expands upon the true idea of strategy, often forcing players to be adaptive in their approach to taking down several computers. 

The resources are basic to understand much like Starcraft in that there are only two, Mass and Energy, both which are required to build structures, units and to maintain buildings as well, adding a unique economy system to challenge the player every time. 

With three distinct factions and an added faction, this game beats Starcraft 2 hands down, simply for the fact they added a new faction with the expansion of the base game.  I've featured some description of their features but not all.
- The Aeon look like humans but are very defensive ( good shields ) with some awesome mega weapons ( Mega robot thing and flying saucer )
 - The Cybran are cyborgs that sound like Soviets lol with a deadly arsenal of offensive units, ( particularly ships that walk on land )
- The Ceraphim are crazy inter-dimensional beings with a very healthy balance of offensive and defensive units, they also have some of the strongest battleships in the game and strategic missiles that are tough to destroy.
- The UAE are the humans, like Terran from Starcraft they are balanced in all areas and feature the classic destructive specials like a rolling fortress and artillery canon. 

The maps can be huge if you want them to be, i mean pick the right one and you could have a two hour slugging match with the AI, your trusty bestfriend struggling by your side, well on another island that is lol A great array of land and naval maps for sure. 

Always remember you are nuclear, don't blow up and buy this game!

Supreme Commander; Forged Alliance is an RTS which follows on from Supreme Commander and has its roots in Total Annihilation.  Resources are virtually unlimited, and experimental units rule the battlefield.  The campaign allows you to choose one of three factions, with individual units and structures.  The main challenge in campaign mode is that, on each map, there are objectives which, when accomplished, enlarge the map with a new base and often a huge incoming wave of enemies.  So it helps to play through once, and you can preposition units to stem the tide (it becomes trivial if you position experimentals at choke points, and enough anti-air and shields to protect your main base).

I think this is the first in the series to have the modern RTS control conventions.  The AI is weak in campaign mode, it doesn't often rebuild even when you give it the opportunity, never expands, and attacks with small groups that are easy to defend.  If you like to build your base and turtle up, it will give you the time to do that.  The only challenge is the abrupt map expansion, and sometimes overwhelming air units.

There is simply no "RTS" that makes you feel like you are actually commanding an army and waging an all out war like SupCom.  Every other RTS feels like small skirmishes by comparison even to this very day, and it isn't because of just the scale of this spiritual successor to Total Annihilation.

You truly have so many options to try to win in this game--so many ways to scout, to harass or distract your enemy.  You can fight wars of attrition, or overwhelm your opponent's defenses with sheer numbers or by an experimental mega-weapon.  Base defenses and artillery have ranges that are meaningful.  The latter can be screenfuls in distance-- they feel like artillery and not just some guns that have trouble lobbing a shell a few feet out.  Strategic artillery can even lob shells directly from your base to your enemies' bases across the map.  And if all else fails, you can launch strategic air strikes to knock out your enemy's nuclear defenses and then nuke them.

But this is not a twitch RTS where success is measured by clicks per second.  You have many ways to win, but resources are limited and you must choose a balance between how much you build/expand, how many units you produce, and when to push for more territory.  You need to study your enemy, to send scouts to see what they are up to and be prepared to counter it.  This is a thinking, strategic RTS where the big picture matters, not individual units.  You are not trying to micro manage units like a MOBA.

For me, SupCom towers beyond every other RTS that has ever been made--including the popular ones like Warcraft, Starcraft, Command and Conquer, etc.  And that is not to say that those others are bad games, I enjoyed playing them-- but SupCom allows for that open-ended creativity that the other games do not have.  Yet... this game is not perfect.

First, this game can severely tax your computer.  If it is not powerful enough, the game can drag to a crawl.

Second, there are only two resources in this game, metal and energy.  And unlike other games where the emphasis is on the amount that you have, in SupCom you have effectively unlimited metal and unlimited energy-- its their production rate that matters.  The rates you produce these resources become limits to the rate you can build and expand.  Which is good, but the bad thing is that maps become pretty bland after a while.  No amount of trees or other elements of a map matter as where are those metal spots happen to be.  Metal locations, water, and terrain height matter--but nothing else really does.

Third, games can really last for hours.  Which can be a positive or negative depending on your tastes.

This is the best RTS game EVER MADE with gameplay that still is fantastic 13 years later. 
Story: Well despite my love for this game the story is very simplistic but I don't think it was ever really the focus of the game and it serves as basicly a device to introduce the new race. 
Gameplay: Its amazing with great control. It is very hard to learn but once you do you will learn to love it. All of the races have their own unique quirks and abilities that suit many play styles. There are so many ways to build and expand with lots of options. 
Maps: Honestly haven't played them all but so far as I can tell there great with lots of ways to play and expand.
Graphics: There not as good as a lot of other RTS's but for 2007 i'd say there good. There is a ton and I mean a TON of cliping and that's it, i'd say there fine nothing to go crazy over but fine.
Overall this game gets a 9.8/10 the only detractor is the graphics and story but that's it, one of the best games ever made.

I've started playing strategy games when they came on the market - Dune II, the C& C series, Warcraft II. Starcraft. But I largely stopped playing new games early 2000's: C&C Generals: Zero Hour and Warcraft III: The Frozen Throne were my last new games, and I kept playing them right up until I got a steam account in 2020.

You see, I'm a Linux user. And very busy. So games are both a bit harder to run than for most, and I'm not THAT interested. I play usually two to three times a month for an afternoon or so. Never online: always against AI! But in 2020, I built a new computer with a juicy new AMD RyZen. And due to a nice bonus from work, I decided to throw in a mid range video card (RX 5500). I would've added my old GeForce 6600 otherwise, enough to play Warcraft II and Generals... But now I had something to that could do more. And I wanted to give it a go.

I was actually looking for Total Annihilation. Wanted to play that again - had good memories. But the Steam store recommended SupCom which was just 1.99 due to a promotion. Hard to say no, so I decided to give it a go.

Love. At. First. Sight.

What a game. Perfect! played the campaign, in the wrong order (started with Aeon) and when done, Forged Alliance was next.

The story is perhaps not amazing, but the way it is integrated in the campaign, the size of the levels - it is all awesome. The game pulls you in, giving you new challenges. A Turtle like myself who loves to be as efficient as possible can minimize game speed & tune everything. Lovely.

If you like the original SubCom, FA is simply more of the same. There is 0 downside, seriously. There are a few more units, a slightly improved UI, but that's it. The campaign is better. More challenging, especially after the first few operations the AI starts to harass you more so you are forced to balance base building with defense. Lovely! Build those shields, quick!

[h2]Basics[/h2] 

Now there are a hundred reviews and fan pages on SupCom, so I'll leave it to them to describe how the game goes, but the very basics are as follows.

You're dropped in a big robot on a small map. You have to order the robot to build some buildings, including resource generation and unit production. There are two resources: energy, which goes up and down quickly, and mass, which is much slower to generate and use. Unites come in three basic varieties: land, air and water.

Once you have some units, you need to go over to the base of the [b]other[/b] commander and kill it/them.

That's it in a nutshell. There are many complications, from different types of units, building upgrades, super units, stationary weapons like cannons and nukes, but that's all additional fun.

What makes the game unique in the genre is it's user interface. Or, one element of it. In other games like the Starcraft, Warcraft and C&C franchises, you have a combination of 'local view' where you're managing a small number of units, and a 'map' or 'radar' where you see the world. You can zoom in a bit on the action, but only a little in or out. Not in Supcom. The scroll wheel zooms you out until you see the entire battlefield, and back in until you see a single unit. Need overview? Zoom out. Need details? Zoom in! It's SUPER intuitive, and honestly so superior I'm surprised the others haven't copied this. Well, not like anyone really still makes strategy games anyhow... it's 2020, when did the last good strategy game come out? Maybe Starcraft II - I didn't play it, but even that game is years old by now. Everybody plays MMO's these days, first-person shooter or top-down RPG style with fast action and no base or resource management. Eliminated that overhead! I get it.

Back to SupCom. Is it that bad if you are used to Overwatch?

The game has a tutorial and a campaign to guide you through the base building and management process, but if you don't have much patience, this won't be your game. Resources and efficient base management, handling multiple unites etc - you are busy with, well, strategic choices. Fast action is important if you play online, against the computer (as I prefer) you have to be efficient, deliberate and can take (some) time to decide by slowing things down.

If you're into all that, though, dozens of fun hours are guaranteed. Enjoy!

I bought the Supreme Commander Gold Edition, which includes Supreme Commander 1 and Supreme Commander: Forge Alliance, after watching some gameplay commentary it looked amazing and i was excited to play it but the game WILL NOT LAUNCH. 

I have followed perhaps 6 guides to fix this issue all of which failed to work. Upon launching from steam it goes to a black screen and will then minimize to taskbar, after trying to maximize it i only get a black screen again and it minimizes yet again.

I have tried running in various compatability modes, ran it as administrator, installed on a different drive, verified integrity of game cache, uninstalled and reinstalled twice and ive come to the conclusion the game isn't worth this trouble, the FAF team must not be active enough anymore. 

For a game that came out in 2011 it was perhaps foolish of me to think it could work on my brand new latest tech, high end machine, i have requested the refund.

had the honor of playing this RTS when i was a snot infested 10 year old kid. Back then, it was the gateway drug that pushed me into the genre. I pandered around through Starcraft II, Age of Empires, Red Alert 3, Company of Heroes, you name it. I always had this pressing notion that since Sup Com was my first RTS, and that it was so good, that there just HAD to be more like it out there in boat loads.

Through time I started to realize that there has never been an RTS created of this caliber... Ever. The funny thing is that, though this game is undoubtedly the best in the genre, the only reason why it doesn't have a super saturated E-Sports market or anything of the sort is probably just due to the fact that it's massive and "slower paced". But it's not, it's better executed than SC2 for making you feel like you have an actual army to use instead of force-channeling your ADHD to kite marines. Also, stalemates don't exist. If nukes don't work, use artillery, if that doesn't work (it will work), spam experimental units, or all three, blow up the entire map. Someone will always lose.

The follow-up to that is that it's not clicks-per-second. You set build orders for your engineers/command unit and predict what the enemy will do. If every other RTS is checkers, this is Chess. And for that reason, it's the only RTS that scratches it for me even a decade later.

Still one of the best RTS games out there. The scale is grand, and I love the tech system (units range from tech 1-3, and then experimental units, where experimental units are large enough to crush smaller units). This game is slightly outdated at this point, and there are several performance hiccups, but there are many communities still supporting this game, such as Forged Alliance Forever. The LOUD mod is supposed to improve the sub-par AI performance issues that cause late-game slowdowns/crashes, even on rigs that should be able to easily handle this game. In addition, there are many mods out there that make this game extremely fun to play, adding units and upgrades, UI overhauls, etc. 
The game is only a few bucks now, definitely worth it. I've spent hundreds of hours playing this game over the years, unfortunately steam does not record the progress when using Forged Alliance Forever.
Takes a few hours to come to grips with the mechanics even if you're an avid RTS player, but each subsequent battle becomes an emotional ride you become super invested in. It's a must-have.

Back when I was a kid I used to love playing RTS games like Command & Conquer and Halo Wars. One day my dad brought home a new game for the Xbox 360, and it was easily one of the best games I have ever played in my life. This game was addicting to play as a child, and even now as an adult, I still find myself coming back to experience more and more of the deep and enriching experience this game provides. Easily the best RTS ever made, and one of the best games ever made.

Using the lovely Community-driven lobby (faforever), this game is surprisingly more attractive than any other modern-era RTS since a lot of those are in fact real time Tactics games, relying heavily on APMs and micro managment. 
All hail the noble Large Scale Strategy!

I have a lot more hours as I Beta tested this game and the first and I even made a map.  I thought it deserves a review as there still isn't a strategy game like this. 

NOTE*- Play the first game if you want the Single Player experience, it's worth it.

Pro's

The extended zoom immediately gives you an extra layer of strategic control it's really fun to handle so many units in different places.
Unit roster is intense, each side has a varied as well as a specialised list of units.
Experimental units are really fun, some of them have serious strategic value.
An underwater Aircraft Carrier!
Naval battles in this game are the best I've seen, they can last hours, the same goes for land and air of course.
Nukes, Anti-Nukes and Super Nukes!
Enjoyable Campaign.
Replayability against AI.
A reminder that RTS is not just about point, click and shortcut keys.
An all round quality RTS.

Cons

The campaign for this one is not as big as the first game.

Scope

So out of all the RTS out there this is my favourite, I've been playing RTS since DUNE 2 (the original) and there is nothing like this one. The way it steps away from 'Tactical RTS' to 'Strategic RTS' is worth a look for any RTS fans out there.  It has many hours to give with the campaign alone, fighting AI is also very fun if you setup a custom match to your own taste. You can still play online but need to download FAF (check guides) and this is a lot of fun as people do still play. 

If you need to burn some time for fun and like RTS then honestly check it out.

Once more, if you like campaigns in RTS then try the first game as it's a good story arch and fun to follow.

So as a huge old school RTS and 4x fan.  C&C,Dune, Starcraft ect I finally decided to buy all the Supreme Commanders since they are at a very nice price.  That being said I was expecting the same RTS experience I have had with other games.  But, to my surprise.  Playing Supreme Commander is like playing a RTS on steroids.  I am just a little into SCFA and man.. so many units so many upgrades..  WOW!!  Looks like ill be just on this one title for a long time.  By far the best RTS I have seen!  Now I know why so many people play it!  Great game!  Highly recommend for those RTS fans!

 Called the best RTS ever made for a reason, from small quick battles all the way to huge hours long maps.  Easy command interface.  All units and projectiles exist in the world, a cannon shell can hit a tree instead of you.  Tons of replay value, and an online community still exists in 2020.

  A few things that set it apart for me:

1:  The factions do not have identical units and base structures that can be built, versus ones where the "look" is different but the units are just clones for "balance".  Yet they are close enough that one side is not OP.   The game has an appropriate level of balance among factions.

2:  No limits on Super Weapons.  That's right, if you want 300 Strategic Nuke launchers you can.  You like that Submersible Aircraft Carrier and wan't a few to swarm the base with 800 fighter/bombers, you can.  You need to figure out a way to survive that long but there are no unit-type restrictions, just an overall unit cap.

3:  You are a Commander and can assign tasks to your units and let them go, instead of micro-managing the assault and staging.   You can tell two factories to make 300 medium and heavy ground units and tell those units to stage at an island across the map.  If you support the factory, with one click, with air transports they will automatically fill to capacity and fly all ground units to the island.  You don't have to load each unit, assign flight paths etc.

4:  The diverse unit availability means different speeds.  With one click you can assign any unit type to coordinate an attack time and strike simultaneously instead of personally managing each unit to get it where you want when you want.

5:  Strategy is completely up to you.  Snipe with artillery, Swarm, Naval Bombardment, Flank and Rush, come up with anything and give it a try.


  The game really lets you play different strategies, that can win, instead of a single attack method that works best for X-Faction, or Y-faction.  It's cheap these days and you can lose thousands of hours playing a quality RTS so why not drop some coin on it.

Best Real Time [b]Strategy[/b] game ever made, period. (Emphasis on strategy, [b]not on tactics[/b]) 

I have thousands of hours played on this game on Xfire (when it was a thing) and on GPGnet (before servers were shutdown) This is the only game, that I've played on tournament level and the only RTS that I've ever made real money off on tournaments. I've played it... a lot.

Match length greatly varies according to map sizes. 5x5/10x10 took 30 minutes to couple hours. 20x20+ could be something like couple hours to 4+ hours. I've even played a 8+ hour FFA game on Betrayal Islands, which is the longest match I've ever played in my life. Good luck trying to have a toilet break or anything of the like, in a game like that.

This game is all about long-term planning and adjusting to your opponents movements and plans. There is no short term "I'm going to build a unit to counter this" Or "I'm going to press this ability to counter this" You have to have (in most cases) a correct army/navy/fleet composition to counter the things they are meant to counter and it takes time, a "long" time to build them. Those unit groups are your "tools" and "abilities" and then comes your own tactics, build orders and how you group up your units. which greatly varied from person to person. By the time you see something unexpected that can end you, it WILL end you, usually...

There are just so, SO many layers of difficulty and strategy in this game, that raises it above all the rest. Every faction is truly unique, aesthetics, weapons, strengths and weaknesses, culture and ideology and most of all, [b]units and structures[/b]. These do NOT look, feel and play the same as the other factions. 

UEF has the only T3 Point Defense in the game and almost all the tools other factions have. Cybran has the best Experimental in the game (or well most cost effective), it's tier 3 Air units have homing missiles and they are also stealth (other factions have projectiles that can miss) Aeon has the most cost effective (and unique) way of defending from tactical missiles and most of their units hover. Every faction is truly special in this game, in so many ways, that I can't possibly put them all here.

UEF is the most versatile of all factions. Their units can handle almost anything other factions throw at them and hit them back, just as hard and they are best defensive faction in the game by far, slowest units in the game. Cybrans is all about low hp, high mobility, stealth and high damage, rapid firing units (except Brick, which is an exception to their whole unit roster and discipline for some strange reason) Aeon has units, which are very specialized at their roles. They have slow, heavy hp/shield units which take damage but have short range weapon, which is also a heavy hitting, slow firing weapon but they also have fast, long range, accurate, slow firing, high accuracy units that have low hp but high damage. They cannot go toe to toe with most of their units on their own, but they have some units that can take damage and deal with close range enemies as well while other units excel in long range. In short, with other factions you can use most of your offensive units to do a push, but with Aeon, you have few of those units that can do that, but a lot of units that shouldn't do that, because it's not cost effective. 

[b]Theeeeeen[/b], we have the Seraphim, the "Worst" faction in the game. Most expensive units, "Best" units, most of them are multi role, not very cost effective at their roles but they do their jobs very well. Second best (or best, depending on player) experimental unit in the game and then best game ending experimentals in the game. Only faction with T3 sub hunter, which is also ship hunter, which also has the best naval AA weapon in the game embedded on it, making it a nightmare to counter in high numbers. T3 Battleship can launch nukes, "cheapest" game ending experimental bomber, which is near impossible to prevent, without having at least one player dedicating their entire economy on it, Experimental Nuke WILL end the game in couple seconds or couple of minutes, depending on the amount of nuke defenses and is the most versatile at both attacking and defending, while other game ending experimentals will take about 10 times more time to do that, giving other player chance at destroying it. Absolute nightmare in team matches if people are coordinating and playing to their strengths while covering up seraphims weaknesses.

I could write an essay about this game and how good it is and what a fricking shame it is, that we have nothing like it at the moment and there probably are no plans whatsoever to ever make something like this again because, it is a game that is truly unique from others. This game truly is [b]LARGE[/b] in scale, compared to others. It truly meets the definition of a real time [b]strategy[/b] game. It is not a perfect game by any means (nothing ever is), but it is the one that I truly loved and played, that still has a special place in my heart.

Goddamnit Chris Taylor, get a new funder or publisher or whatever and make a new game like this and please STAY FAITHFUL to the original and make it even better than the one before. I don't know, or care, how you will accomplish it, but there's at least one hardcore, faithful fan still awaiting that "one" game to come out. A truly worthy sequel to the Supreme Commander...

Oh and don't even mention Supreme Commander 2. Supreme Commander 2 is a joke, don't you dare mention that SupComLite to me. It still burns my very soul to see, that it has the very words "Supreme Commander" in it. May god strike down the publisher, that forced them to make it that way! Cutting down on features and deviating from the original formula, so it could be played on consoles! Damn them all to oblivion! [b]DAMN THEM ALL!!![/b]

Alright so this game kinda came outa no where for me, i just recently got a PC so my only experience of this series came from SupCom 2 and ive loved that game for years now, once i got my PC i though well let me get SupCom 2 cause ive heard it has better A.I customization (no nukes, or artillery that sort of thing) This led to me finding out this game was on sale for a super low price of about $2 so i thought hey might as well. and boy am i glad i did, i was not expecting SupCom 1 to be SOOOOO much better than the second one. the scale, the units, the progression, the buildings! all just fabulous. i loaded in my first game and was blown away at how big the map was, (i didnt pay attention to the size when i picked and played my first match on a 81X81 map lol) So basically in conclusion, this game is great! i wish they made more SupCom like games or even another sequel and i love the fact that this game is still alive and played regularly and would gladly have payed normal price for it if id known how great it is! 10/10 game would buy multiple times lol.

FAF is full of morons, noobs, casuals, and cringey sweaty boys. BUT, it is hella fun. Even just to watch. 
Sup Com FA is one of those games that you boot up first time and BANG, the AI just blasts you into the dirt and demands you to learn. You do, and you start some giant brawls. Very rewarding. FAF is a MUST for multiplayer, coop is available there, along with MP matches that are still being balanced and tweaked. Ranking is there too, so people will see your rank and complain that you are too "good" or you are so "bad" or that they lost their blanket and they don't have the spine to play a PVP game... but all told, there are a lot of good players there and some of them even have decent personalities. If you like RTS in a futuristic setting, don't hesitate to pick this one up. Download FAF and roll coop with friends in campaign or custom fights against AI until you are ready to learn what a build is, and how to play your position.

This is one of the most complex RTS games ever. Unlike SC2 you dont have to rely on APM and freak out about a attack, a complex choice to drive economy into air can seal a win instantly when you strike, but if you invest to much your front might fail. A superior unit enters the battle, crushes a front, now you must built static defence or invest into a counter unit! super complex thinking and the macro standpoint of this game allows for amazing gameplay. 15 min of teching up or building a device can win the game or fail. The economy is super complex, balancing "minerals" and energy, you have to use energy to get your minerals and and more energy to spend them. It's very rare in the games industry to find an absolute gem of a game like this one.  On a high end PC it's still gorgeous and runs smoother then a laxative yogurt gelato, even when epic battles involving up to thousands of units are in full swing.  The sheer amount of unit variety, structures, and the four unique factions makes even a modern RTS like SC2 look amateur by comparison. The icing on the cake is for it's price you get a full game that's free of the micro transactions that plague newer games and with full mod support for user created content. I can't say enough good things about this game, easily one of the greats if not greatest RTS's on the market today.  If you've ever enjoyed any RTS game, you owe it to yourself to give this one a go.

Easily the best RTS ever made. The scale and scope of the battles is immense, but also the smaller scale 1v1 battles are fantastic as well.

As you become more experienced you will realise the massive depth of control available to you through the UI and hotkeys.
The game has a hugely customizable UI allowing you to see dual screens, mini map, weapon ranges, radar coverage to name just a few.

The games economy is a finely balanced work of art, simple and fun to balance production against income of two resources, mass and energy. Multiplayer is where the game shines, 1v1 being the epitome of the experience. Download forged alliance forever for the unltimate multiplayer experience, including chat rooms, ladder, custom matches, tutorials and more. There are always hundreds of people online and plenty of games available to play

It is purely volunteer led so please donate if you can. It is worth it.

This is my ALL TIME GOLDEN STANDARD of what an RTS should be. Huge verity of units and play styles, XS sized maps too XXL. Four different playable Factions, and resources that don't freaking run out (looking at you Starcraft and Warcraft) I grew up playing this with my Dad, and I love those childhood memories. We were both the type of player that would turtle up, and build a super defense line with deadly artillery laying waste to our enemies. 

I will say, and I don't know why this is, but the game does tend to get lower frame rates at about the 15 to 30 minute mark of the game. It kind of sucks, and I have no idea why it is doing that, when this game came out in 2008, but it never takes from the overall sweet, sweet gameplay.

To me its an old classic that was way ahead of its time. Like starcraft, but good (shots fired). The scaling and skill ceiling is immense. Great game for both hardcore and casual players. I love slacking off after work, building a town, watching your nuclear missiles go over the horizen, put your sunglasses on and prepare for a white light to cover your screen. Thinking you won, you see several silhouettes of giant alien death robots marching stright trought the inferno. It seems you forgot to turn off the steroids for your AI opponents. They cheat, and sometimes ALOT. Shit dosent seems so "slack" anymore. Half the planet is coverd in craters, robotic skeletons and nuclear waste. Desperately you focus on your shields while under constant bombardment, power outages keeps you from supporting and holding the frontlines. You can no longer afford to rebuild, holding off in a last stand. Your scanners detect nuclear missiles as frequent as the last few seconds of a popcorn bag in the microwave. The sky is coverd with chemtrails, and you realize, you never even bothered with a missile defence system. 

"Those cheating bas..." - Craimer. A true story.

Fun game to play and great campaign. Each mission is long and drawn out and requires considerable planning and strategy. Skirmishes are fun and can be challenging when fought against 2 or 3 computers. Only complaint is that the game engine is slow when you get 2,000+ units on the field.

This is a superb RTS, which has a unique feature: all resource extraction and spending is in rates. To build a building that costs 500 mass and 2000 energy, a builder may be able to channel 10 mass and 40 energy into the building. If the building is destroyed, you only loose the resources that had already been channeled into it.

Unit command is via an intuitive interface, and allows you to issue quite complex command sequences. There's an AI that will handle micromanaging unit formation for you - if you choose to use formations. This is actually recommended, since if you mix mobile shield generators into a land army you'll want them evenly distributed. You can still issue commands to move and attack, or do a move+attack.

There are 3 types of mobile units: land, air, and sea. You can set up factories for each and give them build queues to ensure you never run out of units at the front lines. There are also several types of building that can be used both offensively and defensively. These include cruise missile launchers and defenses, point defense turrets, AA turrets, shield generators, both short- and long-range artillery, and nukes and nuke defenses.

There are 4 unique factions in the game, each with their own strengths and weaknesses. There are some buildings and units that all 4 factions have, but they may operate in different ways. The UEF point defense turret is a frequent firing projectile that does low damage; the Cybran turret is a LOS lazer; and the Aeon turret is slow-firing/high-damage. The Cybran are the only ones with a mobile stealth field generator, etc.

The most spectacular combat takes place via truly unique "experimental" units, 3 or 4 to each faction. These are either powerful mobile units with unique abilities, or buildings that grant impressive abilities. Building them takes a lot of resources, but by the mid game you can be taking in enough to make it worthwhile.

Overall, the combat is very balanced and has lots of room for individual playstyles and clever strategies. I like this a lot better than Starcraft.

Best RTS I have ever played. It is a shame it was overshadowed by some of these larger marketed games at the time. I love this RTS so much, I bought the main game and forged alliance twice (CD hard copy and when steam had it, I got it then too). Besides, there is a fully LIVE PVP/PVE community called Forged Alliance Forever for FREE! No cost AT ALL! they work by donations (please donate, keep this community alive). I digress, 4 factions, very well balanced (something RTS struggle with at times), but unique enough to feel like you are not playing the same armies. One of the coolest things about this game is the user interface is easy and can be customized. The UI and command orders are easy to manipulate and give. Lastly, the combat is just..... aaaahhhh there is nothing quite like it. Very cool combat. This RTS is worth every penny. But be warned! there is a huge learning curve for this RTS, some research might help you out to improve game. Read guides. Or have an experienced friend show you the ropes. Regardless, still a fun and critical thinking filled game.

Resource Management is the key to a successful deployment and troop building strategy. Mass and Energy must be produced in tandem if one is to succeed. 
If any two resources of Mass or Energy is reduced to Zero while building an army of many units, your economy will stall and must be built back up by stopping all Building of units before proceeding further. All unit building will be drastically slowed by a stalled economy. 
A very good simulator for Resource Management.

Other Real Time Strategy (RTS) games require you to keep track of multiple actions and various decision making processes.  Where the game of chess has its playing board with its numerous possibilities...this game has (literally) scores of millions of possibilities happening on a large world map with dozens of other players interacting with each other to achieve strategic dominance and superior thinking skill.  It is the epitome of RTS because it challenges your wit and matches it against others.  Victories are quite rewarding.

For my tastes, this is still the best RTS game out there after all these years. I like working my way through epic campaigns. Companies rarely include campaigns these days. When they do, those campaigns always look like they were thrown in as an afterthought. Their idea of a campaign mission is a 15 minute romp through a town, killing what gets in your way. No long-term strategy. Minimal tactical challenge. This game is different. You can lose yourself for an entire afternoon playing one mission, especially if you are trying some unusual new approach. I wish all RTS games were more like this one and less like a console twitch game. There really are no EPIC campaigns in RTS games anymore. It's even difficult to find a decent RTS these days.   I highly recommend this game.
