even today its one of the best RTS games ever made. It has a massive focus on macro and has features that still aren't replicated much today. 

infinite building queues

modifiable order lists(move building plans before construction, and patrols while they are being used)

you can have units go from the factory right to patrolling or doing some basic task like assisting

Factories can be set to "assist" other factories thus working on the same building queue(grabs the next 
required unit and working on it)

1000 unit cap per person (base, more with mods)

buildings get adjacency bonuses

4 mostly unique factions (different aesthetic specialties and some insane perks like crab leg battleships(destroyers actually)

plus a fan run server/client called FAF is still going with 1800+ people and 150+ games at time of writing

This game is a masterpiece, one of the best and brightest forms of RTS that will never lose its potential. Constantly amongst multiple different accounts have I played this game, since a small child growing up being ruthlessly squashed and demolished by my father, as we spent hundreds of hours on old shitty laptops not knowing anything about them but the game itself, Supreme Commander: Forged Alliance. I returned to give it a final oorah, the amount of love I hold for this game outgrows any other, the feeling I get from it gives me never-ending joy mixed with sadness knowing that I will play this game for the last time, only remembering and cherishing those feelings of neglectful bliss relaxing in my sweaty chair in the classic Australian summer. 

This game reminds me of those amazing days I will never be able to have again. 

For those who didn't grow up on this gem, no need to be rude but you missed out pal. 

Redeem yourself, give it a go and enjoy it, you may not love it as much as I do and I understand as games themselves and genres advance, 

But this game walked so other RTS' and alike could run.

Its only been 8 years, take me back.

I'll see you again, I promise.

The Best Game I've ever played

The last Supernova of the Silver Age of RTS.

Let me tell you what i saw and feel.

This game is made 12 years ago and yet its graphic is good enough to compete with the best RTS games today.

The strategic value it has to offer differentiated True RTS from RTT (which includes many big names Starcraft, Warcraft, Warhammer 40k...)

And just as a true RTS game would be, it is complex. Random events though rarely occur (0.001%) can sometimes change the course of a match. For example, a Transport ship can collide with a flying Tactical Missile and if your Command unit is on-board, it's checkmate. Or the expensive nuke warhead accidentally hit 1 Air Superior Fighter (this is very rare because the speed of both the missile and the Fighter are fast, not to mention they fly at different altitude and the Nuke only ever drop its height when it is right above the target). Everything on the board come to play thanks to its realistic physics laws.

Each factions though has similar units type, they can either perform slightly better, has additional mechanic or has different statistics combination (Shot 2 high damage rockets vs shot 4 low damage rockets vs shot 3 medium damage rockets). Understanding these fundamental elements can help you shape a better strategy or tactics against your opponent.

GPG closed down in 2017 but the game itself outlived its studios. Even today it has a dedicated fanbase, a dedicated development team, a dedicated server for players to play around the globe, a dedicated mod community that creating more content as we speak.

Why is this good game not as successful as other series?

Number 1: this is for hardcore RTS fans. Thus, the general RTS community either find this too hard or not their cup-of-tea.
Number 2: and there are many definition for success. One of the most successful RTS game which is Starcraft 2 has these characteristics. A short game match (30-45 mins, rarely go over 1 hour) and much easier learning curve. SupCom game can goes into 2-hours mark in average and 4-hours games are not that rare which is ill-suited for Tournament e-sport program. Its learning curve is also quite high. You need to commit to learn if you ever want to go above Average Joe. Even with 1000 hours of gaming but without commitment to learn you will just be any amateur out there (including me).

If this game is not your type, you can move on but i will recommend this game because its quality is at least candidate-for-GOTY and there are not enough good recent RTS out there to recommend them instead.

There hasn't been any game quite like this one recently. The closest to this gigantic RTS is probably Sin of a Solar Empire which is space based.

For an RTS this game can be very slow. You're looking at an hour or more per fight on very large maps. Range attacks are super long. You can stay in one base and bombard the other guy with your own cannons once you get them up. The size of this game units is huge. The smallest units are about the size of a coconut tree while the larger units would be the size of mountains. Weaker units are very weak compare to some of the super experimental units you can field but you can have enough of the smaller units to overpower even the largest units.
Simply put: The most addicting RTS I have ever played.  Great variety of units and factions, and still an active community 12 YEARS after the game has released.

Supreme Commander offers a much more macro-intensive experience than, for example, the Age of Empires games. Battles routinely involve hundreds of units in air, land, and sea, and commanders have to manage dozens of factories in order to maintain supremacy. If you are a micro fiend, you will have a bad time as the giant clunky robots and tanks tend to take a little while to respond to your commands. But on the other hand, you get to command vast armies of giant robots.

Forged Alliance adds a welcome fourth faction, upgrades the UI, and refreshes the pre-existing factions by adding new units and updating old ones. If you enjoy the base game, it's a must-have.

Pros:

+ Unit chain-pathing from a source building to create patrols.  Good players might not use this as much, but crappy players like me will no doubt LOVE the visual affect of watching the patrols running.

+ 3 levels of technology for all units in a logarithmic expense.  I.e. it will take forever to get to the next tech if you try to jump too early, so the time building up creates a layering of the playing field.

+ The single-player campaign is nice.  If you are interested in this, get the package that has FA and the original game to get the whole campaign.

+ The campaign is the only place you'll hear voice acting.  All the sounds in a skirmish are just robotic machine noises and they are all nice to listen to.  The play field becomes this noisy droning clattering thing.

+ This was the first game to have the feature "zoom in wherever my mouse is pointing".

+ Templates are cool!


Cons:

- The UI seems old(ish) compared to recent games.  So don't make comparisons!

An unrivaled masterpiece of large scale RTS gaming.

Came out at a time when I didn't have a gaming PC, and I followed it for years before picking it up this spring. What an effing pick-up for $4 on steam sale!

The streaming economy is easy to understand and hard to master, with a massively high skill ceiling. The unit and faction variety hasn't been matched in any RTS since. 4 Distinct races, each with 4 tiers of units to combine into massive armies of death robots.

And the scale is just breathtaking - regularly managing engagements of up to hundreds of units spread across 20 x 20 or even 40 x 40 Kms of real estate (there are even some 80 x 80 km maps, but at that point it is getting ridiculous). The variety of strategies and tactics that you can pull off is endless... 

Upgrade your commanders weapons and armor and then teleport him into your enemy's bases to snipe their commander? Build game-ending super weapons launching nuclear missiles or nuke-tipped artillery entirely across the map? Build giant death robots, submersible super-carriers or land-dreadnaughts? Or just spam an overwhelming army, navy or airforce to overcome your opponent through sheer brute force of numbers?

This game literally has it all. A must have for any strategy gamer.

Campaign is very interesting and teaches you the basics, but you really need to watch some videos of high level play to really see this game shine. Check out Gyle's FAFcasts on youtube for an idea of what this game is capable of. 

Some of the shit high level players pull off is other-wordly... sneaking a nuke just around the back of the opponent's strategic missile defense via a nuclear submarine parked in the corner of the map... Apocalyptic experimental artillery battles... Strategic bomber barrages... Endless hours of entertainment!

If you love strategy games of any kind, you owe it to yourself to try this one. Right up with Sins of a Solar Empire for my fav all time strategy games!

[h1] THIS REVIEW BROUGHT TO YOU BY YOUR RIGHTFUL RULER, THE OLD LORD OF THE DEEP REACHES, AND HIS EXCESSIVE USE OF CAPSLOCK TO PONTIFICATE HIS EMINANCE. (JOIN OUR CURATOR GROUP NOW, ALL SACRIFICES ACCEPTED.) [/h1]


[b] INITIAL OPINION [/b] 

WHILE I HAVE THE DEEPEST RESPECT FOR THIS GAME, AS WELL AS THE GENRE AS A WHOLE, I MUST STATE I PERSONALLY DISAGREE WITH THE GENERAL DIRECTION THIS PARTICULAR STRATEGY GAME FOLLOWS. IT ALMOST FEELS LIKE THE META IS FAR, FAR TOO LARGE, AND FOCUSES MORE ON JUST RUSHING TO THE BATTLE RATHER THAN FORMING AN INTRICATE BATTLE PLAN AND APPRECTIATING YOUR MASSIVE ARMIES. SOMETHING I ENJOY DOING IN SOULSTORM AND TOTAL WARHAMMER. 

[u] POSITIVE ASPECTS [/u] 

GREAT TACTICAL SYSTEM. ALLOWING DIRECTIONAL CONTROL OF FORCES, AND A WIDE ARRAY OF STRUCTURES TO COMPLIMENT A VARIETY OF PLAYSTYLES. THREE FACTIONS THAT LOOK AND FEEL DIFFERENT FROM EACH OTHER.

[u] NEGATIVE ASPECTS [/u] 

AS PREVIOUSLY STATED, THERE ARE MANY STRUCTURES TO LEARN HOW THEY WORK, IT CAN FEEL OVERWHELMING. THERE A MANY TIERS OF UNITS AND STRUCTURES, WHEN THERE REALLY NEEDN'T BE. THREE TIERS IS OPTIMAL, FOUR IS TOO MUCH. CONTROLS ARE NOT AT ALL INTUITIVE AND [i]CANNOT[/i] BE CHANGED. 

[b] CONCLUDING THOUGHTS [/b] 

I AM CERTAIN THIS GAME APPEALS TO MANY FOR DIFFERENT REASONS. SUCH AS IT IS, IT DID NOT APPEAL TO ME.

Dear reader,

I am avid strategy game player (Both RTS and Grand strategy). This game is an interesting mix of the two. There is a great macro game and a very relevant micro game in real time. 

The real value of this game is of course multiplayer which has an amazing community in the Forged Alliance Forever. You will never want for multiplayer lobbies with equal representations for noobs and pros in the ratings.

However, this game will require you to surmount one very tedious aspect. The early game!

The early game has to be approached as a master chess player would approach the opening moves in a chess game. There are many options, but they are all set in stone and you have to execute them to the letter unless you want to provide your opponent a compounding competitive advantage in the mid and late game. Learn the early build orders, the timings, and the options available depending on faction/map. Everything after this part is pure creativity, inspiration, and cunning. 

Good luck, try this amazing game.

This game is a very demanding in the graphics department, but the battles are unreal. A late release of the 2000's, I would recommend this for any old school RTS fans. Single player matches could last an hour or less, or even longer depending on how you wish to play.

You have multiple races to choose from, including "experimental" weaponry which truly defines the races true intentions of being the one true "chosen" race. Strategy and economy are met in this game; aka, this isnt a "point and click" on resource managements. 
Mass and energy can be produced and fed off one another, which gives you you're own resource management. In a RTS, this is unknown and never been done. I highly suggest this if you wanna practice you micro/macro management skills while playing something completely new.

This is one of the most different RTS games I've ever played, instead of fast micro managing like Starcraft to determine the victor, it's the player that had the best strategy and read their opponents moves the best.

Every faction is only slightly different from one another, but the differences add up and make picking a favorite pretty hard, it's wild that 4 nearly identical factions all play differently.
Here's an example, the advantage to the Cybran faction is slightly reduced build costs, slightly reduced build time and larger area of effect for shield generators for the most obvious differences, then small additions like them having the best rapidfire artillery and the only boats that can go on land, an experimental unit whose purpose is to be disposable at the cost of garbage unit accuracy across the board makes playing them feel completely different from the other armies even if you basically do nearly the same thing with nearly the same types of units and buildings. it's the small abilities on the units that make em stand out. (like grabbing missiles in the air and throwing them back)

Also the games can last HOURS, without mods there's up to 8k units and buildings in a match and individual experimental units that can take up to over an hour to build which can be sped up by having multiple builders but increases resource drain. 

Which leads into the resource economy and would just loop into like a chain of other things in the game that all compliment each other very well and make the absolute best RTS I've ever played.

Also there's still a competitive community for this with a light modding community that shares maps and stuff, just look up FAF: Forged Alliance Forever and then buy this if you like the idea of a strategy game being won with a little bit of luck and a lot of planning and reading your opponent rather than micro managing every minute unit. And the bots are actually fun to play against, the difficulty settings aren't just the usual, braindead listed a few times with different names and then a bot that cheats and is actually good and is nearly impossible to beat without cheese, so you know, that's nice too.

Brilliant game. It's a stand-alone expansion, so you don't need to get the original. Far better than Supreme Commander 2.

If you want to play it online, you can using Forged Alliance Forever (FAF). It's pretty straightforward to set up and well-balanced (there's still an active community patching it on a regular basis), so if you want some thoughtful multiplayer strategy, then definitely check it out.
If you enjoy large scale battles with tanks, aircraft, and ships between 4 unique factions, then this is the game for you.

A vast improvement on the original. In the vein of older games such as Command and Conquer, it expects you to know your stuff, and throws you in head first on the first mission, since it is an expansion. The improved UI, and new units, as well as the addition of a new faction make this a welcome upgrade to Supreme Commander.

Basically just a really good standalone expansion pack to the original game. Story missions can get a bit boring, as the only real tactic for them is turtling. Overall, it's a very fun game and definitely worth buying.

Basically Total Annihilation with several quality-of-life upgrades. 
Squads actually arrange themselves in a way that makes sense: Heavy hitters at the front, artillery towards the rear. 
The Krogoth has been expanded on, into a series of "titan" units that can take on hundreds of normal size ones.
Best of all, commanders can be modified to fit your playstyle, into high-speed fabricators, or heavily shielded war machines.

Supreme Commander: Forged Alliance is my favourite game of [i]all time[/i]. There. I said it. It is quite literally, the [i]perfect RTS[/i]. It effortlessly captures the massive scale of the war you're fighting by literally allowing up to 1500 units per player (in a high player-count game I've seen upwards of 18000 at once), and makes it so incredibly easy to manipulate your units, that you can bounce between the macro and micro scales as fast as you want, whenever you want. There's no bullshit 'morale' system, no bullshit 'squad' system, and no bullshit fullstop. It's pure, fast-thinking, and [i]perfect[/i]. On top of this game being fucking [i]brilliant[/i], it's one of the only two RTS games that aren't complete bollocks (the other being AoE:II) - reasons why below.

My main problem with other RTS games is unneccasery mechanics. Simply having more mechanics does not automatically make your game more meaningfully complex, and it just encourages a focus on micromanagement. Starcraft suffers from this terribly, and battles are determined by who can press the most buttons in the least amount of time. There's no [i] concious thought[/i] in that at all, and battles are never won on strategy - this [i]completely[/i] undermines the very idea of a 'real time [b]strategy[/b]' in the first place.

Further problems include the fact that if you have no resources in other games, you have to wait for your scout/miner/whateverthefuck to bring resources back to your base to build more units to back up your army, and if, say, you were in the middle of a battle, this is precious time lost, and it (once again) is down to whoever clicked first. SupCom's economy, however, is decided by more by map control (more map control gives more mass extractors, more mexes means more mass collected per tick) than who-clicked-on-a-pile-of-shit-first, and map control is decided by, you guessed it, whoever has the better tactics (or more units, but that must mean you've got a better economy, and as such have already demonstarted superior tactics).

None of this [i]even mentions[/i] the game's [i]nigh-flawless[/i] use of asymmetry within the factions. Each unit in the game has different capabilities based on the faction you're playing as, and each unit either has a strategy, or a unit that hard counters it. [i]It's a giant game of rock-paper-scissors, but it [b]actually benefits the game[/b][/i], because (unlike other asymmetrical games ([i]I'm looking at you, Overwatch...)[/i]) you can see exactly what's around the corner at any given time, and adjust your strategy accordingly. [i][b]This means the game is based purely on outsmarting your opponent.[/b][/i] No other RTS is like this. [b]That[/b] is exactly why Supreme Commander is a masterpeice.

The game is even still maintained by the community via FAF - Forged Alliance Forever - at faforever.com. Recently we got loading screen tips, because, why not, and it's updated frequently with various balance changes and the like. The community is great - I play with the GB clan - and they're the loveliest bunch of guys you're ever likely to meet (even though I haven't been active for a while).

Simply put, SupCom:FA is the closest game to pure real-time strategy ever made. There's no messing around. It's a fast-paced, rapid-fire, mental challenge, not a twitch game, and it is almost completely unique in that regard.

10/10 - Buy immediately, it's perfect.

A great RTS that I love now.

PROS
- fair economy system (2 resources, minerals are map dependant, energy is building dependent)
- extensive amount of units and buildings
- You can have a navy, even Halo Wars didn't give us that
- Good campaign that has 3 playthroughs (1 per faction)  that are the same missions but have different objectives and events based on the faction you choose

CONS
- most matches against AI last a few hours in my experience (I turtle but still it can be a slow game)
- some of the super / unique units to each faction are overpowered. 
The UEF have a unlimited range artillery (expensive and takes so long to build but if built, could easily win the match). 
The Aeon Flying Saucer, while it can be killed, can disintigrate half your forces and base before it goes down

Favourite thing is to play UEF, make a submersable-carrier fleet and watch all the fighters and gunships launch out while the battlecruisers and battleships bombard the enemy and then send in the massed dropship assault force, it looks cinematically beautiful.

Total Annihilation was the RTS game i loved to play back in the day. 

I am very happy the concept was re-used in this game.

You know the saying, "They don't make them like they used to"? 

This game is the poster child for that in the RTS genre.

Huge maps, excellent unit selection, queing, route planning, layered sensors and jamming. All of these are not only present, but actually useful here. The units are diverse enough and useful enough to allow for many different approaches to the same problem. Do you want to send a fleet of tanks or ships at your enemy? You got it. Darken the skies with bombers? You can do that too. 

Truly a high point in the RTS field.

Love it <3

P.S.
You should also check Forged Alliance Forever (FAF) in order to play with other people

Probably my favorite strategy of all time, back in the day it used to be games like Total Annihilation and Red Alert 2 or Tiberian Sun, however these days Forged Alliance is just a good mix of graphics, gameplay, mechanics and design.

You can play smaller maps with for instant action where lower tier matters or bigger maps where battles tend to draw out a bit longer and you'll probably see tech 3 stuff, maybe even experimentals, most likely will if you play against bots, less so against humans.

The game is highly moddable, I mostly do comp-stomps so I play the steam version and just play compstomps.
However there's also FAF which is a highly supported mod with a big competitive community.

The campaign is also not too shabby, it's not easy for someone that would be new, as it expects you to know the game (probably cause it's an expansion even though it's stand-alone), but I still recommend a playthrough with all 3 factions.

For 10 euro it's a pretty good deal, if it's on sale it's a must-have if you like RTS games.

The only downside is that it isn't optimized for multi-threaded machines, so it doesn't matter if you have a I9 from 2018 or an I3 from 2014, you'll probably still get the same performance as a Core2Duo back in 2007.

Stick to the original.
Definitely a step backward from the original. 
You start with full cap vice it opening along with the map.
You can make your experimental units on the first map, and there would be no reason to not do so as they count as only 1 each towards cap.
The campaign is all but identical for the three factions, and when playing more than one faction (last two maps) the conquest is trivial.
No timed missions, only one pressure mission (on the first map).
I read an interview where the lead design said they had to rush to publish, and it shows.

The best RTS i have ever played by far. I am going to focus on why Supreme Commander: Forged Alliance is WAY better than Starcraft. 

NOTE: when you buy Supreme Commander: Forged Alliance you MUST follow the links to download the community-driven client called, "Forged Alliance Forever" which allows for easy multiplayer and ladder battles.

SO, the mechanics of forged alliance are vastly better then Starcraft meaning that a person can be competitive even on a low APM. This makes supreme commander a strategy game, rather than a twitch game like Starcraft. Supreme commander allows the player to create templates for quickly building a group of structures and has an option to build units on repeat from a factory. Due to the excellent economy system it is possible to stack construction orders even before the resources are available. 

The maps are beautiful in forged alliance and consist of natural landscapes rather than a contrived typical starcraft map with a main base, natural and ramps connecting them. In forged alliance, zooming in and out with the mouse wheel allows for easy assessment of the battlefield and there are 4 playable races with deep strategic diversity and completely different aesthetics. Getting to know the races is endlessly enjoyable.

There are more diverse units in forged alliance  - for example,  fully fleshed out land, air and navy, radar and stealth opportunities, artillery, dedicated scout planes, submarines, torpedo bombers and awesome large experimental units, to name a few.

Your ACU, which represents you on the battlefield, is a useful and upgradable weapon but it must also be protected because if it dies you lose the game. This mechanic adds tension because a player who is losing in economy can still win by sniping the ACU if they are clever. When an ACU dies it also explodes like a nuke which adds interesting mechanics in team games.

I could go on for hours about why Supreme Commander: Forged Alliance is great. It is criminally under-rated and I could never play starcraft again after playing this.

i played online a couple times, very hard, they send a bomber to my base and kill my resources super early on just to bully me forever. 10/10 game i recommend, is especially fun when you turtle and randoms carry you, i have used a nuke once; if it wasnt destroyed mid air it may have aided my comrades. if it had easy difficulty for online id give higher rating

I like the units, I like the graphics, but I absolutely hate the resource gameplay, all it is is who can rush units to mess up mass extractors, it feels less like an rts about unit placement and strategy and more a simple war of attrition, little of the challenge comes from building defenses and making an army, I would enjoy the game if it were easier to get resources both for me and my enemy or if it was more localized around your spawn, enjoyed the tutorial but as soon as I fought an ai and some people I realized how hard it was to get resources, most of my time was spent upgrading mass extractors to the next grade over and over again and doing it even more if one gets destroyed which they often do, I would give this game a 2/5, when something so essential for the entire game is so flawed it takes a toll on how much I can enjoy it, if you disagree that's great that you were able to enjoy the game but sadly I was not.

This is the best RTS game ever made. Seriously, it's better than anything I could even dream of. The campaign is amazing, the scale of the battles are breath-taking, the strategies you can come up with are numerous and vary wildly every game, and don't even get me started on the tech and units. I used to play with toys and imagine epic battles, full of heavy shields, nukes, massive artillery, giant mechs, strategic bomber swarms, you name it. I never would've thought that something like that actually existed as a playable game. This game is my childhood dream come true!

Yes it's an old game, but there is still a very active community (with plenty of amazing mods that add even more content). Just search up Forged Alliance Forever. The balancing in the community is wonderful, though it varies quite a bit from the steam version. I highly recommend playing FAF though, it includes everything from this game and so much more. Because of this community I've played thousands of hours of this game, so the steam numbers lie a little bit (more like a lot). In my opinion the graphics aged very well, the game looks epic and if anything the graphics make the game scale into huge battles a lot easier. 

The sci-fi theme of the game is truly one of a kind, the story is interesting and the theme lets units be wilder than you could ever imagine. The mechanics are wonderful, the tech system is the best out of any game I've played. It has the perfect blend of air, naval, and land units. The best part is the scale and weight of experimental units, they're truly unique and can change the tide of battle all by themselves. The most interesting aspect of this game that I haven't seen before is the usefulness of your commander unit. The standard gamemode (that's pretty much [i]always[/i] played) has your commander as your lifeline, which leaves you needing to protect it while killing the enemy commanders. This leads you to believe you should always have it heavily protected, but this unit is also your strongest. It makes for an interesting balance in every game you play, because the usefulness of your commander can't be overlooked. A good player can kill an entire tech 1 army with just their commander, leaving his own army free to raid his enemy's base. The over-all balance of this game is best seen when playing on FAF (they did a really good job with this game and have been going strong for years now), but what keeps this game interesting and fun is the sheer amount of units and possible strategies to win. I don't want to spoil the fun, but I want to say that there are more ways to win than you'd expect from a glance at this game, and certainly more ways than I could hope to write in this review. Any meta for this game involves so much more than any other RTS game it's almost laughable. Of course expansion and land-ownership gives you the edge, but you can definitely still win if you know what you're doing, and that's something I enjoy most about this game. You never play the exact same game twice, even after thousands of them. The only disclaimer I'd like to make is that the games can last very long (usually at least an hour per game), especially if you don't have a good cpu in your computer. It all just depends on the size of the map though and the amount of units there are on the battlefield.

I can't stress it enough, this is hands-down the best RTS in existence, and my favorite game of all time!!! (other than souls of course)

Rarely a better RTS is found. So many things about this game are good it's hard to narrow down on them.  If you're into long range, serious fire power and routing of hundreds of units into combat at the same time, this is it.  The interface is so good, specifially because of the ability to scroll out and see a "global" view of the battlefield.  Before this feature, not many RTS had this as an option.  Most RTS keep the player view what feels like inches off the action.  What a frustrating way to play an RTS. Understanding the field is one of the most important parts of an RTS game and not being able to see what you are engaging is a great way to kill the commanders ability to command.  Supreme Commander does not suffer from this illness.  

There are a few (small few) titles since this game that have kept up with it's amazingness but if you havn't played THIS one yet, have the cash and time to blow, do it.  You wont be upset about it.  I can tell you the price tag underwhelms what is most certainly one of the best RTS out there.  The reason it's not expensive is because of it's age but it holds it's own against the test of time.

One of the classics. When everyone else keeps trying to take things down to a smaller and smaller scale where everything is just more and more micromanagement, this is a game that takes the scale in the exact opposite direction. Everything is on an epic level. Battles go down between thousands and thousands of units, and the war isn't won in clever little second to second moves but in being able to react, plan, and focus on a much larger level. This isn't about if your 8 guys and their 8 guys met up and you got good trades on the balance. This is about if you can react to multiple fronts and strategies and armies all at once and come up with something that will outdo what the other guy is doing. And then do it again when they change it up to react to you.

It's hard to explain it in a way that gives it proper credit, but it's something very different to all the other RTS's out there and it's well worth a look.

This came is just an outright masterpiece. I already have a lot of hours logged on steam, but played it even more before steam got it. Supreme Commander: Forged Alliance has the best streaming economy out of any RTS I've ever played, the factions are similiar enough to make learning the game simple, but different enough to allow for a wide variety of gameplay. 
You can build large amounts of units taking a few seconds each and swarm the opponent, or build a massive economy to build powerful Experimental units and crush the opponent with sheer force. You can turtle and build long-ranged artillery and nukes, or rush the enemy base with bomber planes and a huge army. This is an RTS game not based on how well and quickly you can press buttons, but how well you can strategize to defeat your opponent - the way a true RTS game should play!
One of the best RTS games out there. Yet to be topped by others till this day.

A unique classic of the RTS genre which still has no peer or proper reproduction. It's easy to learn how to send a massive army of mechs and nukes flying at the enemy base, but the depth of strategy here can take years to really master.

I have a few hundred hours on this game. Download Forged Alliance Forever client. This is the only real way to play multipleplayer. The Forged Alliance Forever client has match making with a fair mmr system, but prepare to get wrecked, since most people playing this game now have been playing for awhile. The community has balanced the game very well, and SupCom:Forged Alliance is easily one of the best RTS of all time. The races are as balanced as they will ever get, and the main balance of the game comes through map pool selection. 

This game really shines in 1v1, similar to starcraft, but is still playable in 4v4 match ups. 

Mods are unfortunately somewhat of a must, which allow for things like hotkeying (that makes sense), better economy UI, and unit/building ui/symbols that don't hurt your eyes to look at when you zoom out all the way. 

10/10 Experience. Ignore Supcom2 and it's expansions.

Finally bought the entire franchise on steam during the sale. Owned the games even before steam, this is a grand sci-fi strategy game recommended for gamers who adore large scale battles on continent sized maps. From small tier 1 robots trying desperately take down a massive experimental weapon to large ariel battles and ship-to-ship combat, SupCom is now even made better with the LOUD mod project which further optimizes and enhances an already fantastic game. Highly recommend.

Supreme Commander: Forged Alliance 

Before I talk about the game I prefer supreme commander 2 than Supreme Commander: Forged Alliance, this wont change my point of view on the game and I will make points to Supreme Commander 2 within the review.

Supreme Commander: Forged Alliance is more of a slow paced game compared to Supreme Commander 2. 
Forged Alliance, brings new fantastic units to the roster, with more options with the reclaimed mass, the maps are much larger with great terrain height. The unit movement is a bit poor tho, I found myself micro-managing a lot with the land and sea units. The land units would keep getting stuck on the side of the mountain which did not help in combat but was easily fixable and not too much of a worry. The unit navigation, in the end, was all right for a game that came out in 2007. 
The graphics in the game are great It just blows my mind that they did all this in 2007, compared to 2018 aaa games it might stand to be a game with similar graphics.

This game is fairly unforgiving if youre not flexable. I've found it can be a bit difficult as unlike the previous game or SC2, you and the AI don't progress in tech each level. You start out with the schematics for t3 stuff immediatly nd so does the AI, which can make pregession in some missions difficult without being prepared to take a different approach.
Personally it took me a few attempts to get some of the missions, one specifically where you have the optional choice of freeing a PoW and destroying 3 bases, I ended up throwing my hands in the air, forgoed my usual base building and sent my ACU in. It went rather well.

Overall, I would recommend it. It's a good way to spend a few hours if you're inclined

The big daddy of Real-Time Strategy.
While the online scene is long dead and gone simply due to age, playing against the AI is still a great barrel of fun with some friends or alone. Sinking 2-3 hours a game isn't unheard of if you really want to go crazy on a 100+ square kilometer map.

However, the game's age does show - units often have poor path-finding and there's a lot of dodgy controls with regards to mass unit movement (such as them clustering, or lagging behind one another due to limits on the number of units being sent pathing orders at once) that can become frustrating. While this is never going to addressed by any kind of patch as the developers are long defunct, the issue is more commonly caused by pushing the boundaries of the game to territory it wasn't really intended to reach (such as a 3+ hour game with literally 8000 units moving about at once).

Still, if your idea of a strategy game is "Make a hundred of these guys then attack-move to the enemy base" as opposed to the microintensive games of the current era, then you're absolutely going to love this gem from the past.

I want so badly to love this game, I really do. But the simple fact of the matter is, despite the rabid fanboys gushing over it, Supreme Commander: Forged Alliance is an incredibly mediocre game in many of the most important areas.

Don't get me wrong, there are good aspects. The unit variety is good, the graphics are superb, and once you get established the experimental units are a lot of fun.

However, the game is plagued by issues that only the most obsessive strategy nerds will overlook, which is one reason why this game has cult status but little widespread appeal.

The most obvious is the GUI. It's cluttered, gives little indication as to what the buttons actually do, and even the unit buttons are so tiny and difficult to identify that you'll often spend several seconds trying to find the one you want, which in this brutally unforgiving game is a death sentence (more on that later).

The units, while varied, are classified into "tiers" which basically means every unit in the first tier is copy-pasted into the next higher tier, given a higher cost and better stats, and a new visual design. So most of the game, instead of balancing units by their individual characteristics, revolves around knowing the exact microsecond at which to start upgrading to the next tier. And if you have poor timing and try to tier up too early or too late, you can usually expect the game to give you a fat middle finger in the form of having no hope of recovering and defeating your enemy.

Of course, I can't talk about the game's focus on ridiculously specific tier upgrade time frames without talking about the other ridiculous and equally crucial aspect that is resource management. You have two resources, which shouldn't be hard to manage but they've made sure it is by putting all your resource data in a tiny bar at the top of the screen from which you must divine exactly how much you can spend without power stalling. This plays into the UI problems, as both the resource bars and the costs of each unit are difficult to read and often leave you trying to figure out how much you can afford to spend, and usually making wildly incorrect guesses which the game will happily punish you for.

The units themselves often have subtle differences between tiers and factions that WOULD make them more interesting and useful, if the game gave you any indication whatsoever of what the units do and how they can be useful. The game's tutorial is short and pathetic, and will leave you struggling to figure out the cumbersome UI and completely clueless as to what units fit what roles. Unless you have a calculator handy and don't mind pausing every 10 seconds, you'll never know what ratio of damage/armor to unit cost you're running, and where most games organically and intuitively place units in their own distinct, easy-to-understand roles, the roles that this game's units fill are so disparate and awkwardly mashed together that you could write a dissertation on the strategic roles of each one. 

Again, this complexity might be great to hardcore strategy nerds, but I do mean HARDCORE because to anyone else it's going to be hours of miserable trial and error before you can begin to enjoy yourself. I've played about six hours now and still have little if any idea of what any particular unit does, what it's good for, what it's weak against, etc... outside of its basic role of "does it shoot ground or air" and "is it long range or short range".

The units' designs in and of themselves reflect this completely nonsensical mashing-together of capabilities with equally frustrating and unintuitive size comparisons. So you have this unit that towers over the battlefield, surely it's more than a match for this tiny little spider? Well guess again, because that tiny little spider is a sniper that will rip your giant walker apart before it gets in range. Units are usually viewed as tiny swarming ants on a vast battlefield, but there's no natural size-to-armor or size-to-firepower relationship, making it even more difficult to understand the game. Even the massive experimental units experience this, because while they're quite powerful, their volume-to-armor ratios are complete horse shit. How are you supposed to tell what units do what? By slowly reading the manual and trying to remember which of the sixteen nearly-identical tanks is the one you need?

All of this compounds with the fact that the game is terribly optimized, chugging even on modern machines, with units often taking several seconds to register their orders (if this is because the pathfinding is offloaded to another thread, then what's the excuse for my garbage framerate even at minimum settings?) 

Overall, even if I decide to buckle down and learn how to play this insane game (I do love strategy games, being a fan of Command and Conquer and to a significantly lesser extent Starcraft), I'm not sure I can ever recommend a game that so vigorously spites anyone who buys it with the apparently wild expectation that it make sense and have an actual learning curve, instead of this game's learning cliff. It's just a complete mess and profoundly un-fun to play.

The game is great. The only true strategy game I know of where you can do what you want and make it work. You can play air, ground, navy, doesn't matter, it can work and this isn't a shitty RTS like Starcraft 2 where you see the same shit every single game. Marine Marauder anyone? Every match feels different in this game. Don't get me wrong, there are recurring strategies, like T1 spam, Monkeylord Rushes, things like that. But they are things that can be properly countered in many different ways. Not just "If enemy builds X counter with Y"

For example a common strategy is T2 Bomber Rush Sniping. What this means is, there are 4 tiers of units. T1 are basic, T2 are mid tier, T3 are the endgame units, and T4 are experimental units, the big guys you might never see more than one of in a single match. A strategy is to rush to the point where you can build T2 bombers, get a handful of them, say like, 20, then rush them across the map to directly attack the enemy commander. If you do it fast enough, the enemy commander won't likely have enough T1 interceptors to stop them from killing their commander, or AA or anything like that. 

Thing is with this strategy, you can counter by... properly setting up AA to defend yourself. Keeping your commander under a shield. Having a good amount of air support and AA ground units roaming around. Or just... walk your commander into the water where the bombers can't hit them, and sure they will do damage to your base but it will let you get defenses up to kill them wher otherwise they might have killed your commander in a single pass. And scout your enemy to see if they are trying any cheesy strategies like this, as catching them out and countering it can cost them a lot of resources, allowing you to turn on them with a strategy of your own. 

Unfortunately the servers are shut down and the only way you can play real multiplayer is with Forged Alliance Forever (FAF), a third party client trying to keep the game alive. 

I say unfortunately, because not only is the community surrounding FAF EXTREMELY toxic with every match ending with people trash talking their teammates, calling them idiots... my god the number of times I've been told to kill myself for nothing more than not playing perfectly. But another issue is that I believe it's peer to peer, but regardless of the method, it's kinda crap. Unless all the stars align and you have the perfect internet, with the perfect provider and ISP, and the perfect location in the world... you can't play. Because it's very likely that every match you try to join will either be left with endlessly trying to load into the lobby, constantly trying to connect to people in the lobby who are infinitely stuck "Connecting to-..." on your end, or ultimately, getting into matches, lagging out the game because "Sorry your internet and location combination don't match up perfectly" and thus having the other people in the game all leave, and not allow you to join the next lobby as you'll just lag it out again. 

But hey, if you can get past the toxicity, and you end up having the right internet/location to play without lagging people out and getting blacklisted from everyone's lobbies, it's a really, really fun game.

Edit: Tried playing on FAF again recently. It's just as toxic as ever with extreme racism running rampant and the like.

Might be an old game but darn it is good. It is harder to play than Supreme Commander II, but when you master the mechanics of the game. Also the games last a lot longer than SC II. All factions are pretty similar if we ignore their look and their experimental units. They are extremely similar for the air units. All their units have a unique look and statistics, but most of them have an euqivalent unit in the other factions. With four factions :

United Earth Federation : tank builder and they use napalm for their bombs they rely a lot on bubble shields and damage,

Aeon : Religious zealots, they rely a lot on the use of personal shields, their damage is moderate and a lot of their land units hovers which makes them unvulnerable to torpedoes if they cross a river or a lake which represents a big advantage compared to the UEF's amphibious tech II units that floats which makes them vulnerable to topedoes and the batteries from nearby ennemy ships.

Cybrans : they are cyborgs that decided to live free from the UEF, they are pretty balanced but they have really powerful experimental units. Their amphibious unit goes underwater which makes them unvulnerable to nearby ships canon but vulnerable to torpedoes which is even more advantadeous to than the Aeon's hovers since these tanks can send torpedoes and subs are less commonly used as ships.

And there is the Seraphims : They rely on lots of HP and DPS. They are an alien specie that almost got exterminated in SC I, now they want to destroy humanity. By humanity they mean what humans created too. They attack the UEF, Cybrans and some Aeons (because some of them think they are gods).

The rest of the mechanis... find it out by yourself.

I have been playing RTS games since about 2004, and this game still shines bright as the best RTS game ever made- in my opinion. Many other RTS games have a smaller focus that rewards tactics on the battlefield more than actual war-machine strategy. The scale of this game is massive, and the terrain plays a much more complex role in gameplay as a result. In many games, a hill or mountain serve the same purpose- that purpose being a simple obstacle that your units must navigate around. In this game, the geometry of the landscape will control what units and strategies will be effective based on the flight path of the missiles or artillery shells you choose to use against your opponent. This also is a result of the simulation-style of game engine the game features, which can result in interesting emergent behaviours or strategies that can turn a game around if a player imagines a creative way of using the physical laws of the game. The simulation can also result in bizarre rare occurrences that can make for fun, unpredictable and interesting events during play (such as an ICBM striking an overhead plane during liftoff).

If you are on the fence about buying this game because of a recent interest in RTS games, I recommend you just pull the trigger and do it. I have tried many of the recent/modern RTS games and none of them have captivated me nearly as long as this game. I would not recommend you even give Supreme Commander 2 a chance because it is a different game that follows a different philosophy, and it is a pity that it even shares a title with this game.

One final note: If you buy this game, downloading Forged Alliance Forever (FAF) is an absolute MUST. FAF is a 3rd party lobby that continually supports/patches/balances the game, features a pretty active community, and adds a lot of functionality to the game including multiplayer support for the campaign, a ranked ladder, and a built in map/mod sharing service. For free :)

Supreme Commander is a one of a kind RTS game. Probably my favorite one too. 

You start a skirmish game with a single ACU (Armored Command Unit) a big towering robot with the ability to build and attack. Your ACU starts to build your base, build military units for offence/defence, manage out your recources to a healthy balance (you have Mass as building recource and Power as upkeep recource) to the point where you build additional construction units which in turn start building their own forward bases. Your factories are supposed to be building on loop, meaning they will not stop producing units, to provide you with a constant flow of units to throw at your enemies.

This is probably one of the best things about the game but is also its downfall. The game is designed to limit your system to 2 cores of your CPU, meaning as soon as a lot of units are on the map the game will slow itself down in order to keep up even though your system can easily handle it. This results in all units moving in slow motion making it frustrating to play the game.

It's pretty stupid because the games charm is building giant armies and managing recources to build even more. The only way to counter this is playing on small maps and playing with a unit limit. That is the only issue there is with this game, and if this issue would to be resolved with a remastered version then it would be the best RTS on the market.

Even though this game is so old, it looks and plays really really good and deserves a remaster. To see your monkeylord (an experimental unit spiderbot that towers over the rest of the units) firing its huge ass laser over the battlefield really is a sight to behold.

I bought this on my search for an RTS game that uses a flow-based economy, and inadvertantly found the best game of the genre, which still holds true to this day.

For years I dabbled in Age of Empires 2 and Starcraft, always wishing for and suggesting ideas that would improve the quality of the UI, always being shot down for some reason for another, only to find out that this game has all of that.

-Paying for units over time instead of up front? Check.
-Queueing lots of varied orders to a unit, and THEN being able to edit those orders on the field? Yup!
-Units and weapon projectiles that have something even resembling physics? Fucking finally.
-Play co-op story campaigns with your friends? Yes! But only with Forged Alliance Forever.
-Overly complicated research system that makes the game as obtuse as fucking possible by having two dozen buildings with different upgrades and serve no other purpose once they're finished and thus a skill floor that's somewhere in geostationary fucking orbit? Nope, wont find that here.

If you love RTS games you should already have this game.

If you have never played RTS and want to give the genre a try, play this first and see why everything else in the last decade or two has been a huge let down by comparison.

And stay away from Supreme Commander 2, it is NOT a sequel to this.

Imagine commanding units on a massive battlefield where gun ranges are more than ten feet. Imagine being able to zoom out to see that entire battlefield before zooming in to see all the tiny details on your units. Imagine massive robots steamrolling through a giant base at your command. You would be hard pressed to find these features anywhere other than in Supreme Commander.

Graphically, Supreme Commander is still one of the best looking strategy games on the market. It was even further ahead of its time than Burnout Paradise. You can zoom so far in that you can see individual lines and mechanical components on the robots. On the negative side, the explosions and missile trails could use a bit of work. Additionally, when you zoom out, it de-renders all of the units on the map, replacing them with their respective unit symbols. For the massive experimentals, however, the unit symbol does not cover the entirety of the unit no matter how far you zoom out. This means that some units seem to randomly dissappear for no apparent reason. Admittedly, I am nitpicking, but this does bug me just a bit.

Mechanically, this game is nearly a masterpiece. All projectiles are rendered as such. They have a ballistic arc, travel time, and can be dodged with skillful micromanaging. With long range weaponry, (particularly battleship cannons and artillery) no two shots will land in the same spot. Resource systems are persistent. Engineers don't spend all of the resources required to build a unit at once. Rather, they spend it at a fixed rate over time which detracts from your rate of income. If you are spending more mass and/or energy than you are earning, you will begin to deplete your reserves, which is where storage comes in. Storage units add capacity to their respective resource reserves and, when adjacent to their respective resource production structures, will give those structures a production boost of up to 50%.

The game flounders a bit with unit movement. Units tend to get stuck on each other. They simply do not flow together the way they do in Supreme Commander 2. This does lead to some interesting strategies, however. Units can be used to block others, particularly when trapping a commander or helping one to escape.

The most interesting part of this game is the fact that there is still a thriving multiplayer community. After GPGnet shut down, a modded multiplayer client named Forged Alliance Forever was created. This standalone client makes improvements to many of the slight imbalances that weren't important enough to list here. It also simplifies the mod installation process (much like the Nexus Mod Manager) and is a great way to add new maps to the game.

All of these features combine to make my favorite video game of all time. If you have fifteen dollars, this is definitely one to pick up.

This is seriously one of the greatest, if not THE absolute greatest RTS available... regardless of when it came out. If you are on the fence, do yourself a favour and pick this game up. Got hooked on Planetary Annialation (which is great but not nearly as deep) and moved to this. Thought it would be a nice distraction becasue the new game had to be bigger and better... WRONG! Since I got the hang of this one I have not played any other base building strategy game! There's a but of a learning curve, but the community has tons of guides to get you started.
Its old but still fantastic!

Micro-management, unit stupidity, overpowered and too easy to get experimentals, basically economy gameplay with a higher tech = more powerful concept.
Obvious flaws in UI design (costruction bar doesn't know if to show the UEF Commander's missile construction progress or the structure construction progress he's at; lack of shield state info; no adjacency info for structures - neither affected nor provided), obvious flaws in population cap design (population-wise many low tier units can't counter few high tier units), no researches or upgrades that allow low tier units to stay relevant in the game later on, instead only structure upgrades and unit upgrades solely for the Commander and sub-commanders but they can't move while doing that - for whatever reason.

The solo campaign is awful: Always 2x map expansion + enemy attack waves spammed at you each mission. Shallow story, rarely any innovative mission design. In most missions the AI even fails to use (existing) nuke launchers against the player or the player's allies and even if the AI manages to use them it may fail at doing so correctly (irrelevant spot).

The UI lacks huge chunks of usability, ranging from proper engineer and engineering station control (don't nuke my economy into a deep minus; don't waste wreckage with excess gathering; it's not important that you reach the end of the waypoint(s) with attack-move but that you gather the resources along: wait if storage units are full opposed to driving from waypoint to waypoint) to show damaged unit repair cost in mass, energy, time with the selected amount of engineering units; show remaining time on missile construction of tactical missile / anti nuke silo missile / nuke silo missile along with total and remaining cost; show how much an engineer assisting a shield does increase it's recharge value and what's it's current recharge-assisted recharge speed like; what structures provide or benefit from adjacency bonus in which way; being able to restrict repair stations from certain tasks like structure construction / unit construction / missile construction / repairs / refuelling assistance or to make it auto-gather wreckages around while and in the amount it makes sense; no engeineering unit helps recharging shields by default if on assist or attack-move even if nothing else matters at the moment; no option to highlight any strategic icon in zoomed out map view to easily find relevant structures / units of the enemy; ...

Huge maps, pretty to look at units with a variety of weapon systems but obvious flaws, such as unit stupidity: a unit immediately dropping it's target order if ordered to move to dodge incoming fire, even if that target remains in range and an angle to be attacked continuously. Predefined unit target priority lists are sometimes absolute garbage and yet can't be changed, by the player, the "Supreme Commander", nor viewed. Thus I can't make use of a unit's turret as my choice is either to dodge enemy fire but have the unit attack the wrong target (like mobile tier 2 rocket launchers attacking mobile units opposed to structures, as they're siege units) or to take damage but be able to attack my intended target.

Bottom line: Focus on economy, far too much micro-management, unit stupidity that can't be fixed by the player because there are no UI options for that or it's not possible due to too many units doing stupid stuff (like tier 3 bombers flying off to suicide just because an enemy unit was around without the player having ordered that or stationary tier 3 artillery that, if left on it's own, starting to attack units instead of structures despite it existing to destroy those), lack of useful and important features (highlighting; engineering station restrictions; Sub Commander auto-upgrades), lack of things that make sense (low tier units not produceables in batches within high tier factories; tier 1 unit population cost equal to tier 3 or experimental population cost), pretty to look at but ranging from annoying to boring and in any case full of flaws. I tried to have fun but the game wouldn't allow it.

Now that I have a computer that can run it 7 years later, I‚Äôm having a blast.

Huge scale battles, intense resource management and strong tactical focus (your strategy really does matter, and and making the wrong choices at the wrong time can and will lead to disaster). The automation of factories and the way you give sequences of orders to groups of units works very well an allows for a reduction of micro management.

If you want to play the campaign, I would probably get the original ‚Äúsupreme commander‚Äù too, as  this one drops you in at the deep end with little in the way of a tutorial. 

The story isn‚Äôt anything to write home about in either game, but this game isn‚Äôt about the story - it is about a few giant mech suits teleporting onto a planet and smashing automated armies into each other until there‚Äôs only one left alive.

Multiplayer against human opponents is the best, but don‚Äôt expect it to be a relaxing experience - the game will demand your full attention and leave you feeling on-edge and under pressure.

It‚Äôs perfectly possible to panic a human opponent by putting them under pressure to defend, and making them make bad decisions.

Highly recommend for playing with friends.

Like the original Supreme Commander, you get a poorly balanced game with too much emphasis on boss units. The campaign is only 6 missions long, but the missions tend to be even more elaborate than in the original game, so there's still a decent amount of playtime involved. There are four factions, but unit types are mostly the same between factions - the factions don't feel distinct and unique like they do in other RTS titles.

Unfortunately, the campaign in SC:FA seems even more broken than in the original game. You can easily beat almost every campaign mission by turtling in your starting area and building one or two Heavy Artillery or Experimental Artillery fortifications. [b]The Heavy/Experimental Artillery will automatically target mission objectives, such as enemy structures and commanders, even when they are hidden by fog of war and should not be targetable[/b]. The Heavy Artillery will quickly destroy such targets and win the mission for you, without you even needing to muster your army. There is no defense against Heavy Artillery, and enemies in the campaign have no AI at all, only prescripted behaviors, so tactics like this are stupidly effective to the point that difficulty is nonexistent. 

Because the enemy has no real AI, campaign missions are balanced around cheap tricks. Every time you complete an objective, the map expands, and typically you immediately get hit with a massive surprise attack. This is unfair because there's no way to know where the next enemy base is, and therefore which direction the surprise attack will come from, until the map expands, but it's the only way the developers can add difficulty to the campaign.

Unit-level AI is dumb as bricks. Units try to shoot each other through terrain, don't react to incoming fire from enemies they can't see, and prioritize targets badly. Units with splash-damage attacks will damage friendly units, or destroy buildings you are trying to capture. 

The game includes none of the warnings and notifications that are standard in other RTSs. No "Your units are under attack", no "You're low on energy". The only time you're given any kind of cue is when your Commander unit is under attack. Lazy.

Key mappings are inexplicably completely different than Supreme Commander [b]and can't be remapped[/b]

As before, SC:FA contains many pointless tactical options that were a waste of time for the developers to implement. Strategic Submarines take so long to construct a nuke that they will never be able to launch one. The Paragon Resource Generator requires so much time and so many resources to build that if you can actually afford to build it, you don't need it. Although there are four levels of tech, the first two levels are largely superfluous since every match turns into a race to build experimental (boss-type) units. That said, there are a few nice new additions such as shield boats and repair buildings that add a bit more depth and utility to the game.

This game has got to be one of the best RTS games out there and I enjoyed getting the chance to play this again almost 10 years later since I first got the chance. The storyline in the campaign is also great and there are a few levels that one can replay several times over. I also really enjoy playing this game with other players either verses or against the adaptive x AI which makes for a great challenge.

How can I even begin to describe this game...

Had it before steam, and must have well over 2000 hours played by now. I'm far from the best player out there.

This game will test your skills continuously. I've played RTS games since the very first C&C game, and if I have to compare it to anything... It's Command & Conquer: Zero hour. With WAY bigger maps. And WAY more units. And WAY better balance between factions.

No matter what faction you play, if you play to its strengths you can overcome its weaknesses. There is no "best" race, there is no "best" unit. There are game-enders, yes, but building them means you will already have a vastly superior economy. Trying to build one too early will result in your army failing in other areas, which will lead to your death.

Every game you play is a non-stop series of choices: Will I focus on air-to-ground? His air-to-air might overwhelm mine which means his air-to-ground has free reign. Will I focus on land units? They're no good if his navy is superior and bombards my army to gravel before it reaches him. Will I focus on an experimental? I better have a decent army in all other areas or he'll pound me before I can finish it.

This game is not for the impatient, this game is not for those who get frustrated at a learning curve.

I purchased the original Supreme Commander when it came out and it remains, to this day, easily the most interesting and engaging RTS I have ever played. No other game has captured real-time strategy at such a grand scale and depth quite as well as Supreme Commander has. Some have tried to replicate Supreme Commander (SupCom 2, Planetary Annihilation, Ashes of the Singularity), yet none have come close. Truly a game before its time. 

Forged Alliance is only an improvement.

I would mention a strong emphasis on the "challenging" aspect. I can promise you, like any other RTS if not more, you *will* experience frustration, tears *will be shred, and salt *will* be spilled. If you happen to play with friends, it *will* test your bonds, whether they're on your team or not. At the end of the game, if you manage to survive through the endless slaughter, or the merciless players, congratulate yourself, for lady luck has just smiled upon you and granted you to achieve greatness. 
So what I'm trying to say through all this is, buy the game, play the game, and above all else, enjoy the game.

One of the best RTS games ever created. Supreme Commander Forged Alliance is the king of epic battles. Forget Total War, forget all of these games coming out trying to capture what this game had (I'm looking at you Planetary annihilation), because none of them are it's equal.

Supreme Commander: Forged Alliance, is much like it's predecessor, Supreme Commander, except it is, in every way possible, an improvement. A better UI, a better selection of units, new factions, et cetera. If you were considering buying Supreme Commander over this one, I can only recommend doing so if you are interested in what happens in the story (although considering the endings were basically retconned, and one can only assume who won in this, this is not really necessary).

So, it's an improvement on the original? So what? What makes the game good to begin with?

Well, Supreme Commander has some interesting gameplay elements to it. First, there is unlimited resources. And I'm not talking Age of Empires trading caravans meaning you can theoretically have infinite resources by buying things at the market. No, the two resources in this game, Mass and Energy, are entirely unlimited. You will never run out, provided you have the means of production. But this comes at a cost. If you want to have any resources on reserve, you have to store them, and that is difficult to do on a large scale. You can't just have 1000000 mass, unless you build a whole lot of mass storage buildings. But fortunately, you don't need it. Resources in Supreme Commander are not spent all at once. They are spent over time. Rather than you building an engineer and having it cost 50 mass and take 10 seconds, you will build an engineer and it will cost 5 mass per second for 10 seconds. It equals the same, but this allows for one thing other games do not. If you have 50 units being built at once, but you don't have enough resources to build them, that's ok. Their building will slow down to match what resources you do have, instead of never happening in the first place. But the opposite is also possible. You can be building no units, but have hundreds of mass coming in. If you don't have the storage, that mass will absolutely be wasted. Gone for ever. This adds a balancing act into the game where you try to get enough engineers (which can also boost the speeds/resource cost per second of factories, by the way) and factories to match your resource production, without having too much that things grind to a halt.

So how do you get resources? Well, the resources in this game, Mass and Energy are both gained in unique ways. Mass is the more valuable one (usually), it's generally the thing that is hardest to get. In order to get mass, what you have to do is build mass extractors, which can only be built on certain spots on the map. There are a limited number of these, and controlling them is the most important thing in the game. The second way to get it, is to build mass fabricators. These turn energy into mass at an unfavorable, but uncapped rate. You can have as many as you want, so theoretically you can have as much mass as you want, so long as you can get enough energy to cover it. And the third and final way to get mass is simple; your primary commander unit, which is the first unit you have (the most valuable as losing it means defeat in the primary gamemode) an your secondary support commanders (which are expensive, but you can have as many as you want) produce a small amount of it innately, which can be increased with certain factions with upgrades.
Energy is the easier thing to produce. There are three ways of producing it as well. Your Commander units, certain tiles on the map called Hydrocarbon, and the third, and most basic and easy, building energy generators. These can be built anywhere, and you can therefore have as many as you want (although, if they are destroyed they do explode.. so maybe dont build them too close to one another).

Alright, cool, you can get resources, but what can you spend it on? A lot of things, actually. Supreme Commander boasts a large assortment of buildings and units that are spread over three technology tiers. You advance through these tiers by upgrading them, an expensive and slow process, but one that is very rewarding, as the power of tiers increases exponentially (each tier is about 3 times more powerful than the last). You can upgrade factories, Commander units, Mass extractors and Shield generators through the tiers independently. The rest of the buildings and units cannot be upgraded directly, although can be replaced by higher tier units and buildings through factories and engineers (which are made out of higher tier factories) of the respective level (or any levels lower than them). Not every unit has a direct upgrade, at least not in every faction. For example, most factions (except for Cybran, who have stealth instead) have a Tech 2 Mobile Shield Generator unit. But no factions have a tech three mobile shield generator unit except for the Seraphim. This means that, even if you have the third tech level unlocked, there is still use in the older techs; nothing is useless, even tech ones if you use them right. Of course, the factions that have access to the stronger variants are typically stronger in their respective fields. This gives every single faction a unique playstyle, and different strengths and weaknesses they can play for.

But, there is no talk of units without mentioning the most important units in the games, the ones that make Supreme Commander supreme commander; the experimentals. These are available at tech 3, but are unlike any unit in those trees. They are not built out of factories, but by tech three engineers, upgraded ACUS, or SACUS on the ground. These are unbridled power houses, and by far the most powerful units in the game, but also the most expensive. Each experimental is capable of serious damage, whether it be from raw firepower, like the high powered laser of the Monkeylord or the quantum disrupting bombs of the Ahwassa experimental bomber, or tactical power like the Paragon's infinite resources or the Czar's air unit construction speed. But none are the best. Every unit has it's counters, whether they be physical, like the galactic colossus being weak to air units, or more economic, like the Mavor costing more than anyone can afford without the game having gone on for far too long. These are the units that make this game epic; when you see a gigantic towering monster ripping apart armies of weaker units, or completely shattering the front line defenses, nothing is more exhilerating. 

Nearly everything in this game is balanced, and the things that aren't are most certainly fixed by the community. That's right, this game is both amazing, and still has an alive community of players and modders after ten years. A simple search for forged alliance forever finds you hundreds of people to play with, tons of mods that add new maps, buildings, units, ui changes, and balance updates on a well designed platform.

There is no reason for anyone who likes RTS games to not play supreme commander. It is, by all accounts, a masterpiece.

[h1][b] On the joys of bloody enormous armies [/b][/h1]
Never before did a game show this much dakka on a screen. It takes strategy, transforms it into an art form, and finally obliterates it with a whole armoured division of giant microwave lasers on spider legs.
The vast maps allow the players to think on a scale never seen before, and no game has replicated this accomplishment yet.
The units are gorgeous, and the experimentals are as awesome as they are ridiculous. All strategies have a place in the game, as long as the player has the wit to enact them. Between giant swarms of drones, artillery batteries bigger than most cities, groups of robots as tall as a skyscraper, and enough nuclear silos to erase your opponent off the map, this ten-year old game can still make us weep with joy.
All in all, it's the best strategy game of the decade.

Better than Starcraft.

First off, this is one of my favorite RTS games to date. It's very different and unique from other games and has it's own learning curve. Just because some units are higher tech does not make them better. Experiemental units don't win games and can be stopped with overwhelming force and numbers. Forged Alliance is oodles of fun, but has some issues.

The campaign is solid. Nothing all that different aside from characters yelling at you to help their worthless asses and different maps. I admittedly stopped after 4-5 missions. Do not care for campaign but it gets the job done. Skirmish and multiplayer are where this game shine. Oh, and if you don't like micro managing this might not be the game for you. Don't worry about hotkeys and actions per minute, but if you want your forces to fight intelligently and without too much human intervention then this might not be a fun game. The same goes for setting up a base. You need to layer air and ground defences properly, spread them in such a way that no side is weaker than the other or is supported by troops, blah, blah, blah. Lots of micro and strategy. Anyway.

Games start with your ACU (armored command unit) spawning in alone, and you have to build up from that. Depending on any in-game mods (it comes with a few) the game progresses quickly or slowly. You have to balance resource expenditure with resource gain, expand in a way that does not spread you out too much, and keep an eye out for enemy attacks from land, air, and sea. Early game is tense and nerve-wracking, depending on how quickly and efficiently you can amass a fighting force and defend your home base or ACU. Mid and end game are either quick steamrolls, (either you or the AI get smashed by others) or an hour or more war of attrition. Generally AI in this game is ok, but misses as much as it hits. They'll leave hundreds of land units stuck on an island, or drive them up and down the map without attacking a base.
However, I cannot express to you the terror of seeing a hundred+ enemy bombers flying towards your base. Same with experimental weapons. They can be countered, but god help you if they catch you off guard and unprepared. There are also nukes in this game. They're able to be defended aginst with missile defence silos, and  don't wipe out entire sections of the map, but they do enough damage that, should they land, it is very difficult to recover and can end your game.

There are plenty of units in each faction to construct unique and versatile fighting forces, and different tiers have different types of units. Tier 1 generally has the mass-produced and numbers over quality units. Tier 2 is the best of both worlds, decent fighting strength and affordability. Tier 3 is specialized and extremely expensive. The unit is good at one thing and nothing else. Tier 3 Interceptors command the skies but have nothing to attack the ground. Tier 3 bombers annihilate ground targets with MOABs and blinding speed but fall easily to well-placed Tier 3 and 2 AA defences as well as some patrolling Tier 3 Interceptors. 

One major problem I have with this game though is that, the larger the battle, the slower the in-game time goes. In an 8v8 battle with AI it got to a point where the passage of a single in-game second took five real-world seconds. And it wasn't because my computer couldn't handle it, but the game itself slowed down because it assumed I needed it since I was micro managing hundreds of units. At first this is a cool aspect, so you don't fall behind AI who can react instantly and manage thousands of units and productions at once, but it is unadjustable. Therefore once I've created the perfect base which supports and defends itself perfectly and I can just focus on fighting the game gets boring fast. It is the most frustrating thing to watch Tier 3 planes (the fastest units in the game) crawl across the screen like a snail. But if you have the patience for that, which I usually do but only for one to two hours, then this'll hardly be a detriment. To be frank though I'd rather have the slow-down than not, it has admittedly saved me from missing an experimental unit steaking through my lines more than once.

I could go on and on about this game, but in the end it's only $15 and if you like RTS games and have a few hours to dedicate to figuring out a whole new way of war, give this game a chance. It is not THE best strategy game (there isn't one) but it is certainly one of the best. It stands out from all others with it's scale, depth, strategy, and attention to detail. Supreme Commander: Forged Alliance is definately one of the benchmarks in strategy games and well worth a measly $15.
