ALL HAIL MONKEYLORD

This game is fantastic. 

The economy in this game is one of the best in the genre, one which SupCom2 fails to uphold. The continuous economy system is great in practice and intelligent in design. Instead of a staggered income like in Starcraft where your resources are tied to workers physically traveling back and forth with an infinite storage, you have resources being aquired per game tick and finte storage. This facilitates building as much as possible when possible.

What is especially unique about SupCom1 is that when spending resources (mass and energy, the only two resources other than time) you don't pay the entire cost the moment you click build. Like the income, your spending is also on a per tick system. This is not only intuitive, it bypasses a lot of the tedium of macroing in other rts games. Instead of being charged upfront for queing 10 units, paying the entire cost of each unit before a single unit rolls out, you que units as you please and get charged the build cost per tick (something like every 1 or 2 seconds, i dunno).

You may think this is inconsequential, but when combined with spare resources in storage, you can build expensive structures or units extremely quickly for as long as you have the resources for it. In that same thought, if you have insufficent storage, you can use your engineers (all purpose builders, repairers, recyclers) to reclaim mass from destroyed  friendly and enemy units. After a large battle near your base, it's entirely possible to greatly increase your production per tick if you have engineers get the mass, allowing you to build some costly things for a short time.

The scale for this game is amazing. Unlike in other games where the camera is only ever at a fixed distance, requiring you to pan, click on the minimap, and use hotkeys to snap to places constantly, you can simply zoom out to see the entire map in SupCom. This gives you a better picture of your own army and buildings. Depending on your units' line of sight and sensors or dedicated radar/sonar structures, it's possible to locate every enemy unit and building on the map (barring some gameplay features). 

There are several core ideas to fight the enemy SC in the game. All of which involve building a main army, probably consisting of many tier 1 units and a smattering of Tier 2 and Tier 3 units when possible. T1 units are the most cost-effective, after all. 

One way to fight the enemy SC is to deny their mass income by destroying Mass Extractors as often as possible. Build a few units and send them out to deny as much mass as possible. This should slow down their production and development slightly. Of course, if they are also destorying your MEs as well, it gets more complicated.

Another idea is to use air transport units to attack structures that are important to the enemy. If your scouts see an undefended Shield Generator, for example, it might be worth dropping some T1 units into it to both deny the enemy SC protection and waste their resources and time by forcing them to rebuild it. It may also be a good idea to prevent large strategic buildings and Experimental units from being completed in the first place. No one wants a constant rain of artillery in their base or a giant death robot massacring their army.

The concepts in this game are inspiring and the execution of it is just so fun. It's clever and avoids some pitfalls or annoyances of other games of a similar genre. I suggest you at least try SC:FA.

This is possibly the best RTS game I have ever played, rivalling even my long-time favorite AoE2 and AoM.

Lets start with the premise for this game. If you ever played an RTS and felt like it was a bit small, Supreme Commander is the answer to your unasked question.

The game plays out on absolutely giant maps, with distances that take average units ages to walk across, requiring you to build transports to move them at an even slightly acceptable speed. It allows for actual artillery to be laid down and strike your enemies from afar, sending a hailstorm of screeching shells into your enemy's frontline or even their home base. It allows for nuclear strikes that can wipe out entire fields of units if you're not prepared for it. There is so much feeling packed into Supreme Commander of being an almighty God that you cannot help but go a bit mad playing the game.

That's not to say Supreme Commander isn't balanced; quite the contrary. There are four factions, each with definite strengths and weaknesses, none of them so great that they cannot fight the others, but require different tactics and approaches. You can play the UEF, the remnants of a federation of humanity, trying desperately to restore order in a galaxy of chaos, brought about largely by themselves. Signing on with them nets you a straightforward fight, with classic artillery, tanks and choppers. Or you can play as the guerilla cybernetic freedom fighters, the Cybran, who seek to bring justice to all those melded with machinery from the tyranny of UEF. The Cybran are decidely more versatile, often equipped with cloaking devices, EMP strikes and amphibious vehicles, which give them an easier time doing many different things, as the situations change, but not quite the same headstrong charge of the UEF. If you play the long game, you can take your chances with the Aeon, an almost religious group, using long-dead alien technology to bring their fanaticism to the rest of the galaxy. Your units tend to be more maneuverable, hit harder and have slightly longer range, but with slow firing rates and a general inflexibility; each unit does one job only. As the story mode unfolds, you can play with any faction, advancing their campaign to an eventual endgame to decide the fate of the galaxy, whether it be in the hands of a shattered UEF, the fledgling Cybran or the mysterious Aeon.

In Forged Alliance, a whole new faction is brought to bear; the Seraphim. An alien race, believed extinct and vanished, returns in the aftermath of the first game, bringing with them a hellfire that fractures what's left of all three factions of the first game. Only by uniting together will they be able to defeat this threat. But the strain of these alliegences threatens their goal and the game opens with the entirity of the humanity on its last legs, trying to stem the tide of the Seraphim. Playing as the Seraphim offers a unique sensation. They combine many elements from each of the three factions, while remaining very distinct from the others, not merely in aesthetics, but also in their unit options.

And still, I need to speak more about playing the game itself. Every game begins with a Supreme Commander; a builder, elite soldier, gatherer of resources and military overlord all in one. These commanders represent your player and if they are eliminated, traditionally, you are too and the game is over for you. Even if you allow for the deaths of commanders without ending the game, it can often lead to it indirectly; the explosion left behind is massive.

There are two resources, energy and mass. Mass is only found in specific locations, while energy can be harvested from anywhere, but the buildings for doing so represent huge targets for your opponent and a loss of energy, even temporarily, can often knock out many of your elite units' special abilities, costing you more than you might realize. The struggle for more mass extractors promotes territorial conflicts as players scramble to collect as many as they can, build defenses and station soldiers there.

Once the resources pour in, you lay down a few factories, either to make air units, land units or sea units; each with distinct features and systems, but none of them isolated: land units are quite capable of downing aircraft, aircraft can bomb land and sea and a vessel close enough to the land will often obliterate nearly any land unit that gets too close. And when you've got enough units around you and a few engineers out from them, you upgrade your factories and start producing newer and often better units.

An interesting facet of Supreme Commander is that even late in the game, older units never become completely obsolete; they are always generated faster, cost less and often 50 tier 1 units can outmatch the equivalent cost of tier 3 units. In this way, keeping tier 1 factories around is rewarded, rather than punished and it promotes a genuine question as to when to upgrade, rather than just as soon as possible.

But when it comes time to end the game, Supreme Commander is a spectacular show of so-called "Experimental Units" which can only be built by engineers from tier 3 factories and often at absurdly high costs. But if you can afford it, you will not regret it; experimental units are designed to end games that would otherwise continue indefinitely and they are often highly succesful.

And that's not even getting into all the complex features of radar, cloaking, stealth systems, reclaiming, neutral camps, terrain, air fighters, submarines, tactical strikes, ground defenses, shields, mass generators, upgrades for your Commander, support commanders and so much more. In terms of features, Supreme Commander cannot possibly be said to disappoint. They never become overwhelming; so many of them simply make the game a joy to play. Queing actions has never been easier and more visual than in Supreme Commander, nor has transporting large swathes of units across the map or setting patrol routes.

Besides this, the game is highly innovative in its ideas, forgoing a minimap in favor of simply being able to zoom out so far that the main screen becomes a minimap, letting aerial units actually go off the map if required to by their maneuvors, aircraft carriers, submersible aircraft carriers. And if you were to zoom in, you will find that despite the game's age, it is quite a detailed and carefully crafted game, visually speaking (though it does tend to cost your performance some when too many units begin to gather onscreen, which, given the absurdly high limits for how many units can be on the field, is quite often possible). Not to mention a very good, if not always very memorable, soundtrack and sounds that instantly convey their meaning.

If you like RTS games at all, this is one you simply have to try.

The only two gripes I have for it are the following:

1. The maps are very large, which is not the complaint, but I wish I could have a minimap that had larger icons to indicate where enemy troops are (even though there may not be many enemy troops, when having the minimap zoomed out to include half the map, its hard to tell if the enemy is moving since their icons are so small).

2. The turtle AI really changes the way it behaves from map to map. Sometimes it really does sit back and build defenses and sends out some attacks, but other times it sends waves and waves of enemies. Also, I played against the Turtle Ai on several maps, and they never used a nuke. Then when playing on a new map, I got nuked within 20 min of game play...

Other than that, it has the feel of a true RTS.

If you've played the original Sup Com, play Forged Alliance on HARD

As a Sup Com veteran having completed all three campaigns on Hard a couple of years ago in my CD, I must say, Forged Alliance starts off with a bang, literally. 

I found Forged Alliance both harder and stupidly a hella lot easier compared to Sup Com in some missions. In the original, you start off with the basics, T1s and slowly progressing to T3s until you finally get to play with Experimentals. Forged Alliance starts you with everything (with an exception of 3-5 new toys per faction) available at your disposal in the very beginning. This makes sense given the context and situation of the events in the game. Yes, this means you can build Fatboys at the very first mission, and that's exactly what I did. You have more freedom in tackling with your mission objectives with the wider options you have. 

Starting my first play through as UEF on Hard, I found it relatively easy after getting used to the controls. I ended up turtling until I had a couple Fatboys and an godly number of Percivals, the UEF's new T3 Bot to pretty much cake walk the mission.
The second and the fourth missions I found the hardest in all six missions (yes, there are only six missions). Reason being, for the majority of the missions, you start with your ACU only, that's it. The enemy will be constantly harassing and sending waves after waves of units at you. Grabbing a foothold at the start of the missions IS the hardest part of the missions themselves. 

This is basically what I did for the entirety of my UEF playthrough on Hard. You can live off with only 2-3 Mass Extractors, create a defensive perimeter, tech up to T3 using only a single Factory and start spamming T3 Gens and Fabricators until you have enough to start massing Fatboys (15 is a good number, but there's no stopping you to go for more). From here, you can start tackling your first objective and pretty much steamroll the enemy until the mission ends. 

The problem I found in Sup Com in general compared to other RTS, say Starcraft is that you have all the time in the world to tech up and spam high tier units before proceeding to your FIRST main objective. It really breaks the illusion of urgency. Another problem I found in FA is it's short! Six missions shared between all 3 factions compared to Sup Com's 18, with six "unique" missions for each faction. However, with the introduction of the Seraphim means a 4th faction with a whole new box of toys to play with, but unfortunately, there is no campaign for the Seraphim.

Although Sup Com in general is a slower paced game with battles that could last for hours, the ability to change the game speed is an AMAZING addition. Because why wait for half an hour to create a nuke silo when you can speed the game up to +10 and wait for only like 30 seconds? Players with slower reaction times can perhaps play the game on lower game speed whereas players who find the game pretty slow can speed it up or you can do both to mix things up. 

All in all, I had a blast playing Forged Alliance and it was certainly a great addition to the game.  At $18 NZD, the price is a little too high IMHO. If you're gonna buy FA, buy the Sup Com Gold Edition instead, or better yet, buy it when it's on sale

For me, this is the best 4x RTS ever made.  Huge maps, huge armies, awesome experimental units. (You can play this faction in skirmish mode, but not in the campaigns.)  

Your groups of units march in formation, so everyone comes into range and opens fire at the same time.  Best unit AI of this type I've seen.  Newer games haven't duplicated it.

I find myself playing it through one more time whenever I'm bored.

When you try to use the secondary display function (to show the minimap on another monitor), if you have more than two displays connected the game will not be able to use a secondary display at all and it will default the resolution to something low like 1024x768 - the only "solution" to this is to either unplug your other displays so only two are connected and it will work fine on two displays, or not use the secondary display feature of the game and it will display at full resolution on a single display. Given that I do not see either of these as an acceptable solution, and due to the age of the game I doubt this will ever be fixed, I have submitted a refund request for this game.

A Total Annihilation style RTS that will keep you playing for hours.

This game only loses half a point rating because you will need a very powerful quad core CPU. This game came out in 2007 so wasn't optimised for any more than that. Even then it can still slow down on larger maps with many units and/or AI running becuase the engine only really uses two main threads. 
The GPU won't be the bottle neck as long as you have an average one by todays standards.

Just a heads up, this is my first review so I apologize in advance for any suckyness. Also I have played much more off of steam. Also this goes for both games.





       The best game "ever" is a very hotly disputed subject. Most people say it's WOW, or Halo, or CS go, or COD, or Shadow of the Collosus, or some other game with a big fandom. All things considered, I say this one, because I truly believe it has (almost) every aspect of the ideal, at least strategy, game.



Great Interface 
                           
Immersive storyline                     

Balanced units                             

Unique factions                           
 
Many viable strategy options

Great replayability                       

Amazing Graphics

excellent Multiplayer and LAN gameplay

HUGE unit cap

tons of units to chose from

Truly epic maps

lotsa mods

Stunning (and realistic) scale (the smallest units are twice as tall as a truck and the biggest are about 1000 times larger)

              

If you havn't lost interest thus far I would love to go into details.



There are only two resources in the game, mass and energy, both ar equally important and are used to build everything in the game. mass is gathered primarily from "mass deposits" on which you build "mass extractors". Energy is gathered by building generators. Both are used in about equal amounts if you go by values as opposed to numbers. One of the most interesting parts of Supreme Commander is that its resource system is "active". In other words, you don't save up to buy something, then have it instantly reducted from your total when you buy something. Instead, the resources are gradually  pumped into a unit as you produce it. In short, how much you have stored up doesn't really matter, what does matter is how quickly you are getting it. Personally, I like this system a lot and find it more realistic.    


There are five basic unit categories in the game. 

ACU: The Armored Command Unit, it is the only unit you start out with. It can build stuff, shoot stuff, and upgrade itself. The best part? If it dies it explodes with the force of a hydrogen bomb :)

Engineers: build stuff, make factories build faster, and can "hack" enemy units and buildings.

Land units: kills stuff on land

Air Units: transports land units and kills stuff just about everywhere

Naval Units: are more powerful (and expensive) that the other types of units, and, you guessed it, they kill stuff on (and under) the water
 

There are a TON of different buildings to make so I wont go into too much detail. There are land, air, and naval factories, loads of turrets for different purposes, artillery, and intel structures, as well as advanced structures and assorted resource-related stuff. 


There are three main tech levels. Basically, when you build a factory of any sort, you can build engineers (and of course military units) from it. you can upgrade the factory to the next tech level at any time and get access to new units and better engineers, with access to more advanced buildings. The only individual units which can be upgraded are your ACU and some other buildings. 

PS. There are also MASSIVE experimental units for each faction, each with the power of an entire lesser army. thay are built like buildings and many include these as tech 4, but I cant help but think of them as seperate.


There are four factions in the game, each with its own appeal and advantages.


UEF:  The United Earth Federation, the humany humans of the game, mechs, bullets, and tanks. They are pretty good at rushes and tend to have more in the way of armor and heavy assault units and less in the way of shields. 


Cybran: I really feel for these guys. In short, they're oppressed humans with cybernetic implants who want to free their bretheran from forced obedience programs. They are the undisputed masters of cloaking and stealth technology, and are optimised for surprise attacks. 


Aeon: the classic humans-with-alien-tech-who-are-quasi-religous. lots of lasers, powerful shields, and plenty of hover tanks *cough* Vanu *cough*. Their main thing is "every unit must be as good as possible at its given duty and not be able to do anything else". no filthy multi-tasking in the illuminate. This really comes out in their units and is favored by a lot of people.


And last but certainly not least (don't tick them off they blew up earth) THE SERAPHIM. Long story short, we nuked them on first contact (smart humans, seriously more should do that) they dissapproved of that for some reason and promptly alien-nuked us back, and so on and so forth. They don't seem to have an over-arching unit style, but thay are very good at turtling (great AA, good artillery, and best shields in the game). Their tech is sort of Enders game's Formics meet Halo's covenant.



All in all, an amazing game, 9/10, honestly the only thing that could make it better would be a map editor.

Forged Alliance improves upon Supreme Commander in every aspect. The only issue I really have with it, is that it's a standalone game and that they did not include these improvements in the base game, which could REALLY benefit from that.
Some examples:
- Better and smaller UI. Everything takes less clicks, is easier to find and takes up less space, giving you more space for glorious battles
- Graphics seem to have been improved a bit as well
- Land units now actually march in sensible formations from what I can tell. Previously the formation was torn apart when units were moving. This is better now.
- Units in general respond better and faster to commands. Terrain navigation is much smoother.
- Naval units no longer ignore commands are get stuck on terrain as far as I can tell. Previously naval units adopted ridiculously large formations and parts of your naval force would simply not move to a location if it thought there wasn't enough space. This might have possibly been, because naval units also had a tendency to get stuck on one another...
- Air units are easier to handle and operate more efficiently it seems. They also now finally use landing pads the way they were designed to be used: USE ALL OF THEM, not just one when issueing the refuel order. It was pathetic to see 50 air units circle 1 landing pad when 10 were available. Now they use everything as it should be.

The campaign spans another 6 missions which you can play as any of the 3 core factions with new units for each. However, you can't simply switch factions in the campaign and the missions do not change based on what faction you're playing. Just some dialogue and vaguely different units (since all 3 factions have at least mostly units that fulfill similar roles, just with different stats and armaments). Speaking of stats: The game has been completely rebalanced it seems. Also, there is a new faction you fight against in the campaign, which you can also play as in Multiplayer. Great "addon".

I don't usually write reviews, but Im willing to make an exception in this case. There simply aren't too many reasons not to like supcom fa. In other legendary RTS games, battles are made in rock paper scissors-style. Spears defeat cavalry, cavalry archers and archers spears. And of course, upgraded units defeat weaker ones. In the background economy plays a big role. Thats ok, but it lacks deep multidimensional strategy that supcom offers. 

Battles are fought in underwater, groundlevel and air simultaneusly. Instead of dealing less damage to sub-optimal enemies, units have limited capability where they can operate. For example, cannons cant kill submarines and AA-guns are required to kill aircraft. This itself requires more thinking than just normal RTS. Most of the guns can shoot longer than they can see, so radar and scouting is required to utilize units full capasity. Game offers excellent radar and intel system, which ads even more to the strategy aspect. And when you you think this cant get any more complicated, game introduces intelligent missiles and missile defenses, energy shields, nuclear weaponry, EMP weapons and much, much more. In the background, your economy produces units instead of just buying them unlike any other RTS.

When you read negative comments of this game, you will notice two kind of players.
1."My potato wasn't able to run this game, so it must suck"
2.Players with less than 10 hours of playtime. They usually just say it sucks instead of accepting the fact that they just suck at it.

This is a game I have bought very recently and it has not been found wanting. 

I was introduced to the SupCom franchise via Youtube after incidentally coming across Supcom 2 fanmade epic gameplay vids. A month later I bought Supcom 2.

It has been many years since then and I have always heard or read reviews of how Supcom 2 (which in my mind was a decent RTS) had failed to meet the high expectations of loyal fans from Supcom and Supcom FA. My curiosity urged me to discover a little more about this antique and not too long ago, I happened across a steam sale where the bundle pack was sold for 5 SGD (3.45 USD).

In a short timeframe, I have spent many hours into this game and it has left me astounded that such a relic has not been properly glorified. In other words, this game had happened upon us too early for its time. Rarely do we ever come across such a priceless bundle of packaged joy (at such a steal too!).

It had been frustrating but incredibly worth it when I first started this game. My base was constantly getting wrecked by early T1 units simply because I made the noob mistake of jumping to T2 at the start. Eco management in this game is incredibly different from SupCom 2 and when handled improperly, would cost you the game. I only learned about 'ghetto gunships' a week ago and had so much fun pounding enemy bases with 28 mech marines per T3 transports. 

There are really very little restrictions when playing this game and it forces players to abuse as much of the unit abilities as possible. Hell Starcraft 2 did not have this type of complexity when it comes to eco. (or unit management)

To my fellow RTS gamers out there that are still deciding to buy this antique, give this a shot and you might be pleasently surprised at how complex this game can be.

For my money, the best RTS ever. It keeps you focused on the action while not over-simplfying everything to do so (See: Supreme Commander 2) in the best way. This game also shows how quality of life improvements for the player actually give you so much more freedom to strategize and work on complex tactics. 

One example, which is simple but so obvious, is how air transports work. In other games maybe it makes sense for air transporting units to be a manual, intensive affair if the combat is squad based and micro, but in SC it feels like you're AT WAR and you don't have time to deal with loading some land unit you had auto-built for basically no money onto a transport. Instead, you set up a ferry route, which automates your transport to pick up any units at X and transport them to Y. Then, you set the waypoint of your unit factory to the ferry beacon. BAM - you have units being tansported automatically to the front lines of the battle, which never seems to stop.

There are so many viable strategies (at least in single player, i'm not a mutliplayer guy), that depending on the map and the race you land on every game can feel slightly different. This game perfectly itches my RTS 'turtling' instincts - with UEF you can set up insane defenses, then eventually build a massive artillery battery that can win the game by itself. The sound and visual of that thing firing is incredibly satisfying.

Get it, get it now!

MULTIPLAYER community is still VERY MUCH ALIVE (visit www.faforever.com and get the lobby client). Steam multiplayer works as well,but you got the supreme(yes, intended) version of it on FAF.

Also plenty of guides and tutorials avalible, tournaments still happening.

Want to see how the gameplay looks like? Check out Gyle on youtube, he's casting game matches.

Overall this is a brilliant RTS kept alive by the community for a decade now, very complex and with a steep learning curve. Also somewhat dated graphics, but if you're an RTS fan, you know that visuals are the least important thing.

This is the ultimate strategy game. Basebuilding and economy are a huge factor in this game and the default game with expansion has a large amount of units per each faction. Want to turtle up your base and nuke/artillery your enemy into the dust? You can do that. Want to build up a quick and fast army to rush your enemies before they've prepared? No problem. Want to play a game that can easily take 4+ hours and will test how well you can really handle stressful situations? This is the game for you. 

Seriously I don't know how this game never became an Esport, I guess it was just made before Esports really kicked off. 

And with any game, mods can only stand to make it better. I personally use a mod called Total Mayhem which adds in entirely new experimental units, for each tier, and has rekindled my love for this game. 

It's a shame it never the sequel it deserved.

I feel that this is probably the best RTS I have ever managed to really get into for the following reasons: 
- Land, Sea and Air warfare that is functional and relevant
- Decent shielding mechanics
- Great scale, it big but not unmanageable with some practice in multitasking and prioritising
- Resources being and fluid asset, rather than paying up front you pour metal and energy into a build. This means with proper resource management you can aggressively adjust you building strategy quickly while not wasting resources to a cap.
- Build rate basically a third hidden resource, when correctly managed is an amazing asset to resource expenditure
- All projectiles are simulated meaning you can dodge artillery by moving out of the way once it has fired

"Best Strategy game of E3 2006"

To this day, I have never played a game quite like Supreme Commander. Originally, the spiritual successor to the genre-defining "Total Annihilation" (which I love, if not simply for the fact that it's a 2D game, that truly believes itself to be 3D.)

Not since TA, had I played an RTS with real-time projectile simulation. Not since TA, had I played an RTS with fully realised naval warfare. Not Since TA, had I played a game with such a neat and intuitive Flux-Economy. Not Since TA, had nukes terrified me.

Meet Supreme Commander. The game that does it all. Better, for the most part. (tanks could in theory hit a fighter jet, but unlike TA, you cannot actually target your howitzers on gunships) Oh, and there's giant, stompy, death dealing, Mazer firing, ground shaking, base breaking, experimental class units too. From the Monkeylord, (A huge, amphibious, robotic spider with a Microwave laser on it's back, intergrated stealth field and surface-to-air missile launchers) To the Galactic Collosus, (Think the Iron Giant, tractor claws the size of your house, and toes as big as a tank. Oh, a face melting beam of purification.)  The CZAR, (Independance day mothership) to the Atlantis, (An aircraft carrier that is also a submarine) and the Fatboy, (A mobile tank factory that is also itself, a tank. A tank that carries 4 battleship turrets, can drive on the sea floor, projects it's own protective shield bubble and can perform repairs on allied aircraft.) 

This game provides no shortage of ways to reduce your opponent along with all he (or she) holds dear to scrap. Superheated scrap, being propelled at considerable speed after having had an alien nuke land a couple hundred metres away.

The game provides 4 factions that despite being so similar in terms of core game functionality, (this is not your starcraft, where each race builds and expands in entirely different ways, (AND the simmilarities of the races does make sense in lore!)) have their own very unique play styles.

The Cybran Nation: Fast, Stealthy units designed for harrassing the enemy wherever they can. Whilst not the best in a standup fight, (their units generally have the weakest armour) do have some of the games most devastating weaponry and you'd be hard pushed to see them comming. Has an aerial gunship for every tier. Wrecks faces.

The Aeon Illuminate: Specialised, Single-Purpose units that excel at their roles. Many of their units can hover, allowing for a very mobile amphibious attack force. Their mainline units have some of the longest ranges out there but they can be quite slow. Many units can be bolstered with cheap and efficient shielding. Can dominate the skies.

The United Earth Federation: Heavy Firepower, Heavier Armour. Never one to shy away from a fight, a UEF commander has the best options available when it comes to digging in. Good fire rates, good armour and a diverse range of offensive tools. Fairly even mix of fast harrassment units and slow, heavy hitting base breakers. Strong naval warfare.

The Seraphim: "Alien Floaty bits" An agressive race with advanced technology. Many fast moving assault units with high fire rates, capable of swarming and causing a ton of damage. Arguably has the strongest Combat Armoured Command Unit, with lightning fast self-repair systems. Combines relentless frontline assaults with flanking air cover and drops.

Now yes, the companies responsible for this game are now nonexistant and as a result, there is no developer support available. However there is a hub, run by the community for the community called, "Forged Alliance Forever." This community provides regular updates and balance patches for all those running their free game lobby. The FAFfers (as they call themselves) are the lifeblood of the game in it's current state. Multiplayer server hosting, balancing, bug fixing, custom maps, custom mods, performance enhancements and so much more besides.

For those still unsure, I cannot reccommend enough that you watch the youtubers "Gyle" and "BRNKoINSANITY" (and if you search one, you're bound to find the other) I have watched hundreds of matches casted by these guys and every single one is different. In Supreme Commander one thing is certain. Nothing is certain. 

Do I recommend this game? A thousand times, yes.

Do yourself a favour, and pick up the greatest Real-Time-Strategy title that the modern world has seen. (Humble Opinion)

Oh, and do yourself another Favour. Play this, love this, but stay away from Sup Com 2 unless you're taking it with an ocean's worth of salt. (same goes for Planetary Annihilation... such dissapointment)

As someone who grew up playing command and conquer, this is the best RTS ever created.

The sheer scale of supreme commander is part of its appeal - the smallest unit is as tall as a tree, your commander towers many times taller than that and the 'experimental' endgame units are many times larger than even that. The excellent physics simulation and solid unit animations make the light units feel agile, while hulking mechanical monstrosities shake the earth with each ponderous step. Maps start at five kilometres square, and end at 81x81km strategic nightmares where it feels like troop movements take forever. All areas of combat are accounted for - land, sea, air and intelligence (even space, sort of) are each a powerful tool, and a game's outcome can be decided by any one of them. Weapons range from those wielded by rank and file units to fight one another, to strategic nuclear missiles and enormous artillery pieces able to fire clean across most maps. Each and every projectile is simulated - a launching nuclear missile can impact on enemy aircraft flying overhead. Units can physically block incoming fire from vulnerable targets. A high-flying bomber can accidentally bomb an interceptor flying beneath it.

Making all this manageable is an excellently implemented strategic zoom and robust waypointing system that allows orders to be queued long in advance to make best use of your limited attention. And your attention will be limited - there is so much to keep an eye on in supreme commander that you'll always have something to be doing. Upgrading your economy, managing units, keeping ahead of the tech curve and making sure your ACU, the commander at the core of your forces is safe. The commander is an exceedingly powerful engineering unit, but is also the most powerful combat unit on the field in the early stages of the game, and as a result using him aggressively can be the best way to gain the upper hand. This creates a somewhat unique mechanic in which your lose condition must fight on the front lines in order for you to survive, creating great tension.

The Forged Alliance Forever community project has taken FA and kept it alive, offering matchmaking services as well as regular balance and bugfix patches to keep this incredible game going. By far the best RTS I have ever played, and likely ever will play thanks to its unique scale, vast amount of options and effective interface.

Pros:
Huge maps.
Good unit variety, across four unique factions.
Projectiles and corpses use Newtonian physics.
Great RTS that requires actual strategic planning.

Cons:
Largest maps will bring your computer to its knees.
Terrain height not always obvious, might need to rotate map to figure out why your turrets can't hit incoming bombers.
Built-in AI insufficient for learning to play the game well, need to supplement with mods.
Slower pacing of game and clumsy units may be a turn-off to those who are used to playing games like StarCraft, which are more focused on tactical decisions in combat.

This game was released in November 2007 and now, nine years later, is still the most multilayered and yet refined RTS I know of. There are land warfare, air warfare, naval warfare, intelligence warfare, missile warfare and everything inbetween. There are so many options to turn around the tide of battle that you never know when the next surprise is awaiting. The game still looks great, sounds great and feels great to play. There is no itch of gigantomania that this game can not satisfy (if your computer can run it, that is).
Granted, there are a few annoying issues (e.g. you can't save mutliplayer saves and performance does drop significantly in apocalyptic end battles that involve thousands of units because barely any game uses multicore capabilities and neither does this one), but that doesn't change that this game is AWESOME. If you have any interest for the RTS genre at all, you need to have played this game. I don't think you'll regret it ;-)

To me, this is still the definite real time strategy game. It may be a bit graphically dated, as well as demanding significant single-threaded performance, but its strengths in UI, scope, unit and strategy diversity still shine as much as they did when it was released. The automatition and construction planning options are likewise second to none in the genre, allowing to truly focus on the big picture, long term plans and multiple assaults at once.

Thanks to the rate-based energy and mass economy, sacrificing an army or two as a diversion or loosing a fleet or even base to a clever ploy is no big deal, so you can both experiment and take risks. Most maps are big enough to comfortably house a bunch of backup facilities anyhow. Not to forget the endgame units are both a great way to dramatically resolve too balanced battle situations and just tons of fun to see unleash their might amongst smaller foes. 

The storyline missions are nice enough. Sure the dialog is a little ridiculous at times, but it has a bit of B-Movie charme and gives each faction a nice coloration, motivating to go through all of them. They also don't hold your hand much. While this is a standalone expansion to the original, you're expected to know your way around enough to dive right into it once you decide to tackle the campaign. This also means less filler missions though. But the real meat is in the multiplayer, which, especially with mods, offers almost endless replayability. There are some great balance tweaks, the all-important sorian AI improvements and the fun commander updates and new endgame units of Black Ops, for example, but many mods and a very much alive fan-made multiplayer project still exist (though as the steam version added matchmaking services, it's not even needed to enjoy it). 

Despite being older, I consider this superior to both its successor (Supreme Commander 2) as well as the spiritual successor planetary annihilation. It just feels both more diverse and more balanced, despite four very different factions to me. Still a definite recommendation I expect to enjoy just as much in five years as I do now.

Many hours have been had strategising the defeat of one's enemies on this games sprawling maps. The game's goregous strategic zoom function is some of the best user interface design I've seen in gaming. The factions are similar but very different, yet still balanced seemingly perfectly. The game only builds on it's predecessor, and is in every way superior to it; it is the correct way to do a sequel. All the things I like about this game add up to make it one of my favourite games ever.

Supreme Commander: FA is a RTS game that merges a plethora of unique or, at least, unusual mechanics with a classic base building strategy core to create something truly exceptional.

Some strategy games allow you to build a 'wonder' to win; here you instead build experimental units that roll over the map rather than trigger a boring win counter.
Reckless rushing and failed attacks are punished - wrecks of destroyed units can be salvaged, so a failed attack can go into the opponent's pocket, providing unique comeback potential if the attacker can't maintain constant pressure.
Resources are spent gradually over the time of building/unit construction instead of in bursts.

Now, for the downsides.
The official multiplayer is dead, however the community managed to establish a new server (google Forged Alliance Forever).
For some this is a plus, but there's only 1 real win/lose condition: respectively, destroy all the enemy Armoured Command Units (ACU) to win or have your own ACU destroyed to lose. This can lead to frustrating sniping, as each player starts with only 1 ACU and there's no way to acquire extra ones.
Single player experience is underwhelming. Relies on attacks from inaccessible areas of the map for difficulty, which is very, very cheap.

Currently my favorite RTS of all time. AoE2 havent really survived the test of time for me (its still alright but i prefer AoE3 over it). 
the economy in FA requires you to balance the energy and mass you're inputting and outputting. Whenever you're overflowing the resources you're essentially wasting resources. 
the game has a large variety of units and structures and has a small modding community aswell. there are 4 factions each with their own specialities, from navy that can walk on land to heavy T3 point defences. 
The battles can be massive with thousands of units on field, the game seems to have a system of time dilation where if someone is experiencing poor performance the game will slow down so it can perform all the events that are happening.
The graphics are what they are, supreme commander 2 does look nice but turned out worse on a lot of the mechanics. I personally love this type of futuristic look (especially UEF and cybran stuff <3).
Sounds are also pretty good.

This review covers Supreme Commander and Supreme Commander Forged Alliance. Get both!

One of the greatest RTS games of all time.

If you like commanding hundreds of sea, air, and land units please read on.

Don't let the low hours on Steam trick you. Eight of my friends and I bought this game on CD years ago. We would routinely play 6 to 8 co-op or multiplayer (free for all) games on LAN before the Internet speeds really got fast. I've got at least 1000 hours in this game with all the weekend LAN parties hosted at a bachelor pad.

This game ruined my RTS experience by introducing or near perfecting some techniques.

1. Virtually unlimited queueing of orders (patrol, move, etcetera). I've never hit a limit. I would reckon that I have had at least 100 orders queued without any issue to tens of different unit groups.
2. Large scale battles. Each side can have hundreds of units (we've had 8 sides in one large battle).
3. Mouse zoom in/out. I can't explain in words the many ways this feature is plain useful and should be the standard in RTS games. You can zoom into a low level (one unit) and out to see the entire map and units are then represented as particular icons (easily identifiable). You can issue any command or select any unit from low to high level zooms. It's plain awesome.
4. True faction faction and unit differences. Big difference between tier 1, 2, 3, and experiental units.
5. Interesting upgrade paths for commander with multiple paths (Builder, fighter, stealth, etc).
6. Short cut keys to do same thing as mouse.
7. Four factions that look, feel, and really behave different.
8. True land, sea (above and below), and air units.
9. Transports (air or sea) with fantastic transport queueing/ferry options.
10. Graphics look great, even for an old game.
11. Replayability (different campaigns as different factions, co-op, multiplayer, maps)
12. Experimental units.
13. Game balance. Almost every unit has a counterpart. Want to nuke people? Want to build anti-nuke system?
14. Automation of engineers (patrol duty) to clear battle fields of wrecked metal or terrain and repair stationary units.
15. Massive selection of buildings and units
16...I'm sure I'm leaving stuff out.

Note: I am playing with Windows 10 64-bit operating system with Supreme Commander and Forged Alliance executables set to Windows compatibility (Windows XP SP2). If I do not set this, then game crashes between levels. With it set, I haven't crashed yet.

You will definitely like this game in two cases:
1. StarCraft 2 is too fast for you and you prefer to use tactics instead of "Actions Per Minute" skill.
2. You like the game "Wargame" (or similar games) but you don't like a lack of possibility to construct buildings and gather resources.
This game is much slower than StarCraft, have much larger scales but also allows to construct bases. So you probably will like it.

Also, not anyone knows, but the game still have strong community and you can easily find a game to play PvP up to 4x4 or even 6x6 players.
Community of this game created a service for multiplayer, you may find details here: faforever.com
You can found some video of PvP on Youtube and you will note that the game is very tactical.

Another interesting fact, at first glance you may think that most units of all 4 factions is similar.
But actually they have very different characteristics. You may found units database on the website above and explore how to use different advantages or disadvantages of different units and factions.

Also, if you played Planetary Annihilation (which is similar to this game), take a note that Supreme Commander have a lot of features which is not available in PA, such as:
 - Shields
 - Large air transport
 - Better aviation
 - Mods with a lot of new units
So I recommend you to check this game.

This is the best. Do not tell me about the others, for this one is the best. In no other game I have seen can you build a sprawling military complex, and then build several military complexes each with specific functions. I have built naval bases, radar stations, listening points, walls, artillary bastions and air bases cloaked from radar. I have sent vast fleets to patrol the oceans, I have made refueling stations where spy planes and bombers alike refuel within sight of a walled complex humming with fifty power generators. Supreme Commander: Forged Alliance is the expansion that brings the Supreme Commander community to life. There is one new campaign that can be played through three times, once for each faction, with some differences in dialogue and secondary objectives between factions. New units add to mid- and late-game strategy, and the new faction gives greater variety in multiplayer games.

What sets Supreme Commander apart from other RTS games is a combination of in-game cinematic graphics and the tactical nature of viewing the field. A player can rotate the map in almost any direction and at any angle to see units firing on each other. This is the first RTS game I've played that uses zooming for navigating the field as an alternative to a minimap. If you zoom out far enough, units show up as icons that immediately tell the player what role each unit plays. This unique "tactical view" also has a dual-screen mode, which allows the player to monitor and act on two places on the battlefield at once.

The community of Forged Alliance players is still alive and well, with thousands of active players on a community-driven lobby (Forged Alliance Forever, FAF) that also keeps the game up-to-date.

If you plan to get Supreme Commander: Forged Alliance, get it together with the original Supreme Commander. The two games are like computer desk and chair; they each function fine on their own, but put them together and you get a whole different experience.

Forged Alliance is the natural progression of the Supreme Commander gaming experience, and in many ways it is very superior to the old. A completely new faction, as well as a handful of new units for each of the already existing factions, means that there's a lot of new content. Unfortunately, the campaign is not particularly good. If you liked anyone who survived Supreme Commander's story, then I think you will at least get some emotional impact as they struggle to survive this new war, and not all of them make it out alive. However, it just doesn't measure up over all, and I think this is because there's just so much more single player story content in the first game. The multiplayer experience is greatly improved from the introduction of the new units and faction, though. The AI is much more aggressive for online co-op play, and the new AIx computer opponents provide a refreshing challenge. They are still not with out their limitations but I really like playing against them.

When I was young, I grew up playing a lot of CnC on PS1 and later PC. For the longest time there was no other series that scratched my RTS itch in the same way, at least not until I got this game. Supreme Commander: Forged Alliance is what I would consider the pinnacle of old school RTS gaming. No squad based combat. No requisition points. Just mountains of resources, and hordes of units to conquer with.
It is a game both familiar in it's mechanics, yet unpecedented in it's scale and execution. Those days of my youth, wishing for larger battles and greater control of my armies, have been answered in full with massive maps and unit caps, super inuitive controls for group assignment and ordering, and the ability to see it all from on high like the god of war I wish I was.

Regardless of how old or new it is, you will be hard pressed to find a more well executed RTS than this, and I would recommend this to any armchair general, without a moments hesitation.

Supreme Commander & Supreme Commander: Forged Alliance
First of all let me say that I love Real-Time Strategy games and consider myself kinda an authority on them.  If you like futuristic RTS, then you‚Äôll love all 3 of these games, I've beat the campaign on all of them at least twice :)
(I even love the Total Annihilation games that these are based off of)
I used to play SC & SC:fa all the time, then bought them all again when it was on sale here on Steam.  They are simple to learn, yet difficult to master.  The number of units can be intimidating; I‚Äôd recommend doing a little homework to find your favorite FACTION and UNITS that will fit your play-style.  I used the website: http://supcom.wikia.com/wiki/Complete_unit_list

An engaging RTS with plenty of units to figure out and massive maps to spend hours playing on.

If you're new to the RTS genre or too unfamiliar with Supreme Commander's mechanics to play a skirmish match, then you should play through the campaign. The story is average but it does ease you into the game so you can better enjoy a skirmish match.

Forged Alliance, similar to the original SupCom, have a very uncoordinated AI. I often see a bunch of units, given the same order to move, endlessly bump into each other until I separate them individually. The per-unit micro-management can get quite distracting when you have 500 other units on the map. Fortunately, there are mods that alleviate this issue. I must still credit the AI however, for being able to traverse across maps that are 81km x 81km in size.

Graphics are nice for an RTS of this age and most modern graphics cards should be able to run the game well on high settings. I should point out though that Forged Alliance isn't well optimised for multicore processors, so if your CPU is more than six years old then it better be top-of-the-range otherwise the game will start to lag after about half an hour in large AI skirmishes.

Issues aside, Forged Alliance is a timeless game with epic battles and I would highly recommend it to any RTS fan or newcomer.

Supreme Commander is the best RTS I've ever player - or rather it would be the best, if some bugs would have been fixed. 
So it's the game I utterly love, but it doesn't return the favor too well.

[The Bug:
Yes, I'm talking about the slowdown due to the AI calculating paths and what not, so that your session will inevitably end up in a stop motion manner - but that's something we have to live with. (There are ways to work around it, but nothing can stop it entirely.)]

Back to the topic:
You are a supreme commander controlling an army up to 1000 units, but instead of counting high tier units as 2 or 5 points, it really means 1000 "things" - that could either be small units and buildings or 1000 giant experimental spiderrobots with huge lasers.
That's up to you and your resources, which you don't gather the normal way, but trough a constant flow of the two: energy and mass. If you get more, you can build more or faster and if the supply stops, you can resume the process until you fixed your resupply. This ends up in an interesting economy, that really provides the basis of massive warfare.

And warfare is massive indeed, as you try to form every rock and every bit of energy on the map into something you can throw at your enemy. The fun thing is, that the most advanced (experimental) units usually provide the best firepower and endurance in combat in most RTS games, but the smaller units will never go unused in SupCom, because 200 tanks/robots/gunships can deal as much havoc as one big pile of steel and guns. 
It's always a matter of choice and not one the devs force on you.

Get the game and have fun, (if you like the genre).

The only thing left to recommend is, that you should play the Forged Alliance campaign first, because the six missions it offers are huge - the map will be revealed further after certain checkpoints - and you don't have to unlock every unit in what seems to be 100 missions in the main game. 
(You can still play the main game after FA, if you're hungry for some more, but then you'll know much better what you should do and how you can achive victory with the low-tech units the game forces you to use for the first bunch of missions.)

For muliplayer, check "Forged Alliance Forever". It's a great mod and a lobbysystem that keep the competitive part alive.

(Small note: SupCom 2 is nowhere like it's predecessor and therefore sucks, I sadly have to admit.)

by far the best installment of the Supreme commander series!  This game has infinite possibilities and overwhelming scale.  Forged Alliance has an advanced strategic system that will tear an iron fist down.  the balancing between air, land, and naval combined warfare gives the game a feel to it that gives the player a clear freedom to dominate how they want.  the three different factions are well balanced, but all offer clear advantages, for example as Cybran, I will find myself getting assault bots picked off by aeon units, but when I notice I dominate them, however, if I cannot react in time, I may be too late.  the economic system is simple, however difficult to retain, and a key component to winning.  a tech tree gives this game a three front battle, tactics, economy, and tech.  all three must be balanced if a player is to win.  this game however is  drawn back by it's low framerates, and online play can be moderate in it's overall lag.  The community is flowing with many still playing the base game, and a new community in Forged Alliance Forever (look it up for more details).  Competitive play gives this game a feel that is sure to last.  As I have already stated, Forged alliances balancing ensures that powerhouse players do not win through simple swarming, however, conservationalism has drawbacks as well.  eliminating overpowering extremes and promoting fair play.  I give this game a 8.5/10 due to the framerates and online play, as well as sometimes underwhelming AI's.  I recommend this game to any RTS competitive player looking for an active online community especially.

Supreme Commander: Forged Alliance is probably the shinest gem out there that still blows all the other next generation RTS games by this day.

The community is still alive and working here, usually hanging on the Forged Alliance Forever lobby mod, which optimizes the game further and adds working multiplayer lobbies, ranked matchmaking, and so forth.

I highly recommend this game.

Like all RTS games you start with a few basic units, usually just your commander.  You then build factories, resource gathering, and military.  You then Explore, expand exploit and exterminate.  In supreme commander you have 4 tiers of units T1 to T3 and then experimental units, which are very expensive and take a long time to build, but are essentially game enders.  Each of the 4 races has its own unique units, strengths and weakenesses.  The experimentals also fill fairly specific roles, making enemy engineer capture a significant boost to your combat power.  It has been out long enough now that the units are all pretty well balanced.  

If you are a fan of RTS games, I highly recommend this one.

As far as I am concerned, Supreme Commander: Forged Alliance is the best RTS game, ever.  Originally Cavedog Entertainment created a game called Total Annihilation.  At the time it was considered the best RTS game, ever.  Chris Taylor later left Cavedog to form his own studio and worked on a spiritual successor to his best-selling TA game.

It's hard to describe to today's generation what SupCom was like when it first came out.  It was the first triple-A title that really utilized dual-core (and above) systems;  In an era where you had to force most games to run on a single CPU lest they crash, SupCom adored it, loved it, reveled in it.  It would drive the top-end system into the ground with its rich, lush graphics and absolutely enormous battles.

It's also the first game that I can recall which specifically had built-in support for multi-display.  One monitor could show you the ground fight, and on the second monitor you could either have a different camera view or a scaled-up map view.

There are too many things to list which were innovated in this game.  Here's a by-no-means exhaustive list:

* First game to really show what multi-core computers could do with gigantic 1000+ unit battles.

* First pure simulation grand scale RTS, with no RPG-like dice rolls.  If a mega-gun launches a projectile at you, you can dodge it if your unit is fast enough and you are good enough at microing.  Every missile and bullet is simulated when it leaves the barrel.  This made the game a micro-lover's dream.

* First game to support multi-monitor, allowing you to configure each display as you want.

* First use of a wide-scale camera.  You could zoom all the way out to 30k altitude and view the battle as a series of stategic icons, or zoom all the way in and watch each individual shell land on the enemy.

* First use of "zoom at where I'm looking" smart camera.  Seriously, I wish more people would utilize this mechanic.  In most RTS games you had to keep your hands on the keyboard at all times despite the game being 90% mouse driven, just so you could move the camera around.  But in SupCom, they made it so when the camera zooms in, it focuses on the point where your cursor is situated.  This makes for an incredibly smooth playing experience, where you feel like you have total control over your view of the battle field.

* First RTS where indirect fire is a critical aspect of gameplay.  Most units can actually launch projectiles or shells at least 10% further range or so outside of their radar detection range.  Other units which had wider radar detection ranges could be coupled with indirect-fire units to maximize your effectiveness.  Early scout units were always useful because of this.  SupCom was never a case of "build unit X until you win" sort of game, against competent players you had to have a mix.

* Innovative resource system inherited from TA which leads to very intense economy management.  Instead of buying units for a fixed cost from a fixed pool of "money," you deal with resources in a producing/consumed sliding scale.  This meant that build order was the king, particularly at the beginning of the game, and you had to be careful with how you spent your resources.  Your factories would never refuse to build a unit if your resource production level was low;  They would just take more and more time.  Conversely, if you over-produced but didn't consume enough, you were likely wasting materials and giving an advantage of the enemy who might not be so frugal.  Because of this, each match is a constant tweaking of your economy.  You had both mass (used for building) and energy (used for powering things) to keep track of.

* Wreckage.  Yeah, it's there just to look cool, but it also contains mass which can be reclaimed.  Build a mega-unit and send it to the enemy base and -- oh no, it dies!  Now, not only did you lose your chance, but you've just given the enemy a huge economy boost.  You really had to think about sending in the heavies, as it was possible to give aid to the enemy just by your failures alone.

* Stealth mechanic which allowed you to coordinate sneak attacks and all kinds of fun assassin-style missions against the opponent.  One of the three factions is geared towards stealth play.  (Cybrans forever!)

* AMAZING control over what your factories and units can do.  Want to have a master factory and 6 others which mirror what it does?  Doable!  Want to have a certain factory to exit a unit and then have it automatically patrol a particular route?  Doable!  Want to edit patrol paths once they are defined?  No problem!  Smart engineer units which automatically assist or reclaim wreckage?  Ayup!

* Adjacency economy boosting system.  Factories placed near power sources get a reduction in their power consumption.  But they also get mass-cost reductions when placed near mass sources.  This meant you were always search for the most optimal building configuration to maximize your economy, usually altered by the terrain.

* Upgradable commander unit.  SupCom had a single powerful hero unit which could be upgraded via research to give it extra abilities.  Most of these abilities were mutually exclusive, so you had to think about what approach you would take.

* Pretty decent single-player campaign that's entertaining and fun to replay as different factions.  It's no Starcraft in that regard but I think it's held up fairly well.

* (Sadly no longer applicable.)  Very active eSports community, with frequent and entertaining matches.  Game supports a built-in replay mechanism which allows you to watch matches with ease.

* Tons of really awesome mods which expanded the life of the game, such as Sorian AI (which fixed the fairly braindead default AI) and Black Ops (adds a ton of new units).

* SupCom:FA adds to the already excellent SupCom by introducing a new single player campaign, new experimental units, all new maps, and a new faction (which admittedly, was kinda broken and way overpowered until the bugs were patched out).


Seriously, this game was amazing.  A LOT of thought went into its design and implementation.  SupCom: FA literally ruined all other RTS games for me.  I cannot play them without thinking, "Gee, I wish I was playing SC:FA instead."  And then I boot the game up again and take on

A very good RTS, and if you loved TA, then this is the game for you.

I previously made a review for the vanilla Supreme Commander, but this is my actual review on the game.

This is Supreme Commander: Forged Alliance. Obviously takes place in the future where people build robots to fight for them in a huge war known as the... 1000-Year War I believe? Anyway, 3 factions are fighting for Galactic Supremacy for their own, but the other 2 factions stand in their way... In Forged Alliance, an alien race called the Seraphim, was once annihilated by the Xenophobic humans. This time, they come back, and they aren't the peace loving aliens they were once known as.
The Seraphim go on a Galactic Conquest to wipe out all humans for nearly putting their entire race to extinction. Now the humans are coming to extinction and the only way to fight back is for the 3 factions to unite and push back the Seraphim invasion.

Now let's talk about gameplay:
This game has a large variety of units, with 3 tech stages (1,2, and 3). There is also a special stage 4, which are the EXPIRAMENTALS! I put EXPIRAMENTALS in all Caps because let me tell you, they are BIG-ASS Giant ROBOTS of Mass Destruction! 
Unlike most RTS games where there's a population limit, Supreme Commander basically has no limit (Well, unless if you count 1,000 units as a limit). Also, all units only take up 1 point of population, so you can literally have up to 1000 units. 

Now there are a few consequences for having such a large limit, LAG. Trust me, Supreme Commander takes alot of processing power, and you probably will not always run at 30 FPS or so.

I recommend this game, It's fun. I'm sorry that's all that I can really say.

ALSO, I would recommend you download Forged Alliance Forever (FAF), it's kinda like a community-made add-on that allows you to play online with other players (Because normal servers are done for), it also has mods for the game that you can mess around with your friends with. Be sure to download that with the game, it's safe.

Supreme Commander: Forged Alliance is a great RTS game that offers an experience like no other. The battles take place on a huge scale with maps ranging from 5km x 5km to 81km x 81km. The sheer size might sound pretty cool, but then you get into more small scale. Base building in this game mixes micro and multitasking with managing multiple bases at a time. Nearly everything in this game is upgradeable in some way, so you have to manage whats upgrading while managing unit production and income. You have to remember to upgrade your ACU so you get the benefits from it, all while remembering to build defenses and intel bases. Base building in this game is also really awe inspiring. Different buildings get buffs from other buildings, such as the energy generator, energy storage, and mass fabricator. These all affect each other in some beneficial way, stressing the need for a good base lay out heavily. The fact that nukes and artillery shells can hit a plane in flight also amazes me. 

This game offers some really awesome experiences and has a real need for a good strategy. Base building gets more and more complex when you're trying to get the most efficient base, and upgrades add more depth and variety to the game. If you're looking for a good, fun, and over all enjoyable game, you're looking at it right now.

An excellent RTS game with a remarkable amount of thought and care put into it, one can tell that the developers truely loved the game they were making, and that level of care, meticulous attention to detail, and authenticity is hard to find in modern AAA games like starcraft.

Supcom effortlessly joins relatively simple concepts such as mass extraction and energy generation with tiered technology and layered complexity to create a game that at no point seems overwhelming, but always keeps the player engaged. I cant remember any time in the game I felt like I was coasting, or I had nothing to do, as the tremendously effective AI always keeps you on your toes, and whether you are a new player, or a veteran, there's a difficulty for you. I also can't say there was any time, save perhaps one instance, where I rage quitted. Supreme Commander is one of thos games where losing is just as fun and spectacular as winning. Hearing that STRATEGIC LAUNCH DETECTED, or seeing an experimental bomber bearing down on your base are the kinds of twists and turns in the game that level designers would work to make by hand, Supcom acheives them on a regular basis just by operating within its own well implemented rules.

Great expansion to an already mind-blowing RTS. The range and freedom of what you can do is enormous. Nice to know that FA Forever keeps a multiplayer community alive. There aren't many mods, but the game does have in built support, including one for expanded unit limits (though I haven't confirmed whether it works, since I focus on turtling and experimentals and never hit the cap).
Addition of the Seraphim faction is nice as it gives an alien race some show in this game, though honestly the four factions aren't too different apart from their experimentals and a few strengths and weaknesses. I don't mind too much, as Total Annihilation only had TWO factions which were almost identical. All the experimentals are unique, though, and the biggest attraction for me. Unfortunately managing fewer powerful units is far easier than managing a large army, but there are advanced controls to help you. And there is a way to fast forward the speed in the campaing with + and - minus keys which I took forever to figure out. Sure helped eliminating the wait time for my armies and defences.
The story's quite a bit shorter with one campaign across all three races (your choice) and not too memorable, but blowing up my enemies with 20+ gigantic flying saucers and skyscraper mechs is always satisfying and makes my day.

It is the spiritual sucessor to the masterpiece that was Total Annihilation, an enormously challenging tactical thrill, a visual spectacle, and... well... extremely good fun! If you like strategy, get this game, and download Forged Alliance Forever (http://www.faforever.com/). The mod community has taken everything that was brilliant about this game, and polished it to a mirror finish. It is the perfect strategy game - rich with options for the long-term planner, the jerky micromanager, or the coordinated team-player. You'll find yourself battling with vast armies of tiny, disposable tanks, giant death robots, nuclear artillery, flying saucers, stealthy nuclear subs, epic battleships and mobile tank factories - and everything is useful, somewhere, somehow. Also, DO NOT get Supreme Commander 2 - this game + FAF (Forged Alliance Forever) is thousands of orders of magnitude better!

Total Annihilation grew up, moved out of its parent's house, and then [i]melted the entire planet's face.[/i]

Seriously, everything I liked about TA is in SupCom in some fashion, but better. SC added features that (at the time) no other RTS had, like the megamap. Now, if your game doesn't have a megamap, don't bother to come to school - the other kids will just laugh and push your face into the dirt. Looking at you, [i]Ashes[/i].

Shields are also a favorite of mine. In TA and other RTSes, when your defenses repel the infidels, they take damage that must be repaired. With shields, as long as the bubble stays up, the shield will regenerate over a relatively short period, and the defenses will keep on keepin' on. There are mods that add super bubbles (shields) that can stop practically anything, which leads to some "battle of Hoth" instances where ground forces must be sent in to take out the shield generator (if you sprint units inside the shield, they can attack things within) before the long-range bombardment destroys everything else. 

It is super fun.

The game isn't perfect, though. The one overriding issue, apart from the developer being dead and no official multiplayer list servers, is performance. The game was developed in a time where dual-core PCs were a new thing, and was quite revolutionary in its multithreaded design. The simulation and the rendering pipeline are broken out to two threads, and this helps the game run fast on multicore systems. 

Unfortunately, the sim thread could really use being broken down into multiple threads itself. Mid to late game, even though the FPS will still be 100+, units will act slow. They move slow, react slow, missles and cannon shots will move slower. This is the sim thread being overwhelmed by the 2000+ units running about. Since the dev is gone, this will never be fixed, and that's a damn shame since the game is practically the perfect RTS otherwise.

[b]Regardless, buy this and enjoy![/b] Actually runs really well on my I7-4770k throughout a match and is as much fun now as then!

This is hands down the best RTS game that I have ever played. Large scale battles with thousands of units under the command of 2-8 players (12 on some custom made maps). Many maps ranging from 5 square kilometers, all the way up to 81 square kilometers - just shy of 50 square miles! - and yes, they really do feel that large.

Pros:

[list]
[*]This game is tons of fun whether you're playing alone or with family and friends
[/list]

Playing alone is great; playing with friends is pure awesomeness.

[list]
[*]Very high attention to even some of the smallest details.
[/list]

There are tons of moving parts. If you go up close, you can see all the tank treads spinning, as well as multiple parts of legs making coreographed motions to create movement.

If a unit has more than one weapon, each weapon will by physically present on the unit, and each projectile will appear different.

If there is a unit that has a passive ability, for example shielding, or radar jamming, you will see that there is a physical part on the unit that creates this effect. What's better is that it will even resemble the actual building structures that use the same effects, to a certain degree.

One of my favorite examples of the above is the Cyrbran Tech 2 Tactical Missile Defense structure and the Cybran Tech 3 Siege Assault Bot. The T3 Bot has it's own personal Tactical Missile Defense system, and looking at the left shoulder will show a similar structure on it (in this case a shpere on a pillar). It even functions by shooting a small red laser at Tactical Missiles, returning them to sender!

[list]
[*]Truly massive scale battles.
[/list]

Up to 8 teams with up to 1,000 units/structures per team, or up to 8,000 in one game, all at the same time. This unit cap can be increased to 2,000 per team and 16,000 in one game with the Lobby Enhancement Mod. Further more, custom made maps can also increase the number of players to a maximum of 12, making the maximum unit/structure count go to a whopping 24,000!

[list]
[*] 4 factions with similar yet unique units and buildings
[/list]

Many units, while similar to one another, can vary so wildyl in combat that they can serve completely different purposes.

One example is the UEF and Cybran battleships. The UEF  battleship's main armaments consist of 3 turrets with 3 cannons per turret. It fires all three cannons per turret at the same time, dealing massive damage. The Cybran battleship's main armaments consist of 2 turrets with 3 cannons per turret. However, it fires only one cannon per turret, resulting in much lower damage, in exchange for much higher rate of fire.

[list]
[*] Strong community and many mods
[/list]

There is still quite a big following playing this game even today. You can find this community on the Forged Alliance Forever (FAF) servers. If I'm not mistaken, downloading the Forged Alliance Forever app will also give you the Sourian AI mod as well as the Lobby Enhancement Mod. Personally, I wouldn't skip these two mods for this game, especially the AI mod if you like to play against computers.

One of my absolute favorite features of FAF is the ability to play the campaign in co-op mode with friends. There are pletny of games being played every day from many players with ranging skill levels. You'll find tournaments and just for fun games alike. You'll also find a nice hand full of custom made maps you can download directly from the Vault in the FAF app.

Cons:

[list]
[*]The unit movement can get a little annoying at times
[/list]

Sometimes they'll get stuck or confused trying to walk around one another, and it can be frustrating, though I find this generally not to be much of an issue.

[list]
[*]The campaign is just okay.
[/list]

You are never forced to try harder to win; you can simply just test yourself on how fast you can do it. You can simply take your time to build up your army before advancing to the next checkpoint.

Playing co-op completely changes the experience for me. I guess I just like playing with friends and family.

[list]
[*]This game is highly CPU intensive.
[/list]

Older and lower tier CPUs simply cannot handle this game on it's maximum scale. Towards the end of matches, and especially longer ones against the computers, you will notice massive slow down in game play. The Sourian AI mod, while also more fun due to being more of a challenge, alleiviates a lot of this issue when compared to standar AI that was programmed into the game. The standard computers tend to build tons, and tons of units and leave them at the base for long periods of time, resulting in less fun, and more CPU usage which results in slower gameplay.

For example, an older rig I used with an AMD FX-6300 played the game just fine with 7 standard AIs, up until the end of the game where it was practically grinding to a halt. It was unplayably slow; roughly 3-4 real time seconds per game second. Now I'm using an Intel i7 4790k with the 7 Sourian AIs and I can easily play games well past the 2 hour mark with 0 slow down, with some head room to spare.

All in all, this game is an absolute blast to play! One of my favorite games that I own.
