It's not often a spiritual sequel lives up to the glory of it's predecessor - Supreme Commander (And this expansion, Forged Alliance), is one of those rare gems.

With it's roots in the masterpiece that was Total Annihilation, Supreme Commander keeps that incredible feel of a glorious RTS with four well-balanced factions, unique units, each with their own checks and balances found among the other factions, mod compatibility, stunning graphics, intuitive but rewarding tech trees, and... The list just goes on. 

When you fight in Supreme Commander, anything can happen. You've begun your siege against the enemy and have an array of missile units; but wait, the enemy has tactical missile defenses, rendering your forces useless! Luckily for you, your chosen battlefield was just in range of your navy, who begin pummeling the shore with their artillery... Until their airborne torpedo bombers are on your radar... Did you bring AA cruisers? Or do you have your own air force in waiting?

This is RTS at it's finest. As one who sunk countless hours into Total Annihilation as a child (and as an adult), this is one game that lives up to the greatness of it's origins, and is an absolute steal at $14.99. Give this one a try, you won't regret it.

And if you're into older games, want to try the predecessor to SupCom, with a soundtrack epicly composed by Jeremy Soule (you may know him from Skyrim, Dungeon Siege, or Guild Wars 2 to name a few), check out Total Annihilation.
Convert now, or fall forever! Join The Supreme Commander: Forged Alliance

The best thing since sliced bread.

Land:

Air:
You got your T1 units. Interceptors, bombers, light gunships, scouts and transports. Great units to take control of the sky, for the beggining of course.
Got your T2 units. Gunships, fighter/bomber, suicides and transports. Great units to deny any ground attack coming your way.

Navel:
You got your T1 Units. Frigates, Submarines, and anti air. Great units to take conrtol of the water and Tech up.
You got Your T2. Got your Destroyers, Cruisers and submarines. Great units to bombared the land from the water at a great distance. Use these units to support you ground and navel
You have your deadly T3 units. Battleships, cruisers and submarines with NUKES!!!!!!!!
Then got experimentals. got your omega submarine too your floating fortress!!

And of course you got your engineers. 

Structures:
Over 50 structures!!!! 50!!! Got you energy, mass, air and ground defences, artilerry, wall sections, troperdo defence, radar, land/air/navel factory and so much more. Even experimental structures. 

Resources: 
Now this is all cool but you cant just build them right away. Whats the fun in that. You got your 2 resources that are the most important thing in the game beside your commander. Let me repeat that, you got your 2 resources that are the most important thing in the game beside your commander!! You have your mass and energy. More you got, the faster you can build and tech up for better troops and structures. If you are low, might want to fix that because your enemy will take advantage of that.

Commander: 
Most important thing in the game. Your commander(Which is you) dies, its game over. Commander has several upgrades. Each fraction has different upgrades on there Com. Gun upgrade, Tech upgrade to stealth. Much that you wil have to find out for your self.

For me this is the best RTS I've ever played. The reasons for this are:
- Epic battles. Thousands of units of different size and shape on land, water and in the air. Battle between huge armies look really massive and epic.
- Great economy model. Buildings receive different bonuses from resource buildings nearby, encouraging you to plan your base's architecture. The game also has build/uprade assistance from constructors and reclamation.
- Micro doesnt play a major role, unlike in Starcrafts and other popular RTS tiles, where the winner is the one who does more clicks per second.
- Fractions seem alike a the first glance, but the small differences in unit's capabilities, like being amphibious, or having a shield, can become a huge advantage if used properly.
- Epic experimental units, capable of defeating small armies alone. They are all different and unique.
- Many small things that make the game comfortable, like building queues/plans, possible building distribution between factories, automated unit transportation from assembly point to te battlefield and many others.

The only reason this game is a little forgotten is it's complexity. To bad it became a disadvantage in modern gaming world.

Supcom will forever hold a place in my heart, as well as whatever disk space it needs.  Everyone has their "top 5 games of all time" list and this will remain on that list for the rest of my gaming life.  Since I first watched it in development to today, I have never stopped trumpeting just how amazing it really is.  I never miss a chance to try and convince every gamer I know to buy it.  I think I have donated at least five copies to my friends just to have them experiance it.

Nearly every RTS before and after have been about just tanks and infantry in small teams... Maybe 100 units at the very most.  Air was usually limited to planes that magically hover in the air and shoot at things until they ran out of ammo, and navy, if present at all, was far less effective than it should really be.  Nuclear weapons and WMD's in Command and Conquer or Starcraft would maybe kill a dozen units and destroy a couple buildings if placed properly.  Nukes in Supcom incinerate everything on the screen, as they absolutly should.

Supcom went beyond the level of being a video game and truly pushing the idea of a simulation.  Much like Steel Battalion or high end flight simulators, this game is less a game than it is an experiance.  High APM click-fests (Starcraft) are lauded as the best of the best in the unfairly small RTS genre, but relied far less on tactics and strategy than they did a small group (or in some cases, an individual unit) winning a single battle which mostly judged the outcome of the game.  Supcom recognized that warfare takes a long time, and even the fastest battles are often an attrition match.  The smallest fights often involve dozens of units on each side, with the largest brawls involving hundreds of tanks, artillery support from a secondary line, dozens of aircraft bombing the ground forces and fighting the other aircraft, and fire support from naval units miles away.  This is why Supcom will always stand out as the premier RTS of all time... it is the only one to recognize that there is more to it than a few tanks at a time... Ground air and sea work in conjunction to support eachother.

If you have never played this game before, you are truly missing out.  It is something that everyone needs to experiance.  There likely will never be anything else like it.  Even for an 8 year old game, it still looks and sounds amazing.  Nothing else has ever truly given the scale of a warfare simulation like Supcom does.  It is however, punishingly difficult to learn.  There is so much nuance to this game, that people often develop a misconception that the races are too similar when they first learn to play.  It isin't until a deep understanding of the game is reached does the vast differences between the factions becomes realized.  Each side has subtle differences that measure not just the raw stats of the units, but the entire playstyle and even the lore-based philosophy of the faction.  

Finally, you can't fanboy this game without mentioning the amazing community of FAF.  It took over running everything when GPG went down.  That so much support exists for a game this old and largely un-mainstream speaks more for it's merits than I ever could.  If you are still unsure of this game being worth checking out, please visit the FAF site at: http://www.faforever.com/

Supreme Commander: Forged Alliance is the type of Real Time Strategy game that plays well with old-school strategy gamers, requiring players to spend hours of sweat, blood, and tears before they can deploy their fleets of lumbering robots against their foe. SC:FA has great tactical depth and fetches a fair amount of complex resource-management and army organization, yet bears enough sheer RTS joy to appease both more casual and hard-core RTS gamers alike. With SC:FA‚Äôs blend of generic alien vs man sci-fi action thrown in with the politics of the previous game‚Äôs 3 human factions, the game also concocts a pretty enjoyable storyline to campaign with. 
The best way, I feel, to evaluate the game is to compare it to the more modern successor, Supreme Commander 2. SC2 has all the trappings of a modern RTS sci-fi product; flying, creeping, and hovering robots of all shapes and sizes zipping around a well sculpted battlefield, brightly colored lasers and missiles flying about under the player‚Äôs direction. Being of the same company and storyline, each game uses the same two resources and the same style of base building (with the usage of shields, turrets, and factories that produce everything from small tanks to submarine-aircraft carriers). The storyline of SC2 isn‚Äôt as important nor as interesting, but what makes both games stand out as frontrunners of the two different RTS genres is the differing styles of tactical gameplay and resource gathering.
Instead of varying sizes of landmasses, such as in SC:FA in which it can take twenty minutes for fuel-thirsty aircraft to reach the end of the map, SC2 possesses much smaller maps, where even the slowest units take no more than five minutes to reach point B. In terms of tactical management, aircrafts of all factions in SC:FA need refueled at specialized staging facilities. This isn‚Äôt relevant in SC2, with aircraft being able to fly over targets and friendly bases indefinitely. Also, a notable difference rests in the building of what is known in both games as ‚Äúexperimental units‚Äù or just unique units that are the culmination of your particular faction‚Äôs military genius (for example, the United Earth Federation‚Äôs Fatboy landship). The Fatboy unit in SC:FA can cross over water, possesses shields and anti-aircraft capabilities, and has very powerful guns, all at the cost of twenty minutes of time. However, in SC2, the Fatboy unit only wields the large guns, with all other abilities missing, giving the unit a much cheaper cost at a three minute production rate. These examples serve to set apart the two different RTS styles; the newer version represents how tactical depth and patience have been replaced by spectacle and awe.
To conclude, if you‚Äôre the type of gamer that likes to spend loads of time setting the pieces up in order to get to the nuclear explosions, then this is the game for you.

I couldn't not. Supreme Commander: Forged Alliance is one of the [i] best [/i] examples of large-scale real-time strategy out there. This game is how I want most RTS games to be, and to be honest, I think most RTS games [i] want [/i] to be SC:FA.

Let's start with the campaign. I won't put any spoilers, but I will list off a few things. Like most RTS games, the focus is not on the campaign but on the gameplay, so don't expect much from the story. One thing I do like is how the main characters of the game interact and talk to you depending on which faction you're playing as. It's a nice touch, however you put it. I can say that the campaign can be fairly challenging your first time around. Enemies can often send powerful units and even experimentals (We'll get to those later) charging at your base without giving you much time to react. This is fun, but can often slow the pace of the game down to a snail's speed if you want to prepare accordingly before the event takes place. I said before that the focus is on gameplay, and even the game agrees with me. When you fail a mission, you have the option of skipping to the next one to see what onslaught awaits you there. Very nice, considering RTS games are not known for their story. The characters are each fairly memorable, but none of them ever seem to have much personality. (Although, I'm not entirely convinced that Fletcher isn't Ben Stiller) It's a futuristic army vs. bigger army simulator, and that's all it wants to be. Frankly, that's all I need it to be.

On to gameplay. I thought it couldn't be done, but somehow SC:FA made it's gameplay even simpler than Dawn of War. Starting with the fact that there are no counters. Most tier II units can destroy tier I units, most tier III units can destroy tier II units, and experimentals decimate everything in their path. Speaking of experimental units, I don't believe I've told you about them yet. Experimentals are a faction's endgame units. They are the biggest and meanest superweapons out there, each more powerful than the next. Heck, there's even one that drops a mega-nuke. Did you know mega-nukes were a thing? Neither did I. In SC:FA, there is no lack of awe-inspiring combat. Seeing massive armies clash on the field of battle sounds epic, doesn't it? Well, how dare you even question the fact that it is so totally unbelievably epic. Shame on you. The resource management is quite unique, and something that I have never seen in a game like this before. Put simply, you have resource intake and resource storage for two primary resources: Mass and Power. The former being your source of unit and structure production, and the latter being to power things like a unit's special ability, or base defenses. While you can construct power generators willy-nilly all over the place, take caution as the bigger generators may provide more power, but they are also incredibly volatile and can wipe out weaker structures in the blink of an eye if they are ever destroyed. Mass on the other hand can only be acquired from certain points which you can build Mass Extractors on. Most of these are scattered about the battlefield, so protecting them may be a pain. Let's say you now have a good intake of Mass and Power and are ready to build some units. Well, each unit or structure will drain you of a certain amount of Mass and Power, the more powerful units often devouring hundreds of each resource. However, if your Mass and Power intake is more than the unit needs, you should be in safe ground and the unit will be produced as normal. If you run out of Mass or Power storage when the unit's drainage is bigger than your Mass or Power intake, your production will slow to something akin to the Heavy spinning up the Brass Beast while being hit by Natascha. Take note that Power has no impact on this, but will disable things like shields if it runs out. I hope at least some of that made sense to you.

Talking graphics, the game doesn't boast anything too great, but looking at the attention to detail on some of the units leaves me feeling impressed.

The soundtrack is meh. That's all I can say. None of the songs are too memorable, at least as far as I can recall. You won't find any Baba Yetu in here, that's for sure.

The multiplayer is dead. But not really. Although there are multiple services that have restored Forged Alliance's multiplayer on their own servers, Rock Paper Shotgun stated that this game is best played with your friends against AI. I don't blame them, because what better parter to help obliterate armies of uncountable size than your best friend?

TL;DR: Supreme Commander: Forged Alliance is excellent at what it does, and doesn't try to be something it's not. I give huge props to this game and it's devs for making it, and may future RTS titles learn from this game for years to come. The RTS genre is dying, and something like SC:FA is just what we need to revive it.

Supreme Commander: Forged Alliance is an RTS classic. Featuring four diverse & unique factions and a massive scope, it is the ultimate evolution of a decade of RTS game development and design. It is frequently on sale for less than ten dollars, which is most certainly worth it.

I have only two complaints. First, don't forget that Supreme Commander was released in 2007. The graphics and gameplay are still immersive, but unfortunately it is not programmed with modern hardware in mind. So while it runs perfectly fine, it is not configured to run on multicore processors and does not benefit from advanced hardware, which can lead to performance issues with thousands of units at once.

The second complaint (a facetious one) is that the commercial and critical success of this game provoked a horrible, dumbed down sequel (Supreme Commander 2).

Also, be sure to check out Forged Alliance Forever, an online community dedicated to the game!

I haven't found another RTS game that I enjoy more than this.  The fast paced battles on large maps (81km x 81km) is not something I've seen in other RTSs.  The ability to zoom in and see the texture of the dirt, then gradually zoom out to see the entire map is a feature that I wish other RTS games had.  Typical rally points on most games offer you the ability to have produced units move to 1 spot after being built... this one lets you setup an entire waypoint system to include being loaded on transports, ferried to a location, then moving from that location and entering combat... and as easy as holding shift while right clicking.
11/10: Would get nuked again!

Ahhhh, Supreme Commander, specifically Forged Alliance. I grew up on several games, this being one of them. It is definitely one of the greatest RTS‚Äôs I have ever seen. Basically, there are two ways one can play this game, rushing or turtling. But when you add that a wide variety of maps, factions, units, tech trees, and complex AI‚Äôs that break your face in with ARMIES UPON ARMIES OF T1 TANKS!?!? It gets pretty darn fun. Graphics are amazing for a game released in 2007, the units mix well with the terrain, and the overlay is perfect. Mechanics are pretty perfect, everything is pretty balanced, and there are plenty of options for stuff in the custom lobby.

Price is perfect, the expansion Forged Alliance is a must get, and it is the TRUE sequel to SupCom, not SupCom 2 made by Square Enix.

A great recommendation, the learning curve may be a slight bit steep, but this game is a must-have for anybody starting an adventure into RTS Games.

When you start out in Forged Alliance it may seem quite overwhelming. However those who conquer the great learning curve will be reworded with the greatest game of all time.  There are many strategic paths to take in Forged Alliance whether it is performing a drop behind enemy lines building bombers and gunships or just out ecoing then and making a giant t4 robot. However there is no guaranteed path to victory.  Every strategy has its counter.  Therefor you must scout and be prepared to counter you opponent as soon as possible. Playing on FAF (forged alliance forever) adds many wonderful features as well whether you are playing vs other fellow gamers or just using the wonderful updates of faf to play vs ai. In the end Forged Alliance is a game that I highly recommend. O and don‚Äôt let the number of hours steam says I have played fool you all my hours are on faf and before that I using a disk.

There are other RTS games that are closer to my heart and that I've had more fun with, but I have to admit that this is probably the best RTS ever made, and still one of the best PvP RTS games to play in 2015 if you install the 3rd party FAF (Forged Alliance Forever) client (requires valid steam or cd copy).

Epic pretty much sums up this game, as you will be amazed by the great designs (looks better than not only all games from the same time period, but most RTS games that were released the next 10 years as well), massive battles, more than enough units and awesome hero (commander) mechanics that make this game playable in two or three completely different ways. The economy system is also slightly different than other games, and challenges you a lot more to play as well as you can, but is also very forgiving if you design it to be (with minimal economic loss).

As long as you play the tutorial it's not very hard getting into the basics of the game, but after a douzen games there might be some things you still haven't figured out and won't either for the next 100 games. Look around, try every button and you will find this game has a lot of good mechanics and features you don't see in a lot of games.

The game engine, however, is slightly limited and if you set the total unit cap too high in games with more than 3-4 players it [b]will[/b] slow down. 75%, 50% or even 20% game speed is common for games of decent size. There's fewer people who have an issue with this than people who don't, but it's worth keeping in mind when you buy the game. To play with 3000 units on the same map you will have to make compromises.

The story is great though, and combined with a multiplayer that will have you playing every map twice or more it would have been worth buying for many times more than what it costs on Steam on full price.

If you have ever enjoyed [b]any[/b] RTS game, you HAVE TO buy this game!

Way back when, I chose the dawn of war games over SupCom. Those DoW games got me into the corresponding tabletop hobby, and I couldnt be happier with the people I've met and all the friends I've made from just buying one little game.

A couple days ago, I spotted this on steam and decided to give it a try, see what I would have gotten had I chose this game instead.

Before I go on, let me explain that I have always loved RTS games. DoW, AoE, Stronghold, C&C, etc. So when I saw this game and the massively positive reviews for it, I bought it straight away! It looked awesome, whole armies crushing your enemies underfoot, whats not to like?

The game worked for me,   only one crash while I was in the tutorial. So no problem there.

The problem was, well, the mechanics. I am used to a minimap, when I play againest my competitive friends, the minimap is needed for survival. The tutorial pointed out pretty quick that my screen IS my minimap. Great.

Not only did I keep forgetting about it, its also extremely awkward to use. I kept playing without using it, making it seem to me that I was alone, when in fact there was a huge battle going on around me, and I couldnt see it.

Secondly, there is a STEEP learning curve. The Controls take way too long to learn and master. I consider myself atleast competent when it comes to RTS's, I can normally figure out the controls in a game or two. 

With this game? Well, you may notice that I only have TWO hours played on it, and also that I've returned it. 

Well, thats because these games take HOURS to play. You can't bang out one game in a hour. Heck no. You have to be willing to SIT THERE and WAIT. Wait for your eco to boost up, wait for your buildings to build, wait for your units to be created. 

Each unit has around a 7-10 second timer. Even the weak units. Yes it has a HUGE pop cap of up to 1000, which is awesome. But for one thing.

I can't get any resources. The game wont give you ANYTHING starting out, and resources come in at a TRICKLE. For my first skirmish game after the tutorial, I tried setting it on huge resources or whatever, and it does not have any. You are stuck with the regular resources, which let me tell you, are gone faster then ice placed in the middle of the sahara desert.


I had to use CHEATS. CHEATS. To explore the mechanics of the game more fully. 

I am not one of those people who can sit down for 4-5 hours on ONE game.  This game is for you if you like slow paced afternoon-length games. If you cant invest the time and effort it takes to play this game, dont buy it. 


I spent two hours with this game. Only played ONE game. And I couldnt even finish it because it got boring using the cheats since it took to long trying to play the game with normal resources and setup.


Poor economy, poor unit build time, confusing map interface,  extremely long length game battles without the resources to easily get said long games off the ground effectively, this is a MASSIVE dissapointment to me.


Buy if your a HARDCORE RTS player who can spend hours in ONE GAME. 

If you like RTS' but dont want to invest hours in a single match, or are new to the genre on a whole, or just a casual gamer, SKIP. 


When I think of the people who might like this game, I think of a old man in his mid 70s.  It requires ALOT of patience. Kudos to anyone who can sit through it, I sure as h*ll cant.


Its like you build a beautiful mansion, but then don't install plumbing or power, and only use one room out of the whole mansion.


Dissapointed, gave it a chance, glad I chose DoW. Skip if you like anything thats not snail-paced.
Still by far one of my favorite strategy games of all time. I will load this up from time to time just to play against the AI.

I am huge fan of the old Total A game, in my opinion ~18yrs on is still one of the best RTS ever.  This one may look better but what I liked about the old TA was the lack of micro management which can plague RTS games.  I liked that you could just cue up a few hundred units in each factory and get straight to the fighting, sure you had to manage resources but it was generally not a primary focus of game play and I found though you couldnt ignore it you wouldn't be spending most of your time focusing on it. 

For me I was hoping for a bit of that same element here in this one but fo me it's good but not as good.  There is somewhat of formula in this one to get started and if you don't follow it (particularly early in a skirmish game) you will constantly be struggling to get on top of your resources.

THQ up to its old tricks again with the spiritual successor to Total Annihalation; Sup Com 1 and Sup Com Forged Alliance are not to be avoided; however Sup Com 2 is to be avoided like the plague. (Dumbed down for the teen market - giant robo t rex with lasers coming out of eyes ffs). When this first came out no one could play it as hardware was not there for the most part; these days though a decent rig will enable you to experience 4v4 with a 1000 unit population cap per player no probs. The economy is identical to Total Annihalation; mass and energy are the only resources you need, the armoured command unit (ACU) is as ever the engine by which you drive your war machine, and units now come in four distinct flavours: tech 1, tech 2, tech 3 and experi(mental) on land, sea and by air. Also the maps range from 5km sq to 96km sq so there is something for everyone in terms of scale; you might like land only maps which are barely large enough to swing a cat, or you may enjoy a naval map the size of a small country. And despite its age it is one of the more aesthetically pleasing games ever produced and still has a large online following on steam. Buy it as it should be pretty cheap these days, but remeber do not touch Sup Com 2, just Sup Com and Sup Com forged alliance please!

This is a super awesome RTS. The economy is really difficult to get a handle on, but once you get used to it, start to see how it all fits together, and then start implementing those newfound skills, it feels immensely rewarding. It also blows balls when a bomber takes out one power generator that's connected to an entire grid of power generators and your entire base goes black, just before a different enemy sends in an experimental unit to wreak havok. But those are also the kind of moments in the game that makes it special. There's something oddly amazing about playing defense, but not so much in terms of using units, but rather resource management to make sure your sheild generators don't drop. 

It feels like a strangely realistic version of over the top sci-fi warfare. On the one hand, you can just spam light units like the Ruskies, or you can focus on developing base defense and researching up to higher-tech units. The crazy thing is that this game doesn't really focus on a "rock-papers-scissors" balancing form, as even if one player has tons of low level units, if an opposing player brings in two experimentals, the other player is essentially screwed. The scale of the maps is big enough for large-scale strategies, and the games are long enough to actually develop them over time. 

It's just... It's unique, and I mean that in a good way.
Incredibly fun with friends.

A complete masterpiece, and the mark of one of the greatest RTS games ever created. If you know your history then you are aware that the RTS genre was very popular from the late 90's to mid 2000's, this is also the time slot when some of the best games in the genre were made, like age of empires 2 and company of heroes. However when it comes to destroying other factions on a massive scale no other game even comes close. With the original supreme commander being good, but not great, and the sequal being a total cash grab by square, this game remains the best in the series and I only wish that creative assembly the strategy giant, would buy the rights to a third game. If you like RTS games like Starcraft, Age of Empires or Rise of Nations, this is along those lines, but with some huge differences that make it unique and absolutely PHENOMENAL. The economy and production is different and takes some getting used to, but adds much more depth and strategy than you get with other games (even though there are only 2 resources!). It's not all about micro and having a zillion APM like Starcraft, but micro still matters and can mean the difference in a match. Cool units, well balanced.

The campaign is no better or worse than you'd get in other games, but I have always preferred skirmish matches in any game. 

You may find the AI is stupid (isn't it in basically all games?) or too difficult, or that there is no acceptable medium between the hard and cheating AI. You should go to forged alliance forever (faforever.com, download the lobby) for the multiplayer, maps, mods and improvements, which help fix this and give you exactly the challenge you want and tons of other cool stuff. Imagine a world dominated by marcos and build orders, and explosions.

Except, with a crapton of robots that obey your every command, and follow it to the very end.  

Now time for me to write a wall of text.

The game offers many unique and cool features for RTS players, who will be in awe at what they have at their disposal to throw at the enemy, AND use to control their massive land armies, navies, and air fleets. The game will give you the ability to ferry units, back and forth. You can set a rally point for your factories on the rally beacon, and have the transports continously transport reinforcements to the front, allowing you to re-allocate your attention to something else. Along with being able to have an efficient transportation system, and basically less of a headache to transport armies to the front. 

You'll also will be enjoying the beautiful destruction the game will provide for you, the AI will pump out armies usually the same order, but will combine all three forces of air, land, and naval. This may result you in pulling your hair out and getting frustrated as your small patrols are no match for the endless swarms of the Hard AI. However, the AI is very easy to beat once getting  the hang of the game, and pumping out your own swarms, or building experimentals and tier 3 units to combat the AI's late game units. Which can easily change the tide of battle into your favor, and keep your interests on the map secured. 

If you don't think land units are your most viable option at the moment, as you need them somewhere else but need to hold a position. Don't be afraid to send a few engineers to set up breastworks and turrets, along with artillery to back them up and your troops. Devastating fire power can also be not delivered via barrel, but through your air squadrons carrying nuclear ordnance to the enemy's main factories, or his commander himself.

Nonetheless, there is ALOT more the game has for you to utilize, and it will give you an enjoyable experience of the RTS genre, and again explosions.

An Awesome game, having played the first game, i wasn't surprised as much by the lack of a learning curve. I just jumped in, got to building and blew the enemy away. 

And by building i mean i took my time, i built formidable bases. Then built me an army and or fleet, to take the first objective, but before taking that i built more armies and or fleets, so i had some left over for when the map expanded. You do not want to get caught without those forces when the final and biggest enemy base finally appears on your map. 

You must take your time and you must fortify your whole base, lack of proper defenses will have the enemy dropship troops onto your doorstep and blow your infra structure to smithereens. Rushing will lead to you being overwhelmed by the forces the enemy had stockpiled. You'll know what i mean once 4 experimentals are marching towards your base and you don't have anything to stop them with. 

The story isn't much, just a little something to hang the action onto, but it's okay.  Visiually it does what is neccesary, allowing vast armies to clash and lovely explosions to cover the field from left to right. I get a blast from seeing nukes going off over the enemies productions centers. 

Special mention should be made of the AI, while not genius level. It did target my radar early on so its attacks would  be more of a surprise, line of sight then being the criteria for a lot of units to shoot despite their range. And it took particular offense to my building the experimental building that would have ended my economic needs. It got bombed conventionally twice as i was building it and actually launched a nuke at it for attempt number three. 

For me, the whole base building and taking my time is what makes, RTS so much fun. Spending two hours a mission is nothing. (for me anyway)

45+ minutes into my first game, and  I accidentally nuke an ally because I didn't know the difference. - Operation Failed, Game Over! - 10/10, would nuke again.

I found that Supreme Commander was such a brilliant game when it was first released i played it over and over again non stop (retail copy then not steam for you trolls who have noticed my game hours are not too great) i loved the commander and how things were built, loved the variety of  ground, air and sea units and loved multiplayer with my mates, however things change.

Firstly the fact the game only uses 1 thread of 1 CPU in your system and as a result as the game goes on it piles where your units are where theirs are, shell trajectorys the AI tactics and so on and so forth into 1 thread so it bottlenecks after a period which in turn later on will slow the game down to every game second takes 3 real seconds, you can get the saurion ai patch to fix this somewhat.

Unit AI more specifically YOUR unit AI, you spend the game not fighting the enemy but fighting your units as ground units will happily try and shell the tank that is behind a hill that they cant hit due to said hill in the way whilst being cleaned up by enemy tanks that have decided to come around the hill until they have line of sight, air units that just sit on the ground and when an enemy plane comes into range will just pick up and land somewhere else instead of engaging, usually when they take they are then destroyed by any fighters the enemy choose to bring with them.  Sea units are just like tanks and will try and shell things that are out of sight.

The commander and anyother building unit can build/capture at range however they like to drive right up to your blueprint or enemy structure before attempting to build or capture, sometimes circling the object until they have found a direction they prefer to face.  Build time is important and building quick is important so any seconds you can save is great but when your commander or engineers fuss about getting into position its very frustrating.

Super units are a great thing to build the hardship of your labours, of getting a good economy going to support building such a massive thing, the satisfaction of being able to survive this long to have built such a device and of corse the joy when it is finally complete and the sense of power that runs through you sends a chill up your spine....... but its short lived.  Super units are just as dumb as everything else in your arsenal if not worse i built a monkey lord from the cybran team and sent him off on his merry down the map just as the enemy team (aion) sent up their sacred assualt bot, now the monkey lord has a sweeping red laser which has a greater range than the laser on the assault bot so i though yeeeessss this should not be a problem and promptly told him to attack their assault bot only for him to walk straight by the bot whilst targeting tech 1 tanks of his own choosing stop when he had walked past it out of range of his laser and turn to try and correct this, obviously this was to late cause as soon as he got in range the assault bot had hit him with his laser during the pass and exploded as he stopped then the assault bot promptly cleaned up my base.

Obviosly this game has been out a while so this review comes late but its just a warning to any people looking at getting this for the first time be prepared to be frustrated beyond belief at controlling one of the dumbest AI's ever in a strategy game, i cant be bothered to even try and defend this.

-Think I am readz to yerg rush the enemy

-Ally gets reked and his base destroyed
-wtf.jpg
-My whole base+army gets destroyed by tier 3 canon boats
-10 out 10

Supreme Commander Forged Alliance starts where the first Supreme Commander ended campaign wise, and sadly just like the original there is no point in paying attention to the story of the game as it is shallow and expectable. The true test of a strategy game is not its story, but its gameplay, and Supreme Commander Forged Alliance more than delivers. The amount of units in every faction from tech one to experimental can actually be overwhelming; surprisingly every unit in the game has its own unique stats and textures that will leave you in awe for hours on. A staple of Supreme Commander is the large scale 1,000 unit battles, and while fun to command such large forces the amount of micro-management is necessary but annoying. A major success Supreme Commander Forged Alliance presents is the balanced multiplayer; all 4 factions (UEF, Aeon, Cybran, and Seraphim) require unique playstyles to utilize the faction's strengths and minimize the faction's weaknesses.
 
First off there is the UEF which are the jack of all trades, but master of none faction. The UEF do however have higher HP than other units, and arguably the strongest tier 1 in the game.

The Cybran Nation's units are the least expensive to construct compared to the other factions' and they have the lowest HP. Their advantages lie in technologies that disrupt enemies. For instance, they have assault bots at tech 1 to disrupt an enemy's early expansion, their tech 3 aircraft have integrated stealth technology, when their Siege Assault Bots are destroyed their cores detonate powerfully releasing an EMP burst that disrupts enemy units, and they have the only mobile stealth field system. This even extends to their experimental units: The Monkeylord is the only experimental unit with a stealth capability. These attributes give the Cybran Nation a wide array of kill strategies.

Aeon units are the most effective in an even fight between equivalent units. Their HP, construction costs, speed and abilities are average, but their weapons are particularly effective. For instance, their tech 2 tanks do more DPS, their tech 3 bombers drop smartbombs that track their targets, and their tech 3 artillery does not stop to deploy stabilizers in order to fire, but also lets them have very good accuracy. The trajectories of their weapons often give them the best effective DPS and initial shot damage.The Aeon also have the best shields after the Seraphim but the highest shield density as the seraphim shields have a very large radius. Their T2 mobile shield generators have the highest shield points. This allows for a task force to be protected whilst engaging the enemy. The Aeon is widely considered to have the best navy. Aeon T1 Light Tanks: Auroras are amphibious giving the Aeon an early naval advantage, Aeon mobile shield generators are also amphibious to support the navy, and Aeon naval units are nearly all more hardy and powerful than the other factions' naval units. They also have the only submersible battleship.

Generally speaking, the Seraphim units are a combination of the UEF and the Aeon--they have a mixture of multi-purpose units and specialized units. Their units usually have the second highest HP and construction costs. Like the Aeon, a few of these units can hover, thereby avoiding the danger of torpedoes and having the advantage of being able to travel across water. In terms of equivalent units, the Seraphim carry units with high HP, high construction costs, and appreciable weapon damage and ROF. They excel in terms of land and naval units (the author can confirm killing a UEF destroyer using 5 T1 submarines without losing a single submarine), but have average air units. If the UEF/Cybran have the best land units, and if the Aeon have the best air units, the Seraphim follows by a close second on both of these. The most obvious advantage the Seraphim holds is their shields. The Seraphim is the only faction to have a T3 Mobile Shield Generator: Athanah, and both Seraphim stationary shield generators have more health and a larger radius, but at a higher cost. The Seraphim's navy in some cases exceeds that of the Aeon due to the fact that they have a T3 submarine hunter which can be used to destroy any submerged unit and has advanced torpedo defences, T3 mobile shield generators can protect a naval group easily due to their high shield points and radius. The T3 battleship is a mobile strategic missile launcher allowing for sneak attacks from different locations. The Seraphim's T2 destroyer is submersible allowing it to act as a T2 submarine as its torpedoes and torpedo defences are superior to any other factions T2 destroyers. An extension of the Seraphim navy is their naval defences which are equipped with torpedo defences which allows them to outlast any equivalent turret from the other factions apart from the Cybran's T3 submerged torpedo turret. The Seraphim Anti-Air turrets have been considered to be the worst around, but a T2 cruiser: Ithalua, having tremendous DPS for air units, is almost a compensation for this. From an aesthetic standpoint, the Seraphim take an even more extreme approach to unit design than the Aeon, especially considering their assymetrical designs. Seraphim units are generally smoother and more elegant in appearance, with few jagged angles. Their units sport a chrome-like finish, adding to the alien appearance. Like the Aeon, the Seraphim employ unusual and alien weaponry, including the Heavy Quarnon Cannon, the Uall Cavitation Torpedo, and the Olaris AA Artillery Cannon.

Overrall Supreme Commander Forged Alliance is one of the best strategy games of all time, and will always be a benchmark in the strategy genre. The game is unique, interesting, challenging, great gameplay, and a small, but active online community to have fun with.

The only drawback to Supreme Commander Forged Alliance is its learning curve. The game takes a few hours to learn, but that is expected of a comprehensive strategy game such as Supreme Commander Forged Alliance.

When I was younger, I got the original SupCom for the xbox (scrub that i was): the controls weren't that great, the unit count was miniscule, and I jsut couldn't understand the game as it was. When I bought it here alongside FA, I was pleasantly surprised, it was far better than what I remembered it as, the unit count is astonishing, and the physics incredible. The very fact that it was possible for a nuclear missile to be stopped by a plane flying into it by accident and could change the tide of a match blew my mind (in more ways than one, my ACU was killed by the blast).  As well as the realistic and unique physics, the experimental units of this game (incredibly expensive yet powerful units) seem to incite fear in every mans heart when they appear on your radar, especially if you were expecting to be attacked from a completely different angle of your base, with all your defences stacked right in that one spot, helpless to prevent your destruction.
 The scale of the game is stunning- especially for a game made in 2007, with the camera able to pan the whole way from a sort of global view right down to the trees littering the landscape, units can leave behind treadmarks and ripples in their wake when on the move, or burnt out shells when they are stopped permanently.  A further detail that interests me about this game is that the burnt out shells can be harvested for resources - it makes winning each little skirmish all the more satisfying as you can melt down your opponents losses and use them to make more units of your own. 

    I would recommend this game if you enjoy admiring the full scale of war and strategy, or just want to watch the world burn from the wrath of your armies.  (Just keep your base defended, and your eyes peeled, and hope that yor foes haven't built any nukes yet.)
5/5 I do recommend .... Why ? .... Because you have to feel the real taste of the RTS !
lol greatest rts

This is a significant upgrade to the SupCom engine, making everything appear much more polished and smoother, especially with fog of war. Along with balance changes and new units, it's like a whole new game, rather than an expansion. My favorite part of this game is how it offers a mesmerising view of a futuristic battlefield. How it allows you to zoom up, watch individual parts of an unit move and fire true projectiles. That might not seem to be not that special, but the level of amusement I get when I see projectiles hit things they're not supposed to hit is goofy high. I can spend hours zoomed in just to watch the animations of units, even small things like energy storage growing taller as more energy is stored, and how engineers tilt their wheels to float on the water. I wish every game had strategic zoom like this game, with such polished visuals. 

The user interface is still rather basic, but much improved over the original, giving you much more space to see the battlefield. It requires 3rd party add-ons (UI mods) to allow things such as keybind remapping, to display health bars all the time, managing templates easier, and upgrade helpers. I highly recommend at least getting GAZ_UI (I used version 6.1). I had to adjust my build order with the changes that took place, such as starting with a factory first. It wasn't until FA that I seriously started to look at deciphering all the + and - numbers on everything, and learning how to balance energy income with mass income, depending on what I wanted to build. A lot of reading tooltips, looking at unit stats in the unit database web page, and a bit of math helped me out, which is akin to doing spreadsheets. 

This game seems to love Intel processors, or those with great "single-thread" performance. Playing on a laptop or AMD CPU will result in some slow-mo action before the end. Even if you have a good CPU, playing in a game with another with a slow CPU can make it agonizingly slow for you, especially if you're used to it being faster. The game doesn't run smoothly at full speed if there's someone else in your game with a poor or unreliable connection as well. I felt like I couldn't play big 8 player games with air battles and 1000 unit cap, until I got my PC upgraded (from AMD X3 720 to i2600k). 

The gameplay itself is a handful. It's a challenge to multi-task. The objective is simple, to destroy the enemy commander, but achieving it is another story. You should manage to progress your economy, never settling with a certain amount as "enough", and considering how there's 3 tech levels of it and the hugeness of how maps are, you quickly find out how difficult it is to keep track of anything spread out. Staying compact will allow you to progress through tech at a manageable pace, but this is not an ideal way to achieve victory. Until you get used to things, to the point they become subconscious actions, your strategies will be extremely limited. I resorted to gambling with basic strategies, such as building up dozens of tanks, outnumbering the enemy, and using an upgraded commander to spearhead the assault, looking to surround the enemy commander. At first it was successful, but as maps get bigger and enemy teams get more members, this becomes less effective. Using a dozen tech 2 bombers or gunships to just simply fly in and bomb the enemy commander was a gamble that was easily countered by a shield and a few flak units. Once I got the hang of quickly upgrade my mass, I tried getting out an experimental as quickly as possible, but this strat could be beaten by a zerg rush. Sneaking a T3 commander with a transport as soon as possible was a huge gamble, but seemingly was the only strat that worked if I could land it where I wanted, without endless practice in other parts of the game. 

Multiplayer is still barely alive. I was able to register my product serial on Steam to play there, but a competing 3rd party lobby seems to be sucking players away with its advertising. If you choose to play multiplayer on that other lobby, "FAF", I hope you have thick skin and have great luck! I'd describe it as being an active volcano. Be extra cautious and watch out for eruptions. Go in with low expectations, else you may be disappointed, as their advertisements are clearly biased. They lose as many users as they get new ones, due to how toxic and unwelcoming they can be to some, especially those who go in expecting too much. Stick it out and endure the frustration and you'll be able to play one of the most noteworthy RTS games with some actual players. 

After playing this, I haven't found another RTS that has impressed me enough. SupCom2 was okay for a short while, fixing some issues I had with Forged Alliance, but was not close to being a FA killer, since it just didn't have the same scale and felt cheapened overall, such as with the cheesy sound effects (ex. commander explosion) and Aeon unit names that sounded cheap and unoriginal. I can't wait for a real update to SC:FA.

TL: DR- 10/10, literally one of the three best strategy games i've ever played, and probably the best RTS.

This game can have a steep learning curve, and campaign missions may well take you two hours to complete if you go carefully, or twice that if you go full defensive on the hardest difficulty setting, but this just means that there's actually meaning to good base design, and it is incredibly satisfying to build up an impenetrable fortress then create an army that will flatten your opponent... hopefully. Then there's also the option of building so many nuclear launch facilities that you can overwhelm your enemy's missile defense systems and drown them in nuclear fire (for reference, nukes in this game are just about the hardest to obtain in any game i've found, but they're also the most visually spectacular and you actually have cause to fear them)

There is a good variety of options for the skirmish mode, you can put yourself in a cagefight with a trio of AI opponents that cheat just for added difficulty, you can customise some major gamemode settings such as completely disallowing certain units or tech-levels, or you can increase the rate at which everyone gathers resources to speed the game up a bit.

The graphics are very nice, especially considering the number if units you will have running around the map at any given time. the textures don't look that great if you were to zoom all the way in, but if you do that you'll zoom out again to find that OH GOD THE CYBRAN HAD A BUNCH OF STEALTHED MONKEYLORDS OUTSIDE MY BASE AND THEY'RE TRAMPLING MY REACTORS!

However, the place this game really outshines anything else i've played is its interface. you can customise so easily what the map shows you in terms of the range of your anti-air, anti ground, indirect fire, etc, your sonar, radar, omnisensor ranges... it offers you so much information but if you're finding it overwhelming you can just switch it all of with about two clicks.
Unit control is so good in this game, in terms of automation. you can very reasonably set up a factory to produce infinite of a set of units, have air transports pick them up from your base, and airdrop into a different part of the map with no input from the player. this makes managing hundreds (or, with mods, thousands) of units so much eaiser, leaving you to direct your army, navy and airforce, and watch the explosions.

Man this one is better than SC2 to be honest ^.^

Quite possibly one of the best RTS games I have played in my life. The mechanics are impeccable, gameplay is tight, and the single-player doesn't disappoint too much. The concept of focused engineering and streaming economies is very cool, and I put many, many hours into this game. 

Be warned that there is a learning curve if you have played other RTS games before, but the tutorial section does a good job of explaining the basics. The single-player campaign is a very good way to learn the basics, as the deck isn't really stacked that badly against the users. That said, you can amp up the challenge in Skirmish matches by picking AI templates that can cheat (which is also an amazing feature)

It being 2014, the graphics now look a little dated (especially textures) but it still remains one of the best-looking RTS games of its time, and still manages to look pretty good. The user interface manages to be very comprehensive out of the box, but can be made more minimal if needed. The UI also presents more features (visibility, command, etc) than I have seen in other RTS franchises. I am seriously never going back to Starcraft!

The downside to all these features is the complexity (and the learning curve mentioned above) but those are all quite easily manageable. There is a very helpful WIki for those looking to really plan out their games. I'll finish by saying that if you like traditional RTS games, you'll be in for an awakening!

10/10 A catergorised review for easy reading

Zoom
The strategic zoom alone is multiple steps ahead of other RTS's which seems insignificant but theres really no going back...

Tech and Research
As with most RTS style games there are technology levels (3 with an experimental level as number 4) with multiple races (4 in this game), then there is an economy stucture based on Mass (harder to aquire) and Energy (easier to build).

Units/Maps
All units (aside from Commanders) are robotic and large in size which helps to accomodate for the large maps. They range from 80km by 80km to 5km by 5km. Unit limits are adjustible but can go up to 1000 without mods

Combat types
Forms of direct combat range from space with satelites (but only ground fire with them), land combat, naval combat (including subermrines) and air combat. commanders are also capable of teleporting to destinations.

Mods etc
The game comes with some mods built in that you can turn on or off as you please. On top of this there is a strong modding community which has made many types of mods and mappacks for the game

Servers
The game has three online platforms to play on GPG been the original (they have run out of money and no longer exist) steam has a platform to play off and hosts the game as it was meant to be, FAF also are a player supported platform that is the largest in use with players across world using it (it is not all originall).

Overall
A very fun game with a strong player community (enough so that they have set up a player supported platform through donations to play on).

This is quite simply the best RTS game there is to date, period. If you are wondering on what to choose from this version from Supreme comander 2, choose this one, it is far better than Supreme Comader 2. However, take these into consideration...

Pros:
-Intense scenes of battle and tons of infantry options (tanks, ships, air and uprgrades)

-Custom maps and mod support
-Stratigically hard and makes you think about your next move

Cons:
-Hard to grasp for new players (very nice and easy tut in-game though)
-Resource gathering is a little bit harder than the original game
-Long wars that seem to never have an end (my record, 4 hours of non-stop playing, which isnt that bad)

-no multiplayer with random people (you will have to find a friend to play with because there just isnt anyone on)

Overall, its a kick ass game and i love it. Nukes, secret bases and stratigic base installments are key to success, while also trying to maintain a good economy (i.e. mass and energy plants to fuel your army).

Whenever someone asks me "What is your favourite RTS of all time?", I splash in their faces this absolute beauty of a game.
Sure, when I first started, I had no clue what to do, but as with every other game, it's a challenge, an adventure, and by god is this game one giant adventure filled with massive armies clashing and nukes exloding left and right. Heck, this game has more explosions than a Michael Bay film. The four, when I say four I really mean 3+1, tech levels in this game need to be brought out at pinpoint moments in the game, if not, you'll just lose since your enemy has more T1 Light Assault Bots than you even though you have five T2 tanks. The best part about this is that everything has been moved to the community since GPG basically died off after SupCom 2. Forged Alliance Forever is the greatest community driven project I have ever seen in my entire life. Mods after mods after mods and a matchmaking system that ACTUALLY WORKS.
Summary of Forged Alliance Forever: Tired of playing ranked matches and losing every single time? Find a lobby with a huge load of mods (or create your own) and fight people in massive wars with stupid, stupid amounts of resources. Tired of THAT? Play the original Forged Alliance Campaign with the same mods! Heck, Forged Alliance Forever even includes the original SupCom campaign (You have to own SupCom 1 first obviously) but with the same improvements, unit additions, improvements and mods that are run and can be run on Forged Alliance forever.

Final Verdict: This has been my most favourite Real-Time-Strategy in the world. Not even Planetary Annihilation can compare to this. Not enough depth I feel. Thus, this game gets a full 10/10 from me. Seriously, if you haven't bought this and downloaded FAF yet, DO IT NOW OR I WILL HATE YOU.

I first stumbled upon Supreme Commander when it come in a glorious steam bundle filled with big name titles. I owned the game for nearly 3 months before actually playing playing it. (You know how it is.) Never heard of Supreme Commander or the series and passed it off as a generic knock off from Command and Conquer. WOW I WAS WRONG. SC and SC: FA are 2 of the most underrated RTS games I have ever had the privledge of playing. The progressive scaling of units and map size where hundreds of units engage in epic land, air, and sea warfare is something very few RTS games get right. NIce blend between theoretical technology and pre existing war machines with armaments that can be found in armed forces around the world.  But what impresses me the most is how smooth the games run, even when 2000 units are "in play." The interface is very polished and easy to navigate. Simply scorlling the mouse wheel immediately zooms into full view of the map where units are displayed by icons instead of smaller models, allowing for fluid macro play even when your 3 bases are scattered across the map. Has all the elements that one would want in an RTS which include but are not limited to:

4 playable factions. All with their own unique flavor and yet are still balanced.
4 Tier(s) of technology and units that are EPIC when engaged in combat. 
A challenging campaign with 8 missions that can last between 1 and 5 hours. (5 if you're like me and enjoy building more automated base defenses.  
Incredibly fluid gameplay that is challenging and rewarding.
And finally it is quality mental exercise when you've got 10 macro'd unit groups and several dozen unit production buildings gaurding your commander against endless waves of enemy units that often have an unfair advantage. 

If you're a true pc game elitist and you enjoy games of strategy that are aesethically pleasing then definitely grab SC and SC: FA next time you get a chance. 

PS - could care less about any grammar or spelling oversights. (Its a steam review that no one will read anyways.)
PSS - Do not buy Supreme commander 2 unless you are a HUGE fan of the serious. Square Enix produced the 2nd installment and completely re modeled all of the units and maps and turned it into shallow, brightly colored, and insignificant shells of their former counter parts.

A realist game that closely simulate the World War 1(Tech 1), World War 2 (Tech 2) and Cold War (Tech 3) warfare technology, tactical and stratrgic combat in a fictional world. A lot of micro managing skill is needed here.

Highlights:
- Realistic Air Superiority and Naval Supremecy than other RTS.
- Fighter and bomber from every world war era.
- Long range bombardment (artillary)
- Missile and anti missile. (tactical)
- Nuclear missile and anti nuclear missile. (strategic)
- Radar concept that can only see bogey signature. Advance radar that can identify signature or even see stealth (radar) or clock (visibility). Radar is nesessary to improve the reaction of units. Your turret would point toward the incoming threats before they even start firing.
- Experimental Unit, unit that take so long to build (might take you 30 minute to 60 minute to build and defend, but upon completion will unleash hell onto your enemy).
- Inteligence/covert operation to know what your enemy are up to.
- Shield (yeah !!)
- Resource management and strategic implication.

If your looking for an awesome RTS game to curb your boredom, then look no further, Forged Alliance is my favorite RTS game to date and the fact that I have over 500 hours on record, should be good enough for me to write my own review of the game. I'm not sure I can express how much fun it is to play Supreme Commander: Forged Alliance, but I'll try anyway. I like to take my time when playing, just to make sure I have enough fire power to overwhelm my enemies, even when I'm challenging my friends, but they make me work for it so it's a fun experience overall.

If you've got the specs to run the game, I guarantee that you will love playing it for hours everyday. I know I do and even though you go through the same thing every time when going through campaign, it's still fun and makes great practice to further develop your skills. I've played this game for years and it never fails to curb my boredom. In the beginning of the campaign, you choose the level of difficulty: Easy, Medium or Hard (Do not choose hard if your just starting out, you will get owned within the first 30 minutes of starting the campaign.) When it's time, you'll choose your faction: UEF, Aeon or Cybran. Just remember that each faction has a particular strength that the other factions either can't do or do better, but also remember that you can repeat the campaign as many times as you want and you can play throught it with all 3 factions.

You can even choose to skirmish your friends or Computer AI's or both and with the AI's having different levels of skill, you'll probably have your work cut out for you. If you dare choose one of the hard difficulties, let's see if you can adapt when the AI is sending experimentals your way every few minutes among the other possible waves of units. My advice, build up a strong defense and make sure you can hold the line long enough to turn the tide.

There is also multiplayer for anyone who just wants to challenge their friends to an all out fight or you can choose to fight in teams. Let's see if any of you have what it takes to reign supreme, but no matter how it ends, you'll all have fun doing it.

Good luck to you all who are just starting out and just try to have fun.

It is ~10,000 members strong, with a competition ladder, up to 6v6 custom matches, a dozen+ mods, galactic war, the campaigns of SupCom and Forged Alliance redone to allow up to 4 player co-op, and more. Hands down the best RTS game available. This game really does things right by focusing on the obliteration of your opponents through sheer force of strength and easy economy management. Don't like the tediousness of micro-managing your economy and just want to throw hundreds of units constantly at each other? Are you annoyed that you have to wait until you have resources stockpiled before you can build units? Want to build massive units to wipe your enemies off the face of the earth? Do you enjoy being able to specialize in either land, air, or naval units, or use combinations of each? This game is what you're looking for. 

Now the only question is, what are you waiting for?

Fordged Alliance Forever!

Spiritual succesor to Total Annihilatoin they said. Well I agree but there are a couple of things that still make the original TA a better game. For starters SupCom takes a LONG time to get a base up and running at maximum efficiency with multiple factories churning out tanks and bots, and the problem is that the AI immediately begins attacking you fom the start so unless you repel the first rush properly and you are able to repel each subsequent attack on your position, because by the time you have dealt with the first the second is often already on the way, then you are screwed. 

The maps are much larger which makes for more epic combat and I must say this is a good thing. You can play with more than 4 players on one map as opposed to TA and that is also good. There are three tech levels instead of two and the ability to customize your commander unit which is also pretty cool but beware that upgrading takes much MUCH more ressources, easily exponential amounts which means if your ressources infrastructures are not ready your facotories will simply stop producing. This is what I had the most trouble with in this game whereas in TA I always got the upper hand on the ressource situation I have a very difficult time maintaining my production in this game because of how expensive good units are. Producing masses of tech one level units is simplky not worht it because a tech two unit can easily outmatch upwards of a dozen tech one units and so on for a tech three unit. 

Furthermore on the ressource issue, the AI methodically targets your ressource infrastucture before even targetting defensive turrets at times which simply adds to the trouble of collecting enough ressources to maintain production. This is not a complaint in itself just somkething that adds to my troubles with the game.

All in all this game is very good though if you liked TA just don't expect it to be a revamped reworked version of the 1997 classic because this game has a flavour all of its own. Epic battles await and Nukes are awesome in this game.

Where to start? Supreme Commander is in one word: MASSIVE. You can set a cap of 8000 units on the battlefield, so if you have a 1v1, each player can have 4000 units. FOUR-F******-THOUSAND. At 8 players (teams don't have to be fair) each player has a thousand troops. I have seen people compare this game to Starcraft with 200 units at the max per player. Some people like the extreme tactics that game has, this game has them too, except on a bigger scale. Let me show you a quick comparison

Airdrops: 
Starcaft: Drop 16 marines in 2 medivacs.
Supreme Commader: Drop 20 units in 1 transport.
Armies
Starcraft: A marine/marauder deathball slaughtering zerglings or a zealot rush
Supreme Commander: A 300 strong army supported by experimentals holds off the main force, as battleships and carriers support the army, then on the over side of the map 5 nuclear subs nuke the enemy base as an airdrop composed of 150 units flanks the main force. (And that is on a 1000 units per team)
Nukes: (I know that it's only a lesser part of Starcraft, but it is quite big in the end game of Supreme Commander)
Starcraft: A Nuke won't destroy the main base building, it's mainly for clearing armies or finishing off bases
Supreme Commander: When you usually send nukes, you send 5 or more. Depending on nuke defences the attack might fail but when it hits, it hits. A nuke will wipe a base.
Defence
Starcraft: SC is about the offensive and manuevering, you defend to hold the army off as a bigger force flanks.
Supreme Commander: If you have ever played Halo Reach, on the desert mission where you need to destroy the AA towers, at the end there is a massive Spire. Imagine that but around the spire there is about 50 gatling guns and AA turrets. Also (most games don't have this) you CAN build WALLS. (I know it's amazing)

While I personally like this feature of this game, some peope disagree. There are NO hard counters. (Well yes, the tech 2  UEF flak turret tank will easily  wipe out tech 2 planes and even take on tech 3 planes. And yes, the experimentals are basically hard counters for everything they can target, and the air vs air planes will SLAUGHTER EVERYONE WHO FLIES.) But mostly a tech 3 robot will not have an advantage over a tech 3 tank or vise verca.  And although all the factions look different and have different units, they are mostly the same. The main differences are: some factions unlock different units earlier. eg the Aeon unlock have a tech 1 attack boat. And the experimentals; each faction has 3 or 4 different experimental units.  The graphics are not Starcraft level, but they are still REALLY good.

I would reccomend getting Supreme Commander: Forged Alliance and "Forged Alliance Forever".A free community hub for SC: Forged Alliance, it includes "The Vault" from where you can download custom maps and mods (All free). And it is only place for online play. The campaign is really solid and stands on its feet, but the main focus is on multiplayer.

There really is no game to compare this to. It is a RTS, it is not a 4X RTS. Yet it's more than a normal RTS. I would call it a quarter of its way to a 4X RTS. The game is really easy to get into, but it's a lot like Starcraft where you need to spend time playing it to get good. On a last note: you play other games to feel like you command an army or a small force. You play this game to feel like you command you command EVERYTHING. Much like the Emperor in 40K. Remember to get Forged Alliance Forever. Also don't get Supreme Commander 2, it sucks 

Also UEF for the win.

In my opinion, Forged Alliance can only be described as one of the best Real-Time RTS games of its type. Despite its age it still looks modern with high graphics settings and the addition of a 4th race to the game expands the gameplay possibility compared to the original. However the best thing about this game is the loyal community that continue support of the game with new updates and balance changes through the Forged Alliance Forever (FAF) Lobby after support for the game ceased. FAF provides the essential multiplayer this game absolutly thrives on, the game is still very competitive through the multiplayer and therefore I can also recommend Forged Alliance to seasoned veterans of the RTS genre. The game has quite a steep learning curve though and the fact that there can be 1000s of units on the battlefield means that the game can be laggy unless you have a good computer. Despite this, I think it is a brilliant title that is definitly worth your time if you have any interest whatsoever in the genre, especially as this part of the genre has very little competition.

Obviously based on the other reviews, you already probably know this game is incredibly excellent.  So instead of reviewing it, I'll just say that the things that blow me away every time I play this is the detail, economy and graphics.  The detail lays in the fact that every class of military unit (air, naval, land) has a factory which produces it, and each of those factories can be upgraded up to three times, and will enable you to produce new units (as well as old) with each upgrade.  This alone, and not even considering the complex and amazing ways these units can interact with each other, sets this game automatically in a league by itself in comparison to most other RTS games where you level up your entire civilization with a click of a single button and the lapsing of a single timer.  In SCFA, if your T3 factories go down and you haven't upgraded your commander, you start right back at the beginning.

Secondly economy.  Two resources.  So simple!  So deceivingly simple.  I have never cursed or praised the accompanying deficit/surplus of a resource before, and the clever surplus resource sharing mechanics with allies is something I have never seen before or since, and can lead to some shocking revelations about the state of your own economy as your ally's base takes a beating by the enemy.

Third, this is a beautiful game.  This seems incredible to say considering it is years old and I have played cutting edge games on my 2014 mid to upper range gaming rig to compare it to.  But despite the huge maps and environments, it contains incredible detail on many of the units (UEF engineers will flip their treads down when going into water, for example) and the textures just look plain beautiful.  Zoom out to see the entire map and the coloured icons representing entire armies, or zoom in so that you are just metres away from the surface to see two units duel to the death, and you will have an equally satisfying eye-candy experience.

Final verdict, best RTS I have ever played, and certainly one of the most impressive video games period.

Originally Supreme Commander came out and was widely praised despite a few major flaws. The game came from the creators frustration on modern RTS games and felt they were tactical and not stratigic. So they solved this by increasing the scale and having an incredible phyics engine that even calculates each shot so planes could get hit by artillary in theory. Another prodominate feature was having extrmely large "experemental" units and a flow econemy.Major issues were the extreme power needed and the fact that turtling was overpowerd.

Forged Allaince then came with wonderful fixes in the term of new units, and making turtling for the most part unviable. To this day if you play on large multiplayer maps, you can still have prossesing power issues despit the fact it came out almost 7 years ago.

Then came the abortion that is Supreme Commander 2. It destroyed the tech trees and took away the flow econemy that made supreme commander unique. When it took away the flow econemy , experemental units had to become cheaper to be usuable and as a result arn't the entire army killers they were in all the prevous games. Combined with many other poor desitions have left many players dissapointed. Combined with very very poor multiplayer support most players flocked to Forged Allaince Forever which are servers and a lobby for Forged Allaince run by a community. They have made significant changes to SupCom2 but for all intents and purposes is a dead player base.

This game relies on you loving the massive scale of the war and for people who want stragegy games without the rock paper scisor style contering being the most important factor and rather have importance on flanks and cleaver drops while creating forward bases and intelegence. Forged Allaince Forever is still being updated to this day and has a still GROWING community. I highly recomend that anyone who buys this to get Forged Alliance Forever too(Its free).
Go FAF !

I can't think of any RTS that allows you to direct your troops in this much detail. Screw formations and all that I was expecting, you can lay out how the tanks will take over the bay, all while laying out how the airplanes will circle the enemy base, drop precise strikes and return, and have ships patrol the area. Some of my patrol routes, scouting and attack patterns got so complex and so beautiful to look at it's pure joy. Very useful, very intuitive, don't underestimate that tool!

Also, the map is awesome. Yeah for once an RTS got the map right, you zoom in and out of your view, and if you zoom out far enough, units and buildings become points, like on a map, and it all becomes a large, interactive, tactical playground. My favorite RTS, featuring huge-scale battles and a very interesting resource system. 

Note that you don't need to buy the base game unless you want its campaign, which isn't worth $15. Just buy Forged Alliance and you'll be set.

If you like war in a MASSIVE scale, then this is your game.  You are the central unit, a Commander, and you spawn in to a map pitted against other Commanders of four different factions.

You must decide the best balance between land, sea, air while carefully managing your resources while denying resources to the other commanders.  The war starts on a small scale with tier 1 units, which are cheap to produce but essential for locking down resources and harassing the enemy early.  The war escalates to tier 2 units which pose a threat directly to an unprotected Commander and butcher tier 1 units.  At this level you will start to see energy shielding, artillery, heavy fortifications and tactical missile strikes.  When (or if) the war reaches tier 3 it's now a high-stakes game of survival.  Every normal unit is a beast compared to the previous tier and the big guns start to come out: Heavy artillery and nuclear missiles, which can devistate entire sections of the map and easily kill a Commander.  Once experimental units hit the field everything changes.  They are nearly unstoppable by conventional units and an inattentive Commander who has let one lumber to their base's gates is moments from defeat.

This game is a bit taxing on older machines, but the sheer scale of the war is unlike any other game out there.  I've put many many hours in to this game and was delighted to see it come to Steam.  A good buy, in my opinion.

This is one of the greatest RTS games ever made. Extremely detalied, down to the rotating turrets and guns on every single unit. Don't fall for Supreme Commander 2, it is crap.
