Just a shame it's badly programmed... even on top-notch I7's (3610QM & 4700MQ, no extreme overclocked sh**) it causes a pretty heavy load (Full load on 2 cores often), and when playing with a lot of AI's the game can even freeze up. I have no idea how anyone would play this with a 1.8 Ghz processor, which the requirements state.... Probably only possible with a resolution of 320x240.

Also the requirements state like "1 GB RAM", well even with 8 GB RAM you still can run into low memory warnings, which is a bug, because there is always 2GB+ RAM still free... it seems this is much more likely to happen when having a resolution of 1920x1080, because I suppose the game has to allocate more memory for the bigger textures.
Whenever you get these low memory warnings, at any given moment your game could just crash, it can mess up your desktop. Meaning you have to reboot your computer by force. (Or if you are not the average person, open up the CMD blindly, and kill the process)

But with some tools like Core Maximizer and Large Address Aware the game runs a lot better.

Multiplayer is very nice in this game, no annoying lag, and there are enough configuration options for all the maps.

Maybe i've said some bad things about this game in the review, but it's definitely worth the money! No doubt!!!
You will love this game, Skirmish mode rocks.

Graphics 8/10 Very good graphics, especially for it's time, turn on Bloom, and the game looks much better, or download shaders. Of course we're not comparing this to games from 2014.
Audio 9/10 Nice sound effects, like the artillary cannons, or from experimentals
Performance 6/10 Like I said, you need a pretty fancy computer to run this game, with ATLEAST medium graphics, and a resolution bigger than 800x600, a 1.8 Ghz CPU and GPU with 128 MB VRAM ain't going to do the job.
Use the tools provided by the community to make the game run much smoother!

This... Is RTS Genius. Every RTS should be judged by this game. This is probably, In my opinion (And many others) The BEST RTS game ever made. I am not saying this lightly. Take word from a person who loves strategy and is a die hard fan for it. Where to start, Well I should go over the races first. This game takes a bit step upward from other RTS genres out there and includes, not 2, or 3, but 4 unique factions. You have the UEF, Aeon, Cybran, And My favorite. The Seraphim. Each race has a very unique backstory, and the lore is fantastic. But to simplify the factions for you. UEF are your standard Humans. Cybrans are  a cyborg like race. Aeons are an humaniod alien race. And the lizard-like Seraphims are trying to destroy all of them. But lore is not the only thing that it offers. A fantastic gameplay that makes you feel like a commander. You can zoom out to a satelite veiw, and see the whole battlefield, Which is usefull since the maps in this game, can range from 10km to 80km. So the maps are a site to see. Each race has their own set of unique units. Ranging from light assualt walkers, all the way up to a towering expiremental bomber, that drops mini-nukes. The unique aspect of this game that i find the most fun. Is that you are in an ACU. And you are in the battlefield. You can customize your ACU to fit your strategies, Ranging from Defense to offense. Your ACU is also equiped with a engineering suite, which allows you to build structures as well. I could go on about this game. But words alone cannot describe how awesome this game is. I STRONGLY recommend this game to all strategy lovers out there. This is worth every penny, but be sure to get the original supreme commander along with it, since you will not be able to play as UEF, Aeon, or Cybran in multiplayer. however you can in skirmish.

Most likely the best macro RTS out there, and by very far my favorite. If you've ever played (and liked) Total Annihilation, you'll feel right at home playing this, although the economy system is a lot more detailed despite also being split into mass and energy production, as well as allowing many buildings to upghrade themselves. It also uses a commander, which can be upgraded to fill many different roles, from a powerful builder to a teleporting stealth assassin to a mobile nuclear missile platform! 

The regular gameplay is divided into 3 Tech levels of land, air and naval units complemented with poweful experimental tech which is commonly called tech 4, such as giant assault robots, mobile factories, giant bombers and (rap[id fire) artillery cannons as well as an infinite resource production plant for almost unlimited tactical variation. 

Using Forged Alliance Forever (Player created matchmaking client) you can still play online with up to 12 people in the regular system and it has all kinds of awesome mods available such as playing the campaigns in coop as well. Probably the most awesome thing about the FAF system is that there is a living competitive scene even this long after it was released, and there are still very frequent balance changes to keep the game fresh. In the last official patch the Seraphim (last added race) feel quite overpowered, but in FAF this problem does not exist, and even if a specific unit is deemed too strong, it can look forward to being rebalanced, which is done by having the community suggest changes which are then tested and scrutinized by the best players and newbies alike, which is more awesome than any currently still officially supported game out there!

There has yet to be a moment where there is not at least 50 people of all kinds of skill levels online. Pick it up if you don't have it yet, because you're missing out on an amazing game!

It's a shame that almost no current RTS games could come close to how good this game is. Massively scaled at 2000 unitcap. You would usually expect to see hundreds of units pitting against each other in a single battle. Comes with a huge variety of units\buildings to boot. Ranging from Tech1, 2, 3 and finally experimental. Each faction (out of 4) are completely different from each other, be it units or buildings. You pick the faction that suits your play style the most. It's in depth as there are countless of possible strategies that you can come up with. Be it spamming a shitload of T1 units to swarm your opponent, overpower them with higher tech, or you could even just turtle all the way to victory via nukes and artillery. You wont expect the 'typical RTS bullshit' point system where you have 'unlock' certain units\function\blabla. *Ahem* RedAlert3. No, every game is fully fledged, you play the game how you want it to be without lame limitations. And oh yeah, air units here have fuel.

There's plenty to talk about how good this game is, but then it would defeat the purpose of actually getting the game and enjoying it first hand. By yourself.

One of the greatest RTS games of the millenium, Supreme commander is considered by most to be the Crisis of strategy games, showcasing intense strategic gameplay and stunning graphics that for its time, were very advanced. In the mass opinion of Supreme Commander fans, this game far exceeds its sequel "Supreme Commander 2"- regarded as a very dumbed-down game due to its console port background. 

Gameplay:
Using a combination of resource management, harvesting, and expansion, the player must use two basic resources to gain the tactical advantage over his enemies, and often his allies- Energy and mass. Whilst mass is used to construct buildings, and units, energy is partially used to run structures and some larger units too. Energy is consumed by the buildings based on tehir activity and is subject to fluctuation based on the energy generated and energy consumed. For example, if a player built a single energy generator, and then built a factory and set it on continuous production of troop transports (all tier 1), this would cause energy to drain massively as teh factory is using more energy than is being generated and/or stored... 

Unit Classification:
Units can be divided into 3 classes with subsequent tiers. Tier 1 are the starting tech and are relatively weak albeit fast. 
Tier 2 units are generally improved on all fronts except maneuvering speed in land cases and tier 3 are the same, the most noticable aspect of all being their damage increase and hitpoints. Air Units in thsi game have fuel tanks and if run out mid flight will crash land and die (quite realistic). 
The three unit classes are Land, air and naval, each featuring an engineer that can use that terrain.

Experimentals:
An excellent Idea cenceived in this game was the expeerimental class (unnoficial tier 4). These units are so big, that it will take a while to construct one and require large amounts of resources whilst also being directly constructed without the use of a factory. (I recommend using quite a few negineer robots to manufacture one and make sure you can spare the enrgy for fabrication).
Some of the units range from collossal air units to enourmous walking land units to intimidating naval ships, all with their own capabilities and special features (i.e. large lasers, remote aircraft manufacture and storage).

Overall Impression:
Fantastic game, moderately additictive with graphics that even today, would make you gasp and potentially enourmous maps (some can be up to 1500 square kilometers). In debth resource management and decent tactical pathfindging make this game entertaining whilst also allowing decent if not slightly dated multiplayer co-op.

There are literally two games in which the zerg rush will fail you miserably. Wargame: AirLand Battle and Supreme Commander + Forged Alliance (I count it as one as it is an expansion off of Supreme Commander). There are no overpowered units, not by a long shot. There are weak units and there are strong units and, really, the only determinant is the tier of the unit. Sure, you can have units that wipe out entire armies, navies and air forces in less than the blink of an eye (well, not exactly, but you get the idea), but they aren't unstoppable, and they have their weaknesses. You can build a Collosus and it can get taken down very quickly and efficiently if the other team plays its cards right. I don't think I've seen a game outside of a tactical strategy game, like Wargame, in which positioning, composition and your skill factors in so much. Between managing and micromanaging hundreds of units, maximizing resource income and keeping up with what is happening on the map, you barely have enough time to draw one calm breath. Beautifully done, masterfully expanded, and chaotically organized. By far one of the best Real Time Strategy game I've ever played, or every will play.

This game was one of the most innovative releases back in its time and I sometimes log in to play from time to time.

This is the stand-alone expansion for Supreme Commander, which in turn is the spirital successor to Total Annihilation.  Neither this nor vanilla Supreme Commander effectively recaptures the magic of T.A., but that's okay because it's still a great game.  This game fixes most of the problems that people experienced playing Supreme Commander (balance & performance mainly) and adds in a ton of new units.  I've never played the story, so I can't help you there, but the skirmish mode is endless fun.  

One major point:  This game (and SupComm) pretty much ruined RTS games for me.  In these games one can zoom out so far that they can see the entire battlefield, then pick a spot and zoom all the way down until all they can see is a single unit.  It's amazing.  Trying to go back to other RTS games is impossible now because the zoom level on those games feels ridiculously restrictive.

I played the beta for SupCom, so I have to admit, I knew what i was buying. This game is ambitious, and sets out to accomplish alot. The only thing really holding this game back from greatness is the blandness in play style of the races. I will explain

Graphically, this game is very appealing, because of its size, scope, and style. It feels like real war, visually, and the mapping possibilities are endless. The maps are a little nondescript sometimes, and the models aren't exactly high poly, but the trade off for size of the battlefield is well worth it.

The Orchestral themes are nice, but a little short. It feels like they have about 5 tracks of music for the whole game. The sound effects are just right, but nothing special

Gameplay is what really makes this game a winner. The size, scale, variety of tactics and unit types make this game amazing to play, you just have to experience it for yourself, it's awesome.However, barring aesthetic differences, the races play almost identically. I think more could have been done to make their play styles distinctive. That is really this games one failing. It is still very much worth an RTS fans money.

A truely unique RTS game, which stands out as a great game for local area multiplayer. The single player campaign is all right, but pretty forgettable. 
I've spend hours playing this game with my friends and I never played a RTS that allowed players to become pretty decent after just a few matches. This is true due to an emphasis on overall strategy as opposed to apm like it is the case in the StarCraft series.

The only negative about this game is that it does not have Dual Core or greater support.  It can slow down on the massive maps when there are a thousand units in play.  Other than that, this is the best RTS I have ever played.  Each side has very distinct characteristics that complement how you want to play.  The sides enable you to play how you want to.  The campaign is actually fairly enjoyable as well.  Of all of the Supreme Commander titles, this is the best.  2 does not hold a candle to it.

How do I even start reviewing Supreme Commander: Forged Alliance? I think I'll start by telling about something that happened earlier today while I was playing a multiplayer match, an experience that quite well describes several of the qualities of this game. It was quite late into the game, about 30-40 min in and everyone had grown quite powerful. My Armored Command Unit, your most important unit that you use to build your whole army and whose death means you're out of the game in most cases, was under heavy attack from a swarm of Gunships and a Heavy Artillery Installation firing away from the other side of the map. I managed to bring my fighter planes in to take care of the enemy Gunships but the ACU was really low on health, another devastating artillery shell was incomming and if it hit I would be out of the game. The shell was going straight for it's target, I was going to lose. But I did not, straight above the ACU the shell hit an unfortunate fighter passing above and destroyed it. An artillery shell from the other side of the map hit a ridiculously small and fast moving fighter plane, I could hardly believe my eyes.

There is an unbelievable attention to detail in this game, every projectile is calculated individually which adds great tactical depth. Good micro and smart use of the lay of the land can have a significant effect on the outcome of a skirmish as shots might miss,  impact hills, rocks or units they where not intended for. This combined with the games truly epic scale brings one of the game's few minor drawbacks, seven years after release even the fastest computers have to slow down when literally thousands of futuristic aircraft clash.

The scale is another thing worth mentioning, the size of the maps range from quite small 5x5km maps to the enomous 81x81km battlefields that it take several minutes for even the fastest units to cross. So no matter if you want to wage war for hours against 7 opponents or if you're interested in intense StarCraft styled matches Forged Alliance will provide.
   There is also a great variety of units, from small land scouts that take seconds to build to colossal experimental units that could take hours for a single engineer to construct but are able to singlehandly defeat huge armies. The balance between units is good, all four factions are viable and almost all units fill some role during some part of the game without any unit standing out as particularly overpowered which is quite impressive as there are hundreds of them.

To summarize, this game is a polished gem. The gameplay, both single- and multiplayer, is great, the design is amazing, the sands of time hardly seem to affect the game at all and the replay value is close to infinite. I'm a huge fan of real-time strategy games and I honestly believe that Supreme Commander: Forged Alliance is the apex of the genre.

SupCom is war on a huge scale, a game where powerful death machines are capable of wiping out hundreds of units before they are brought to their knees and maps are measured in tens of kilometres.  Automation and specialised units let you plan outlandish offensives involving multiple coordinated strikes.

It's not easy to figure out the economy but if you stick with it I promise you'll love it.  If you can't figure out how to balance your economy or need prettier graphics give SupCom 2 a try.  It loses some of the charm but is a lot easier to learn how to play.

Graphics have been improved greatly along with pathfinding, textures, and detail while maintaining the core features of the first game. It also adds a new faction to use: The Serephim. The other three factions must find a way to unite in order to survive the onslought and free thier worlds from the oppression of this race. Will these brave commanders succede? Or will they be "cleansed" ?

If you want to have massive battles, love to research, and to fight on land, in the air, and in sea, then get this and you won't be disappointed! There are also people who still play this on multiplayer, so you can have fun endlessly. Also there are mods availible.

The best RTS on the block. Massive battles with units ranging from tiny robots to huge battle-changing experimental robots that cut giant swaths of destruction in their path. Units are balanced against each other but not in a 'rock/paper/scissors' fashion but tiered. Upper tier units can be defeated by superior numbers but lower tier units pack less of a punch. The interface is also fantastic, allowing you to program long strings of build commands, attack commands, coordinated attacks, patrol commands, etc... You can even save good build plans you like so you can use them again in later games. Forged Alliance added new units and while it's an expansion, it DOES NOT REQUIRE SUPREME COMMANDER. It will run on its own containing everything in Supreme Commander. And don't bother with Supreme Commander 2. We don't speak of its heretical existence. SupCom:FA is the alpha and the omega. Long live Total Annihilation!

A well designed strategy game with alot of depth and hundreds to thousands of units on screen. Battles are epic reguardless if they're land, sea or air or a few scout bots to armies scaling kilometers long. Does take some getting used to.
'Tis an awesome game.
This game is pretty amazing, the big maps you'll need a powerful computer to run but overall the units, maps, story, and gameplay just make this an incredible experience for any strategy lover.
Probably my most favorite RTS. Giant Robots and nukes galore!

Awesome STAND-ALONE expansion of Supreme Commander. I'd say it is on par with SupCom 1 but it add's a 4th faction to the battle, the alien race known as the Seraphim.

I played this game for countless hours before it arrived on Steam. The skirmishes battles can take hours to complete which gives you a great idea for the longevity of matches.

Like SupCom 1, if you dig TRUE RTS games with BASE-BUILDING, then get expansion!
Epic awesome huge robots fire nukes at each other, the game.

The closest remake you'll get to the original Total Annihilation so far, this game does nearly everything right, but the engine lets it down on the larger size engagements (talking 1000's of units) but don't worry; it doesn't get laggy without reason.

Ideally, I recommend you find some mates to play it with, as the online is pretty average without FAForever, a 3rd party server browser, which I talk about in this blog post: http://tehrawt.blogspot.com/2011/12/supreme-commander-forged-alliance-is-on.html

Regardless, it's definitely worth a buy if you liked any of the other SupComs or the original TA.

A good and complex RTS title. If you like epic battles and science fiction than this is probably the game for you. The campaign is nice though nothing exceptional (and if you want to play it I suggest starting with "Supreme Commander" instead of this stand-alone expansion) but the game truly shines in Skirmish & Multiplayer.
Maps range from about 20x20km to about 80x80km while units meassure between 10 and 100+ meters in size and ranges vary froma couple hundred meters to several kilimeters.
Every battle feels epic, realistically scaled and just great! (Though the ressource management might need some time to get used to - but once you are it's great as well!)
A fantastic strategy game with 'a bit' of mass killing.  Get it!
this game is so much fun and u get to make things go boooom :)

I would recomend this game to all the Total Anniolahhion fans out there.

Hail to the king of the franchise! The expansion here is the reason my brother and me had lan parties that went to 5 in the morning for one game. The game is amazing! The learning curve on it is pretty steep, but the expansion makes sure you played the original too. Both are awesome and this explains why the colition in supreme commander 2 was even made. So if you want to know the hardcore roots of supreme commander 2 be ready for something completely awesome!
